39435481.review:
Hiveswap is a well written and amusing point and click adventure game.  It's apparently based on the webcomic Homestuck, which I have never read, but I found this to be no hinderance to my enjoyment of the game so if you've never read it either, don't let that stop you from trying this game out if you are a fan of adventure games.

The game takes place in the 90's and starts with the main character Joey and her brother Jude playing in the front yard.  Things quickly go south when a bunch of monsters crash their afternoon and Joey ends up trapped in the house and Jude in his treehouse fort.  You will mostly play as Joey and will spend the first half of the game trying to reach the safety of the attic with a couple of brief forays as Jude in the treehouse providing backup to Joey.   I don't want to say too much more due to spoilers but as you can see if you have looked at any of the screenshots, about two thirds of the way through the game Joey is going to be blasted to an alien world and things will get weird.

Gameplay is traditional point and click fare with Joey collecting items and then using them on each other or on the environment in order to solve puzzles.  Early on you also gain the ability to tap dance and ballet dance (Joey is an aspiring dancer/veterinarian.....don't ask) and you can use these abilities also to solve problems.  Its fairly standard stuff and if you've ever played an adventure game before, you will be right at home.

The art style is a simple comic book style for the main characters but everything is well animated and that really helps brings things to life.  The background art is bright and colourful and everything is packed with detail.  All in all its a very nice looking game and I had a lot of fun exploring it.

Sound and music is a mixed bag.  I liked the music a lot but the sound effects were sparse and often mixed quite low compared to the rest of the sound.  It's by no means a deal breaker but it just makes some of the moments feel a bit odd as they can feel bizarrely quiet.  There is no speech, but that's fine.  Id rather no speech than bad voice acting and it lets my imagination make up character appropriate voices.  So yeah, sound is a weird one but its a minor gripe more than anything.

As far as the story goes, this is the first episode so a lot of it is build up.  You can see the game putting the pieces in place  and doing a lot of character and world building that feel like they won't pay off fully until later.  That said I enjoyed my playtrhough and am really looking forward to what comes next, which is about the best you can expect from the first part of an episodic series.  It should leave you wanting episode two and it does just that.

The biggest plus to this game for me was that using every item, either on another item or something in the environment, has its own specific text.  This is not a game where you are going to see a generic "That does not work" style message.  Literally every single item in the game has its own text depending on what you use it on.   Try and put the pigeon in the microwave and the game will let you know that it recognises what you just tried to do and it thinks you are a monster for example.  None of this stuff is essential but it is often hilarious and its the kind of detail that I adore in a well written adventure as it makes even the most crazy of actions rewarding, just to see what the game has to say about what you just did.  Trying everything on everything so I could read the humorous responses added about two hours to my playtime as I just messed about with everything.  It also helped give insight into the characters thought processes as their different world views are reflected in the way they game describes their responses to the actions you take.  Its good stuff and I had a lot of fun mucking about.  

All up this was a great opening and I can't wait for the rest of the series.  Here's hoping Act 2 is not quite as long a wait as Act 1 was.

If you are a fan of humorous adventures, pick it up.  It's very much the love letter to 90's adventures it bills itself as and the more people that get it, the more chance we have that this series will actually reach its long awated completion.

39419680.review:
Review originally posted [url=https://www.backlog-assassins.net/posts/9bjqa5l]here[/url].

7/10

After a long arduous road with many setbacks that I won’t super get into (see official version above and this unverified summary here), I finally got the game my girlfriend and I pooled an embarrassing amount of money together to help fund. (Or, rather, part of that game)

And… it was lovely.

While I can’t make judgments on the story yet - this is the first act, it’s all set up - the actual playing of the game was fun. This is the most gorgeous point-and-click I’ve played with dozens of lovingly rendered backgrounds that are FULL of shit to click on. The entire game is 2D animated and it is fluid as fuck. The actual gameplay, as it stands, is definitely on the easy side of point and clicks - no moon logic puzzles here, just a lot of shit to explore. The good ol’ Homestuck charm is in full-force, though I definitely get the sense that Hussie did not write the majority of this game, though maybe that’s just me.

You don’t need to have read Homestuck to play this game, though I would encourage anybody to give it a try. It’s a daunting undertaking, especially as it got more and more crushed under its own weight at the end. Hell, I never even finished the thing - I think I still have about 100 pages and the big flash animation to go, but I just couldn’t care anymore. My favorite parts of Homestuck were Acts 1 to 4 and what’s wonderful is this game brought me right back to that joy and anticipation - plucky kids fucking around in their bizarre homes with a lot of slick jabs and a lot of ‘oh, what’s next?’ Homestuck is worth a read just for that. Give Hiveswap a try, and if you like that, there’s so so so much more where that came from.

Hiveswap: Act 2 is set to launch in spring 2018, and I’m eager to play it when it does.

39379360.review:
I have to say, even coming from having read NOTHING at all about homestuck, that i greatly enjoyed this game. The characters are endearing, especially Xefros (poor guy), and the sarcasm and humor are excellently executed. There are rather a lot of puns, but there's no character that does them constantly.
Also as someone who grew up in the 90s a ton of the pop culture references hit right back at my childhood. Ah Bubsy. (FYI all Bubsy games are terrible).
Sure the game is short, IF you only move straight forward and progress the story. If you instead examine everything the game has interesting comments and humor about just about everything you could possibly interact with, similar to the escape from monkey island series. (hint: try combining the tap shoes with the pogs)
So definitely looking forward to act 2 and more of the stalwart Joey, adorable Xefros, geeky Jude, and possibly getting to actually interact with the enigmatic Tetrarch Dammek.

Ich würde das Spiel wirklich gerne mögen. Ich habe Homestuck lange Zeit mit großem Vergnügen verfolgt, und ich wusste, dass ein Spiel in der Mache war, habe mich dann aber nicht mehr wirklich damit beschäftigt. Dann sah ich es auf Steam und dachte, ich schaue es einfach mal an.

Gut:
- Sehr schöne und detaillierte Hintergründe
- Stellenweise wirklich komisch
- Viele Anspielungen für Leute, die den Webcomic kennen

Schlecht:
- Zu einfach. Eigentlich weniger ein Point&Click-Adventure als ein Walking Simulator. Kein einziger Gedanke nötig.
- Das Spiel ist sehr kurz. Ja, es ist nur der erste Akt, aber die Fertigkeiten der Figuren werden alle zusammen nur eine Handvoll Mal benötigt.
- Auch ein kurzes Spiel kann einen Handlungsstrang interessant zu einer Zwischenlösung bringen. 

Insgesamt ein schön aussehendes und gut geschriebenes Spiel, das am Ende einfach nur enttäuscht, weil es zu nichts führt.

39216864.review:
To be honest, this game isn't that great as a game. It's a pretty easy point n click adventure game. It's much better as a visual novel. I'd rather not use that term to describe it because all I think of is those shitty anime things, but it kinda works. The game's characters are well written, the story, while linear was interesting enough for me to keep playing. It was also really short which is unfortunate. It took me just under three hours to finish it. I could have easily finished it in two if I didn't read all the optional text in the game. 

A couple of other miscellanious things. There's one music track I liked, the rest was very monotonous and I eventually turned it off. The art is fantastic and great to look at. The writing, while it did keep me interested, was very wordy and dense. It got a bit annoying after a while. As far as I can tell this is same kind of writing used in the comic this game was based off of. 

A lot of reviewers said that this game could be enjoyed by people who aren't fans of the comic Homestuck. I guess the game and the comic share a universe. I've tried to read the comic in the past and I couldn't get into it. So I got some of the references to it in the game but not others. Despite that I still enjoyed the game's plot. I think fans of Homestuck might be more enthusiastic about this game and are more willing to forgive its problems. 

I think I'd still pick up the next one. I know this one had a nasty development so maybe the next one will be a better game to go with the good story. If you aren't a fan of the comic I'd say pick this game up on sale or ideally wait to see if ACT 2 is better before committing.

39213504.review:
I recommend that before you purchase Hiveswap you at least read a bit of Homestuck so that you can understand the type of humor that is used within the game. Hiveswap Act 1 is a pretty good point and click that doesn't go into the "what the fuck do I do" territory but also doesn't enter into "this is far too easy" territory. It remains at the correct level of difficulty and pacing.

The humor of Hiveswap isn't for everyone, which is definitely why I recommend you read at least a bit of Homestuck. You definitely don't need to read the whole series (you'd probably spend a year trying to do that), but I recommend you try to get a feeling for how the humor in Hiveswap operates.

The game doesn't require a firm understanding of Homestuck, but there are some fan-nods here and there, and parts of the plot can be further enjoyed by someone who does know Homestuck, but the game can still be enjoyed by someone who doesn't.

However, the game isn't very long, and can be completed in one sitting (as I did). Because of this I don't think the price is entirely reasonable, but I did have fun throughout the time I played the game. The animations, music, and everything else was very well done.

39197444.review:
Итак. В отличие от многих других любителей "Хоумстака" я довольно давно забросила фандом из-за, во-первых, постоянного ожидания, во-вторых, не самых лучших отзывов об окончании истории. Но well, когда ты видишь игру по фандому, который когда-то был вполне неплох, то ты просто обязан в нее сыграть? Правильно? Правильно.

Из плюсов этой игры:

- Анимация и стилизация. Они здесь действительно чудесные, плюс полностью повторяют стиль оигинального комикса. Заставляет поностальгировать, знаете. 
- Музыка. Я, конечно, не знаю, чего еще можно ожидать от Тоби Фокса, но музыкальные темы здесь действительно хороши. Правда,  не настолько хороши, чтобы слушать их ОТДЕЛЬНО от игры, но  во время прохождения они добавляют атмосферности.
- Сюжет полон довольно милых моментов. Некоторые из них, правда, довольно, э... Необычные. Но все еще милые.
- Между делом упоминаются несколько неплохих поучительных моментов о дружбе-семье-самооценке and all that bullshit. Если вы цените такие вещи (я ценю) - они здесь есть, hooray. 
- Куча отсылок к "Хоумтаку" (что очевидно). Фанатам комикса будет забавно искать и находить их ( спойлер: Джон все еще любит синих леди)
- И я просто обязана выделить отдельным пунктом ЭТИХ ЧУДЕСНЫХ ЛУСУСОВ, О БОЖЕ МОЙ? ОНИ ТАКИЕ МИЛЫЕ.

Из минусов:

- Начнем с того, что эта игра  стоит того, чтобы тратить на неё время, только в двух случаях: а) Вы фанат "хоумстака, б) вам совершенно некуда деть три часа. То есть. Эта игра на самом деле неплохая. Она милая и все такое. Но ВСЕГО ТРИ ЧАСА? С учетом того, что вы будете читать абсолютно все, тыкать на все находящиеся в зоне виимости предметы и обращать внимание на каждую мелочь? Учитывая то, что в конце история обрезана, а продолжение, следуя добрым хоумстаковским традициям, может выходить годами? ... возможно перед приобретением игры следует подождать хотя бы выхода второго акта.  ХОТЯ БЫ.
- Не то чтобы минус, но было небольшим разочарованием лично для меня. Персонажи здесь...ну. Они вам или нравятся, или нет. Игра (как уже сказано выше) слишком короткая, чтобы у вас была возможность глубоко познакомиться с ними. Так что если вам кто-то не понравился? Даа, скорее всего ваше мнение не изменится. 
- Если вы не читали комикс, то вы во-первых не поймете кучи шутеечек, являющихся важными частями сюжета, а во-вторых, части сюжета. Возможно большей части. 
- Игра лагает. Иногда сильно. В моем случае каждый раз после выстрела, который должен был отвлечь монстров, игра "умирала" минимум на пару минут. Плюс, временами изображение после загрузки подгружается не сразу, диалоги прокручивались даже в том случае, если я не нажимала на клавиши...в общем да. Если у вас будет что-то подвисать - это нормально. Подожите. Скорее всего, оно отвиснет.

Подводя итоги: милая ли это игра? Да. Интересна ли она для того, кто был или является фанатом "хоумстака"? Да, очень. Тратила бы я на неё свое время, зная, что на данный момент в ней проработано только самое начало истории, при том, что игра линейная, не дает игроку особой свободы выбора и не имеет СУПЕР выдающегося сюжета (по крайней мере в начале. То есть хей, он правда очень милый и я не сожалею, что сыграла, и с удовольствием продолжу играть после обновления...но вряд ли вспомню детали уже через пару недель. Прости, Зефрос, твое имя сново будет забыто)? Скорее всего нет. По крайней мере не сейчас. Может быть, когда игра бы вышла целиком...что вряд ли случится в ближайшее время. 
В любом случае: если вы фанат оригинального комикса и у вас лапки чешутся поиграть - вперед. Если же вы вполне можете подождать до появления хотя бы втоого акта? Подождите. Абсолютно ничего не потеряете.

39172481.review:
Once there was one amazing interactive webcomics, the name Homestuck. Have you read it or maybe played it when it was still “interactive”? Either way it's still there on mspaintadventures.com. You can go and read it. It's quite something. HIVESWAP are set in the same universe with Homestuck, but earlier on the timeline, so you don't really need to know whatever happens in the Homestuck to play this. But you may want to, you know? It's good.

Anyway, we have a classic point & click game here. It's quite short since it's only a first act (and I READLLY HOPE isn't the last one), but attention to the details is quite shocking and unlike old p&c games you won't need to hunt down that damn little pixel on the screen to interact with or fathom insanity by combining everything with anything in order to progress the story or just freaking stuck since you happen to forget something IMPORTANT f-k if you know where and there is no way back. Have you heard about the infamous Rubber Duck Puzzle in The Longest Journey? And that's only the entrance to the rabbit hole. This may shed some light on the subject cracked.com/article_19974_the-6-most-absurdly-difficult-video-game-puzzles.html ... or won't, since even though there are puzzles in HIVESWAP this clustertruck won't happen here. At least not in the first act and I hope it won't happen in the following acts either.

However, that doesn't mean you won't be able doing crazy stuff. In fact game will actually reward you for doing crazy stuff with secret achievements or hilarious comments. So, if you an achievement hunter then you might want to use a walkthrough since you'll most likely miss half of them if you go on your own. Unless, you really want to go on a quest of combining everything with anything.

And here we are, I wrote three paragraphs of text already and this is the fourth one and I still haven't told much about the game. Except for being small since it's only a first act, and haven't given you a comprehensible list of pros and cons either. Know what? I haven't found any cons so far and without cons there is no reason to make a list of pros since there is nothing to balance out. Except, maybe, this whole “chapters” concept, which is quite understandable, but frustrating anyway. I don't like to wait for the next act to be released. I want the WHOLE GAME and I want it RIGHT NOW, but I do understand that without being divided into small portions that “whole game” thingamajig may never actually happen. So, I'll wait for the next chapter and play it ASAP. You may want to wait for the whole game, though. Ah, right, it also lacks voice acting, but I can't really pin this to the cons list.

So, this is amazing first chapter of potentially amazing point & click adventure which is going to happen. Yes, I do believe in these guys enough to think it will happen unless the World just suddenly End. We just have to live long enough to let it happen to us.

And if you read this when all chapters already released you are one LUCKY BAS/TARD! It might be good to be you. Say hello to the future me, please.

Si vous aussi vous avez adoré les aventures de Pouce-Pouce, Sam Pyjam et les premiers King's Quest, alors vous serez servis...
Voilà un moment que je n'avais pas autant accroché à un point and click! Pas depuis les Monkey's Island au moins, ou la série des Chevaliers de Baphomet!

Et bien voilà un digne héritier du genre. L'histoire est originale et captivante, et surtout les dessins sont superbes! Chaque pièce de chaque "chapitre" est designée avec soin, c'est un véritable plaisir de voir les personnages évoluer dans cet univers. J'ai déjà un faible pour l'animation 2D en général, mais là aussi la qualité dépasse mes attentes! 

Hiveswap regroupe absolument tous les critères qui selon moi font un bon jeu d'aventure:

- Une histoire originale et intéressante (ça ne va pas toujours de paire)
- Des personnages variés et tous aussi charismatiques
- Un character design rafraîchissant (simple et efficace)
- Des décors superbes (avec une vraie touche artistique)
- Une band son à la hauteur des précédents critères
- De l'humour!

Une super surprise, j'ai hâte de pouvoir jouer à la suite! 10/10

Não sou o maior fã do gênero, mas este jogo me agradou imensamente. Um point-and-click simples com um enredo envolvente de uma garotinha chamada Joey, que passa seu tempo resolvendo puzzles. Basicamente é um point-and-click de puzzles.

O que mais me agradou foi a belissima arte deste jogo, essa animação à mão é um trabalho que muitos veem como algo inferior por ser simples, mas da um toque especial na obra, além da propria animação, há tambem as artes do fundo cheio de referências que da um toque especial no ideia de ser criança. Agora, se você é fã de homestuck, ta perdendo tempo lendo isso e vá logo jogar :D

9/10 - Motivos: 
[list] [*]Para um jogo simples de 2017, faltou um pouco de empenho nos bugs que não chegam a estragar o game mas faz com que perca a toda emoção.
[*]Animações as vezes com poucos frames, dando uma ideia de "lag" que não é o caso.
[*]Por ultimo e o mais grave que eu acho foi a falta de tradução, um jogo baseado em leitura deveria se dar ao trabalho de pelo menos traduzir nas principais linguas. 
[/list]
Obs. Se você não sabe ao menos um pouco de ingles, talvez seja um pouco difícil aproveitar a obra.

39108235.review:
Wow.. that was just adorable. 

I have to admit that I have never heard of Homestuck before.. but I'll be looking into it after playing the first act of this game I received in the January 2018 Humble Monthly.

The humour was cute, the underlying themes were interesting, the character dynamics had me interested from the get-go. It seemed a strange set-up initially but the further it went along the more adorable and relatable the characters, and oddly the world, became.

There were a lot of references to things that I enjoyed as a kid so it had a little bit of nostalgia value and if that mummy in the hallway isn't a reference to Cousin Ted from Day of the Tentacle I'll be very surprised.

Some of the animation is not as consistent in some parts as it is in others, but it wasn't enough to chuck a fizz over or complain about. Hopefully as they continue along with further acts they might have a chance to clean some of those up - or otherwise make it clearer that the stilted cutscenes were for effect rather than looking unfinished.

I really enjoyed the music. There were points in the game where I just left it running while I went off to do other things with the music playing in the background so my playtime might be a little bit extended were you to just play it without stopping. But besides running out to put the laundry on or do some dishes with the music in the background I didn't stop playing the first act of this game until I finished it.

The illustrations that play while the credits scroll were also just so lovely to sit through and it felt like leaving new friends a little (wow, that sounds  really sad and pathetic.. I guess I just haven't enjoyed a point and click adventure game for a long time). They've definitely hit the feel that they were going for in the games description.

I really look forward to following its progress and seeing where this story takes us.

39104002.review:
I really liked this game and I would recommend it to my friends, but it's not entirely problem free. I like to end things positively so I'll start this with the negatives...

Cons:
-Typos... a lot actually for a published game. Main game play is free as far as I can tell, but the otherwise nice flavor text you get by having objects interact with each other is full with them.
-Music... I didn't find the background music as bad as some, but coming to this game from Homestuck leaves much to be desired. The music that plays while you're playing and the music that plays during important scenes have almost no distinction making their emotional impact practically non-existent. I feel that if you replaced the soundtrack with generic free internet music there wouldn't have been a big difference.
-References... there's not enough to completely alienate someone who's never read Homestuck, but there are some that could confuse the player. They're worded in a way that sounds like a funny inside joke... but they don't know the joke. It's not a deal breaker but it is something to keep in mind.
-Point and click mechanics... they aren't bad but not really polished. The click box is just not where it should be sometimes. You have to do a little search to get what you're looking for.

Pros:
+Trolls!... this is purely a Homestuck thing, but it's pretty exciting to see new grey aliens to love!
+Solid characters!... this comes as no surprise considering Andrew Hussie had his hands on this, but it's still refreshing to have characters that you can instantly tell the difference between both physically AND mentally! There's only three real characters that you interact with in Act 1, but they all have unique interests and hobbies like actual people. They even act like the teenagers (and possibly young almost-adult(?)) that they are.
+Plot!... admittedly not too much was revealed as this seemed to be largely a story set up and character introduction act but what was revealed in interesting and has me hooked in order to find out the answers.
+Flavor text!... I know I said that the flavor text has a lot of typos but it's still fun to read and reveals plenty of tasty tidbits about the characters. For anyone who obsessively combed though Homestuck for clues, this will be a field day for you! For those who didn't, well it's still nice to uncover more about the world and experience delightfully sassy narration to your dumb item combinations.
+Accessibility... while there references to Homestuck, I imagine this would still be a good game to the uninitiated. It has some good world building that I can appreciate and has a much more acceptable... "vocabulary" than the webcomic it's based off of which would make it better for a wider audience (Homestuck has some colorful words that are NOT child friendly).

Overall, there are technical issues with this game, but they're largely minor and most casual players wouldn't notice. It's only when you sink several hours into uncovering all the goodies that you'd notice anything off.

39041192.review: Considering the lengthy and troubled development this game had (switching from 3D to 2D and even changing developers to a brand-new in-house studio), Hiveswap had no right to be this good. While the animation has very limited frames, the art all looks great, the music is great, I loved all the characters, and the Homestuck references are appreciated but not at all necessary to enjoy the game. 39036520.review:
It's basically Homestuck, but in Visual Novel form (but disguised as a point-and-click adventure, because Homestuck). You don't necessarily have to know anything about Homestuck to enjoy it. But if you enjoyed Homestuck you will enjoy this, and if you didn't enjoy homestuck you won't enjoy this.

Every single item you collect can be used with every single examinable- or interactable- object for a unique piece of text, mostly silly jokes or character-revealing snippets. So if you're like me, the plot will progress at a glacial pace and the experience feels exactly like the early acts of Homestuck, only more immersive. And if you're not into that, it'll be over fairly quickly.

On the plus side, it avoids the incredibly long wall of text chatlogs and narration that plagued Homestuck's later acts; whether you're exploring every interaction or not, the pace always feels organic.

Again, if you are a fan of Homestuck you will love this. If you couldn't stand Homestuck's pacing, you may not like this. If you haven't read Homestuck, you should probably do that first, if only because it is free and this game is not.

38999404.review:
An excellent game with charming characters, catchy music, and lovely, whimsical art.

Be warned, this is likely more enjoyable for people who really love reading and exploring. And clicking on everything.
Otherwise, the game is rather short, but there is more to come in future installments.
Despite it's shortness, there is a lot in it for people who like exploring as I mentioned previously.
You can combine objects in your inventory to get different results, and even comedic narratives if your combo results in nothing else. Not to mention, there is dialogue for nearly EVERY item in the surrounding scenery, so be sure to click on everything and click every object on everything.
There is actually a lot of lore hidden in the narrations of everything you click on. From lore about the world, to the quirks and personality of our main characters, you can learn a lot from the funny flavor text boxes.

The game is fairly easy in terms of puzzles and I only found myself stuck on what to do next once.
It has an easy to follow narrative and easy to understand gameplay that requires little mastery.

As for it's relation to Homestuck, you do not need ANY prior knowledge of Homestuck in order to enjoy this game. Having read Homestuck is just a little bonus, as there are some references to it here and there that gave me a chuckle, being  a longtime Homestuck fan.

Overall, Hiveswap: Act 1 is a fantastic, albeit short, game that I highly recommend getting into now, while it's fresh out of the oven.
Knowing Homestuck, this whole thing is likely to start rolling pretty soon. Both in story and with real life, with it's fans.

38968088.review:
Something of a confession to get out of the way before I actually go in and review this game. I was a major Homestuck fan in my youth, and still enjoy the actual material quite a bit. However, I haven't been attached to the fandom for quite a while now. This won't really impact my review, but considering i'm reviewing a Homestuck game... yeah. It's necessary.

It's a game that feels like the Homestuck webseries. That is essentially the best way to explain this game to someone. If they ask, "What's Homestuck?", then they're not in the right demographic for this game. It's not that someone who hasn't been exposed to the comic can't enjoy the game. It's more that they won't be receiving a complete experience, and with an asking price of eight dollars for a game that took me sub two hours to complete, I can't imagine it being worth the price of admission.

As for the actual game, it's a fairly typical point-and-click adventure game with some added bling. Quite a few interactions happen via a communication device to talk with other characters that you can play as. There is a solid main character, but these other sequences with supporting characters do well in breaking things up. The other notable feature is the STRIFE! battles. Now, these aren't true battles. They're more like flashy puzzles. But they're distinct enough from the actual puzzles that I feel like mentioning them. They're fun little diversions with some witty dialogue, but nothing really that special. 

Story wise, it's hard to judge considering this is the first chapter of the story. All I can really say is that it's a good setup that manages to leave some good questions to be answered later down the line and establishes the universe to the extent that it's needed for the plot. I like all the characters that have been introduced. They each feel suitably unique, and the dialogue is all excellently written, which is something of a must for a game that's mostly dialogue. 

Overall, it's not a revolutionary game. But it doesn't really need to be one. It sets out to make a nice homestuck adventure game, and does that very well. Wether it squanders the potential it has is yet to be seen, but i'm personally looking forward to the next act.

38781563.review:
>Going into Hiveswap expecting Homestuck.
No. No. Just stop it there, that's not what you should be focusing on, or looking for. Instead, you should be treating Hiveswap as its' own property, and stop constantly comparing it to Homestuck just because it's made by the guy who made Homestuck. It's not going to be based in Homestuck, will not be focused on Homestuck, and Homestuck characters will likely remain Homestuck - specific characters, as far as we've seen now. So if you're here for something that's like Homestuck or is the "spiritual succesor" of sorts to it, leave. Because you're going to continue to be disappointed.

Well anyway, other than that, I think the game's fun. As a lot of people said, it is kind of frustrating during the first play when you get stuck in certain places (I was using a guide for most of the Alternia gameplay) and if you don't have the patience to click on everything like me, then it's really annoying.

There are a lot of achievements that I believe pretty much capture that "Hussie" comedy, contrary to most who think it's just a forced attempt at humor. I mean, I think a lot of people forget, this is the man who found enjoyment merely in drawing weird human-animal abominations with giant bulging muscles and shit. Got all on my second playthrough except for the seemingly elusive "Ourous" achievement, which only that one guy who probably used the Steam Achievement program got.

It's a very short ride. For my first playthrough, 2 hours (even constantly checking a guide and suffering through an 'unable to interact with anything' bug) and my second, 1 hour, seeing as I'd basically memorized all the choices and skipped through a huge chunk of dialogue.

All in all, I do think that for what it is, the pricing's pretty accurate. I've seen visual novels with no animation like Hiveswap that go for 20 bucks just because "good art", but we've gotten good art, nice animation, and nice music all for 8 bucks. Pretty good deal, if you ask me.

 From my (probably slightly biased) opinion, I can recommend Hiveswap, but I can't confidently say that you will 100% enjoy it.

38768560.review:
A homestuck-themed point-and-click adventure game. As a huge fan of homestuck, I was quite excited for this, but unfortunately I have some gripes with the execution. The game provides very little help when you get stuck, so when a character arbitrarily asks you to fetch her own key before allowing you to proceed and gives absolutely no indication of where she put it no matter how many times you press the literally useless hint button, you can understand if I get a bit annoyed. Most of the homestuck running gags are gone, so no acrobatic pirouettes off the handle will be performed any time soon, which is fine, but they don't seem to want to replace them with anything. The characters are pretty dull, one-note entities with too few chances to meaningfully interact with each other like they would in a webcomic, so despite what some individual scenes or some homestuck style "You are now X" introductions would have you believe, I could sum up all the part 1 characters in about 5 words each. The most interesting characters seem to be the guardians who get zero screen time. I really want to meet this mysterious babysitter, she seems pretty fun, but who knows when/if that will ever happen.

There's also the slight issue that this is incredibly short. I am aware of the drama happening behind the curtains of this particular project, but I'm the kind of guy who enjoys following the main story and only examines random objects in a pretty cursory fashion, so about 2 hours have passed and I've finished the entire thing. I then looked at the achievement list to discover that I missed about everything on it because I didn't decide to feed a stuffed animal with a cracker, but instead spent my time trying to tap dance on a pile of guns and putting a pigeon in a microwave (I'm not weird, shut up). Basically, the achievements just point you to the random comments that the developer thought were the funniest, which would be fine if they weren't all hidden by Steam anyway and required you to rub everything in your inventory against everything in the game world until the friction spontaneously produces Steam achievements (or look up a guide). There was probably a soul-crushing level of effort writing all those possible interactions, but I just didn't want to go look for them. I didn't feel the need to pick every conversation choice in Openbound and I'm not going to waste my time putting batteries in my shoes just in case my character goes on a quick rant about how light-up sneakers are stupid or something.

Ultimately, the game's not horrible, but I feel slightly less impressed with this game's first act than I was at the end of the first act of Homestuck. Yeah, I'm sure the story will pick up from here, and I wouldn't mind spending some time with the sequels when they come out, but as it stands, I can't really recommend this to anyone without it being on a huge sale. Maybe (hopefully) my tune will change like it did with homestuck.

38753074.review:
Absolutely hilarious and charming from start to finish, with very likable characters. Puzzles are somewhat straightforward and simple but still require you to do some thinking. I also was quite amused at some of the little things. For example, I love how the human main character uses tapdancing as her main attack. Yes, tapdancing. It's incredibly random and I love it. I also appreciate the fact that troll typing quirks were HEAVILY downplayed, making them easier to read for anyone not familiar with Homestuck.
Another neat thing about this game is the sheer amount of flavor text. Just about any combination of items and/or background objects can give you a different response. Heck, at one point near the beginning, two pieces of flavor text actually reference each other, and I actually laughed out loud when I saw it. Then again, I laughed out loud quite a lot throughout this game.
That's actually pretty much how I'd describe this game: a laugh-out-loud experience. It's bursting at the seams with humor and charm, and I loved it from start to finish. The only complaint I have is that there's no autosave, but to be perfectly honest, that's more of a nitpick than anything else. Either way, though, I still HIGHLY recommend this game to any fan of point-and-click adventure games, particularly old-school, comedy-oriented ones.

Qu'on soit clairs, le jeu est pas nul en tant que tel, mais je peux pas le recommander au public général dans cet état.
Je le trouve beaucoup trop cher pour son contenu, le jeu étant en effet très court et n'établit pas grand chose au final. Il s'addresse notamment aux fans d'Homestuck, qui, eux, se retrouveront aux anges puisque l'âme du comic est présente jusqu'aux fondations du jeu, jusqu'aux blagues pas drôles qui composent 99% des blagues du comic. Foncez si vous êtes déjà fan. Sinon, renseignez-vous peut-être avant de vous lancer. 

Je n'apprécie pas trop le format épisodique a la Telltale qu'adopte ce jeu. Non pas que je déteste les formats épisodiques : les Mass Effect étant un très bon exemple de ce format étant réussi, car chaque épisode se suffit à lui-même, contrairement à Hiveswap qui, lui, ne peut au final être jugé que par sa suite. Il faudra donc attendre la suite pour savoir si l'acte 1 est recommandable ou pas, et ça c'est dommage.

Graphiquement, le jeu est sublime et a sa propre patte tirée du meilleur d'Homestuck, et montre Hussie et co. à leur meilleur. Les musiques vont de l'oubliable au bon, mais on est loin de ce qu'Homestuck a pu offrir de meilleur. Cependant je ne peux pas juger toute l'OST avec l'acte 1 puisqu'elle est incomplète, et qu'on aura sûrement le droit à une nouvelle claque auditive a la Savior of the Waking World.

C'est vraiment frustrant de ne pouvoir juger Hiveswap qu'à travers la vision réduite du petit trou de serrure qu'est l'acte 1. En bref, à acheter à vos risques et périls.

38647875.review:
FIrst off, regardless of whether or not you've read Homestuck, you'll still be able to enjoy this game and all it has to offer. That said, if you HAVE read all of Homestuck, then you're in for a treat!

Since you've (probably) read the "About This Game" section, I'll spare you exposition and instead focus on my experience playing the game. 

Pros:
+ the enviornments are gorgeous with a lot of detail
+ very nostalgic (Lisa Frank artwork, Connect Four, Simon Says, cartridge-based game consoles, etc.)
+ the characters are well-developed and enjoyable
+ plenty of Homestuck references to pick through
+ Hussie's and his co-writers' humor shines through the dialog
+ every single item in your sylladex can be used with another item or an object in the enviornment for Joey/Jude/Xefros to mentally comment on (for those with OCD who feel compelled to try every single combination, this may be a con...)
+ combat is interesting and involves a combination of using items in your sylladex with your TECHNICHES (for instance, Joey's ballet shoes let her escape/evade enemies)

Neutrals:
/ the animations (including the cutscenes) are just decent
/ the music isn't anything special and becomes tiresome over time
/ as with point-and-click games, you might get stuck figuring out what to do or how to go about doing it
/ not all the items in your sylladex or objects in the environment seem to get used, which means there MIGHT be extra content you can miss in a single playthrough

Cons:
- [insert requisite "this game is TOO short but good enough that I want MORE" comment]
- you'll use your techniches a handful of times as there are only a smattering of fights; it feels like a wasted opportunity to explore a truly unique game mechanic 

Overall, if you enjoy witty humor, endearing characters, and an interesting plot and universe, then you can't go wrong buying this game. I mean, you'd spend more going to a see a 2-hour movie, so what's stopping you? BUY THIS GAME!!

38584886.review:
"Overwhelmingly Positive."  Oh, Homestucks.  Never change.

HIVESWAP: Act 1 is good.  It's a well-designed adventure game (a big hurdle to clear, in my book), but it comes across as more of a visual novel than an adventure game because it doesn't present any kind of challenge -- that's not its purpose.  Its purpose is to tell a Homestuck-parallel story in a Homestuck-like way, and it does that very well.

If you're not familiar with Homestuck, you ought to go read that first before investing here... this game's sense of humor won't make any sense to someone who hasn't internalized the jargon and in-jokes.  That might seem like a failing, but there shouldn't be any mystery regarding exactly for whom this game was designed.  It's a Homestuck game for Homestucks.  Are you a Homestuck?  No?

Read the comic.  Be the Homestuck.

Okay, let's mill some build grist.

I finished Act 1 in two and a half hours with about half the achievements.  I consider that a good investment of US$8.00.

The art and animation in this game is great.  It is inspired by Homestuck, but far more consistent and clean.  On occasion I found myself wishing for a momentary dip into hideous crayon blarg just for old times' sake, but it doesn't happen and I think that's probably a good thing.

The writing is solid, although it lacks any of the occasionally mindblowing japery of Homestuck.  There is a lot of text-bubble reading, which is not a surprise and not necessarily a bad thing.  The puns are... well, they needed a lot of puns.  Some of them work, but brace yourself for the ones that don't.

I am suitably intrigued by the characters, the standalone story, and the subtle and not-so-subtle tie-ins to Homestuck that I will be returning for Act 2, but by relying on what has come before the game has robbed itself of an opportunity to create new inexcusable folly.  Again, though, I don't think that was its purpose.

As a final point, I was surprised by how /much/ this game has to do with Homestuck -- I was expecting a parallel but separate story, but it looks from Act 1 like Hiveswap (or perhaps Hauntswitch) will be tied into the characters and events of the original.  This was not unwelcome, and more importantly I trust the author to be able to do this well.

If I have any complaint about the game, it's that it's not Homestuck enough in its mechanical execution -- I was looking forward to wrestling with a Fetch Modus for my Sylladex and interacting with complex systems like the Cruxtruder-Punch Designix-Totem Lathe-Alchemiter sequence of devices from the early days of Homestuck.  Of course, trying to actually code such a thing would have been an unmitigated disaster, so perhaps it is for the best. 

In short: this is a great start of a game for fans of Homestuck, and if you're not a fan, you should consider becoming one.  It is time well spent.

38401825.review:
I'd sure love to enjoy all this beautiful art, but because this is an adventure game with no quality-of-life features, I have to completely disassociate my perspective and just gradually roll my cursor over the entire screen, click every interactable I find and select every option on it.  Then, after I've retrieved every object, time to go back and try each object on each interactable until something happens.

Games like this have no mechanic to them, no rules to how the universe works, which means all solutions are arbitrary.  For example, an early quest has you searching for properly sized batteries.  You check objects for batteries by clicking them and selecting "scrounge."  In one area, there's a radio, where clicking the radio gives you the option to turn it off.  If you expect the rules of the game to be consistent then, you can easily miss that you need to specifically click on the battery compartment and open it in order to get the scavenge option.  Do that, and you'll wander around, unable to progress the game and not knowing why.  This eventually breaks down to the situation I've describe in the previous paragraph, because the player can't trust the game to present itself honestly.

It's disappointing.  Not worth 8 dollars, not worth two million dollars.

This game... is great. That single word is enough to describe it. 
I was an homestuck fan before playing it, but for all of its winks to the one who read the webcomic, it's totally accessible to someone entirely new to the universe, and that makes it even better. 
- The art style is welcoming, very funny with a great work on the expressions and attitudes.. But the background aren't of lesser quality, it's really a joy to wander in those places and see every little details that are at every turn. 
- The characters are very easy to relate with and you want to be with them on their strange and intense journey. 
- The pacing of the adventure is good, not especially hard, even if sometimes you'll just have a moment to search where you saw said information or object to get past something, so it's not too easy, but not hard enough to make you quit. It's a good balance.
- The story is starting putting itself in place naturally and i can only hope that the next Act to come will be as satisfying.
Bonus point : If you were an 90s kid, you're in for a nostalgia trip~
And to finish, the price is very correct for the lenght and quality of the game, so it's a complete recommendation for me !!!

38186631.review:
Hussie finally, after years of development hell (thanks largely in part to the likely embezzlement of Kickstarter funds by the insolent The Odd Gentlemen studios), delivered the Homestuck game. The major problem with this: It's SHORT. Like, REALLY short. But being episodic and relatively cheap, it's a complaint equal to the amount of love you have for Homestuck in general.

The main character, Joey, is okay. Unlike most of the other characters in Hussie's franchise, she is actually really written into a relatively blank slate archetype, at least as she is expressed through dialogue. The world around her is riddled with flavor text that delivers plenty of background that does give her depth, but through dialogue she just comes off as somewhat flat. Not a huge complaint, especially given the other characters around her, all interesting in their own ways.

The dialogue itself is way more tame, especially in terms of profanity, than Homestuck was. But seeing as this is an adventure game and not a novel of a webcomic, it works out. I found more than enough moments of intrigue, and it was charming and cute the whole way through.

The puzzles were all pretty easy, especially toward the beginning. So it doesn't seem to have a leg up on most adventure games I've played as a kid. No walkthroughs required, and there's only one ending. Take that as you will. Older adventure game fans might find this a fault, Homestuck fans probably will not.

The soundtrack

Is

AMAZING.

I would definitely have to say, even if you're not familiar with Homestuck and are interested in a character and story driven adventure game, go for it! Either way, I loved this and I can't wait for the second episode, hopefully a bit longer, and I'm super proud of Andrew Hussie for managing to crank this out through all of the turmoil!

38176705.review:
I highly recommend this game, even if you have no clue what Homestuck is. The game has a wonderful artstlye, delightful music, and a charming story and characters. The first Act is about 3 hours long (more if you spend time exploring the enviroment and finding the secret achievements), and if the comic is anything to go by, the following Acts will be even better and longer. If you're a fan of Homestuck, you'll be a fan of Hiveswap!

PROS
- Catchy and beautiful music
- Silly, fun puzzles
- Gorgeous art style
- Easy to follow story (for now, anyway...)
- Witty humor and clever references scattered about
- Clever and unique "combat" system (I'm hesitant to call it a combat system, as I'm unsure if it's even possible to lose the battles)

CONS
- The puzzles were a bit easy, and didn't pose that much of a challenge (though this may change in later acts!)
- Even though the story can be followed if you're not a Homestuck fan, those who haven't read the comic may find a lot of story elements/references go over their head

Overall I HIGHLY recommend this to anyone who loves puzzle/adventure games!

I was dissapointed however in how quickly the game could be played.  It only took me a few hours.  I hope to get a lot more out of a game I play 14 dollars for.  The first half of the game is really fun and interesting, but the second half of the game not nearly so much, which is counter-intuitive considering the second half takes place on an alien planet.  The second half was actually kind of boring.
The dialogue is exposition heavy and leaves a lot to be desired in my opinion.

Long time PCA fan here.

I wondered if I got some sort of "bad ending" since the game only lasted about 4hrs. Sadly, that was it. Achievements be damned, this game was SHORT; Seriously, back in 1994, this would've been on a demo disc distributed with a magazine.

I mean, I had an inventory full of neat stuff, the story just progressed to another climax, and then *POOF* --- roll credits, thanks for playing, enjoy your cliffhanger!

That being said, this game is super well-done. Clean, interesting, and fun artwork EVERYWHERE, superb animation, fantastic soundtrack, engaging story, and the game leads you to doing things wilingly (it's super easy). I hope this game makes the devs enough $$$$ so that future Acts actually get produced (a very real and common problem with episodic games!) because this is a fantastic concept that was excellently well-done and executed!

I recommend this game because I want to see another, and maybe even a finale!

37608076.review:
I want to make this very clear: before the game came out, I read as much as I could on Homestuck, and since it was on my bucket list, anyways, I thought that I might as well be prepared. And I'll say it definitely helped me with a few of Hussie's references to Homestuck, but that aside? You don't need to read Homestuck in order to love this game.

The characters, the settings, the creativity in designs all meshed together beautifully. To the point where I'm very glad that they went to a hand-drawn style over CGI. It definitely helped to give the characters more life and expressiveness. It was one of few games that I actually wanted to sit through and play whenever I have spare time (and I have a very hectic schedule, so..make of that what you will). Not to mention the writing for nearly every bit of dialogue for this game is absolutely top-notch. I almost never found repeats in combinations, and it led to some of the stupidest, yet funniest, scenes in the entire game.

So, all that said? Good luck, Andrew Hussie and What Pumpkin Games, on Act 2.

(Just know that I'm kicking myself for not knowing or supporting your Kickstarter all those years ago.)

37221903.review:
This game was pleasant to play and had under-tones that most players wouldn't understand.

It took me only 2.4 hours to finish the game while clicking on every interactable thing (not including using things from my inventory which give humurous quirks.)

Most players wouldn't recommend this game because it was a 'demo' length and isn't a fully fleshed out game.

The entire point is that it's represented as an old-timey, point-and-click game with details in everything you click. If you are only playing it so you can just get done with it then you aren't doing it correctly.

There are mini-details that flesh out the story and give more depth showing each characters likes, dislikes, and their story, but you can only learn about them if you REALLY, and I mean REALLY play the game.

Over-all, I would give the game a 8/10, myself. It's not perfect, but it's great!

The soundtrack is amazing, the visuals are great and I wouldn't prefer any other art-style, and the mechanics are so it's an easy game made to tell a story.

Some would call it a disguised visual novel, but, even without reading Homestuck, you can tell it's all about the adventure. And everything you do has a purpose. Every puzzle makes the story connect and fill in the plot holes.

37214477.review:
I bought this game almost entirely because of the art style and the early praise it received on many of the gaming sites I frequent. 

And a lot of what originally drew me to the game are also the most solid parts. The environments are well rendered and interesting, the characters are generally likable. And the story, overall, has promise, though it's hard to tell from just the first episode.

But for something that comes out of a love of classic adventure gaming, it seems like their familiarity with conventions stops somewhere in the late 80's. A lot of the quality of life improvements that became standard in most games in the genre are absent in this game. The issue with having cluttered and busy art in a game is that you have the give the player some means of parsing useful objects from decoration. Some do this with a hot key, some do this by coloring useful objects differently, and some choose simply to keep their environments more spartan. Hiveswap does none of these things, and forces the player into the old school habit of hovering the cursor over every inch of the screen to find what's useful. This isn't helped by the fact that sometimes really dull items that look like background are often critical to solving puzzles.

There's also, at times, an exhausting amount of writing in this game. The creators are clearly in love with their own words, which is a pretty common problem in indie and narrative games at this point. Video game creators have now reached the point where they should heed the old Strunk and White advice and use fewer words. If there's a way to have the player engage with the content rather than reading, go with engagement.

Having said all that, I'll still probably check out episode 2, but there's a lot here that made things needlessly frustrating.

Für jemanden, der Homestuck liebt, ist das Spiel eine überquillende Fundgrube an Eastereggs.
Jedoch ist es auch möglich ohne Vorkenntnisse zu spielen. Manche Sachen sind dann eventuell etwas verwirrend, werden aber gut eingebunden und wahrscheinlich auch teilweise in den kommenden Kapiteln erklärt.

[h1]Die Grafik[/h1]
Sehr liebevoll handgezeichnet und ich bin überaus froh, dass von der ersten Idee (3D Charaktere) abgesehen wurde.
Die Räume sind zugekleistert mit Items, von denen die meisten auch noch interagierbar sind.
Jeder Char hat seine eigene Textfarbe und Trolle ihre eigene Art zu schreiben (wie in Homestuck)

[h1]Mechanik[/h1]
Ein Point & Click, ganz klassisch. Man nimmt ein Haufen Sachen mit, manche gehen schnell wieder flöten, andere wiederum verweilen (noch sinnloserweise) im Inventar. Man kann alles mit allem benutzen und bekommt gerne einen schnippischen Kommentar dazu.
Bei der ersten Betrachtung des Inventars hatte ich allerdings Angst, dass die Spieler den Launen eines seltsam funktionierenden Sylladex ausgesetzt würden. Jedoch ist jedes Item jederzeit einsetzbar und sprengt nicht plötzlich in die Stratosphäre :)
Es ist möglich zwischen den Charakteren zu wechseln, jedoch ist dies nur wirklich notwendig, wenn es gerade wirklich einen Sinn ergibt.

36936138.review:
Lets get this straight, i'm a Homestuck fan and many who bought this game are too. This is my first review so go easy on me. As a fan Hiveswap exceeded all my expectations, but for the sake of the review i'm putting all my Homestuck love aside. 

The story: On its own the story is funny and interesting, it gives you a sense of wonder in all its jokes and dialogue. The first half of the game is very captivating in the interactions with the environment ranging from Bubsy posters to monsters chasing you around the house. It really makes you feel like there's more to this world that we think. The second half the protagonist is swapped to another planet where you get to take control of (spoilers) Xefros the troll. During this time you really get to know and understand the "universe" Andrew Hussie has in store for us, you get to see its problems and its MiRaClEs. It shows us just how different but not different the "trolls" really are. Too bad it just builds us up to the real story that'll come out in the next acts. 

The characters: The game starts us off with the siblings Joey Claire and Jude Harley taking control of Joey most of the time. In the first area of the game you get to learn about Joey and her point of view of environment. Each dialogue inteaction is from Joey's mind on the subject like how she wants to be a veterinarian to oppose her negective father. Have you ever done something as a counter to someone close. Jude likes to make conspiracy theories, do you like finding out answers to something or predicting the answer. Xefros is a chill dude who likes sports and music but is constanty terrorized by his red blood color which basicly makes you low class. Do you like sports but are discouraged by something you can't contol, these characters are relatable in a way good way. It immerses deeper into why we love video games and entertainment in general to begin with. It lets us feel like we can do things that are impossible.

The gameplay: I personally don't like to read books but hiveswap does in a way that makes me clicking for more. There are SO SO many hilarious jokes that it doesn't feel that taxing to be reading multiple lines. Combined with the great characters the jokes add to the level of interest within the dialogue. All of the places you explore are well drawn and cartoony and it feels like Homestuck at its core, but still different enough for somebody who's never seen Homestuck to enjoy it just as much as the next guy. On the puzzle side it's a little meak but fun nonetheless, it's definitely not as hard as other point and click adventure games. It is a little heavy on the reading side, for example there's a part where you read dialogue from a pad, it becomes slow at times thinking I just want to skip this to get to the rest of the game. The Characters and jokes really save it when it comes to this, anyone who fully reads all the dialogue will enjoy the game more, making you want to find more. That is for me at least.

MiRaClEs: This is what made Homestuck so popular in the first place. Relatable characters, funny dialogue, and exciting lore. Have you ever wished you could play sburb, or fight monsters, or save a princess. Thats what it means to really play Hive swap, it has a nice balance of relatability and fantasy. So if you like games but LOVE Homestuck I absolutely recommend this game.

- Anyway sorry if there's some grammer mistakes or I mispell something, it's my first time trying this but if you read this far THANK YOU go read Homestuck and buy Hiveswap (HeHe). <3

Rather than having story elements that might depend on knowledge of Homestuck, it just gives subtle nods, and not-so-subtle nods to the existing lore. 36530159.review:
edit: this review's a little rough around the edges, mainly because i wrote it when i was stone cold exhausted at 4:00 am. let me just cut the bullshit and get to the point this review makes that most others don't: late into the game, a lot of things in the environment seem to be despondent to use with most items. this may have been an issue exclusive to me somehow or it may have been changed since i finished my first playthrough, but it barely puts a damper on the experience, if at all. all the points that the other reviews have made are still completely valid, and this is a great game that you should buy nonetheless.

With Homestuck being the huge deal that it is, you can imagine that Andrew Hussie would see to it that the highly anticipated video game tie-in would be nothing short of exceptional. And by Jegus, after five long years of waiting and wondering, What Pumpkin finally delivered. With time constraints no longer being an issue due to not having to rush production or risk keeping eager readers waiting, almost every aspect of Hiveswap: Act 1 has been lovingly polished to a fine point, and it shows. The writing is hilarious and filled with references for fans of Homestuck to ravish in, the art manages to establish a beautiful, hand-drawn style that builds upon the classic look of MSPA perfectly, the soundtrack is composed by the two incredible musicians James Roach and Toby Fox -- the latter of whom is responsible for the infamously popular game Undertale and its own soundtrack, as well as being a highly respected member of the Homestuck music team for much of the comic's run, and while the gameplay isn't much to write home about, it does go above and beyond what is usually expected of a point-and-click adventure game by having almost (we'll get to that) every item available in the game usable on any object encountered by the player and not containing any of those overly-obtuse bullshit puzzles that point-and-click games seem to love so much. I managed to stump myself on what to do next at a few moments in the game, but that was mainly due to the fact that I either wasn't paying enough attention, I was overlooking something obvious, or am just incredibly shitty at solving puzzles. If you manage to get similarly stumped, fear not, because there is an incredibly helpful spoiler-free guide available among the community guides at the moment that should be able to help you with whatever problems you may run into, but I'd recommend that you only do this if absolutely necessary. My only remote gripe about the game is that late into it, a lot of the items seem to not render any output when used with most things, which was very disappointing to me as someone who spent at least an hour or two in Joey's bedroom alone. This issue could have been addressed since I last played it, but I highly doubt it, and it's really more of a nitpick than anything else. Outside of that, the game is absolutely and undilutedly brilliant and I'd highly recommend it to any fan of adventure games and/or Homestuck.

36522986.review:
I really enjoyed this game.  The only criticism/ concern I would have is it's length.  It's not a long game at all:  a couple of hours if you know what you're doing and hurry through, a bit longer if you explore and look around a lot.  I do hope the other acts and the connected game, Hauntswitch, are longer.  Simply because if each comes in around 2 hours, then you have 2 games of 4 acts each = 16 hours.  $8 x 8 = $64.  So you're coming in at AAA game pricing for a pretty short, indie game.  I'd be alright with it if they drop the price on each or make them all longer though.

That said, I loved the game.  The graphics are beautifully done, all hand drawn, I believe.  The music is very good as well.  The story is engaging and the characters are interesting.  The gameplay is fun, and it's wonderful that wrong choices give you creative answers, not the same old, "You can't do that!" over and over.

I do strongly recommend this game, especially if you like the old style point and click adventures, just maybe at a discount or sale.

36447891.review:
So, you have (most likley) seen allot of reviews where people mention how big of a Homestuck fan they are.
Well, when I played Hiveswap I had no clue what Homestuck was. But you don't need to know what it is to enjoy this game as it is only loosely connected and has no impact on the plot. But I enjoyed this game so much that I went out of my way to read it (It's apparently a webcomic) and I love it. Now that that's out of the way, we can start this review. (Well, I start this review)

                                                                                 [h1]Gameplay [/h1]
There isn't much gameplay here because it is a point and click adventure game. But, I have to say, it does have more than I expected. When you use an item from your inventory on a interactable it gives you a unique and sometimes humorous text. It makes a second playthrough worth it and it's way better (and less annoying) than the typical "I can't do that!" text that we all know and hate. 
Hiveswap also has something called "strifes". Strifes are a form of combat. But they are really puzzles referencing/parodying Turn-Based combat. You can't fail during these "strifes" but, if you have read any other review, you have probably heard that you can't die either in this game. Which is false because you can die, but it's more of an easter egg.

                                                                                 [h1]The Writing [/h1]
The writing is amazing! I instantly fell in love with the characters and the story. The jokes are well placed and humorous and I found myself laughing a couple of times. You get to know the characters through their thoughts and dialogue. 
The story is great and I found myself deeply invested in it and the characters. I truly cannot wait to see what happens next in ACT 2.

                                                                                 [h1] The Music [/h1]
If you have read any other review then you most likely already know how good the music is. I definitely punished myself for not buying the Soundtrack Edition. The music doesn't distract you from the game but it isn't a boring repetitive tune either. It's just simply amazing.

                                                                                 [h1]The Visuals [/h1]
The visuals in this game are beautiful. There is definitely some background material in this game.
I also really liked the character designs. I haven't seen a single character yet that looks boring or unimaginative.
I really liked the monster designs aswell. They definitely look interesting and monstrous. Maybe I just a have a soft spot for eyeless reptilian monsters.

                                                                                 [h1]Length [/h1]
Now, you have probably heard that this game is short. Which is sort of true. It really depends on how you play the game. If you decide to play this game by just solving the puzzles and reading the dialogue then completing the game will take you around 2 to 3 hours. If you decide to also click on every interactable to see the thoughts of the character on it, then it will take you around 7 to 8 hours to complete the game. If you decide to also use every item in your inventory on every interactable then completing the game will take you around a week. I played the game by solving the puzzles, reading the dialogue and clicking on every interactable. It took me almost 8 hours to complete the game this way and I am happy that I played it like this. I got to know allot more details about story and even more about the characters. It made me like them even more. I find playing the game like this personally the best way to play it. It will give you more insight on the story and characters but you also won't be spending hours in one room wiping your inventory on everything, thus distracting you from the story. In my second playthrough I did use my inventory on everything (R.I.P Byers) and even though I got to see more jokes and story details, it was also distracting me from the story. 

                                                                                 [h1]Final Verdict [/h1]
All in all, this game is amazing and I highly recommend it, even to people that aren't all that interested in point and click games (like myself). I love the characters, the story, the visuals, the music, I love all of it. I give this game a: [b]8/10.
[/b]
Now don't put the game on a incredibly high pedestal. As it can only ruin the experience.

5/10= A decent game but it needs improvement

9/10= A fantastic game
10/10= Perfection)

36176066.review:
[b][u]If you like Homestuck, but have never played a point and click adventure[/u][/b]
[list]
 [*] Can be frustrating if you get stuck so don't worry about using a spoiler free guide, but use it as a last resort.  Consider the game as just an interactive story medium that is 100 times more rewarding than a visual novel (so clicking everything and trying everything you can think of as more flavour is encouraged).  
 [*] The style is exceptionally well done for Homestuck.  The music is excellent so far, but as this is just Act 1, there isn't an epic score like 'Ascend/Descend'.
 [*] To some people £5 will feel like alot of money for such as short game, but they really have put alot of effort into this.  No game in history can comepare to the Homestuck webcomic epic, and never will.  
 [*] The mechanics, aesthetics, even 'Strife' mode is incredibly faithful and fun.  
[/list]

[b][u]If you like point and click games, but have never read Homestuck[/u][/b]
[list]
 [*] Short game, but highly recommended (Is £5 - Which after playing it feels fair)
 [*] The effort in aesthetic is top notch, but the 'style' is unique in gaming.  Be open minded it'll be lots of fun.
 [*] Do not expect this to be in like a Telltale game - by which I mean, don't expect it to be completed within in a year with 5 episodes and bundled for cheap within 6 months - Homestuck's precedent is that it could become an ongoing and epic story that can spiral beyond all expectation.
 [*] 'Strife' mode looks like a RPG battle, but it is actually a non-repetetive novel puzzle element instead! Don't let it put you off!
[/list]

[b][u]If you like point and click games and Homestuck[/u]
[list]
 [*] You should probably already own this game.[/b]

36132608.review:
Now boy, if you thinking you're buying a game that had 5 or so years spent in it's making, think again. Keep noted that it's development took a hella of a long time due to an ENTIRE redo of the project (more details somewhere online, no doubt). What you're looking at the store page of is the Hiveswap that was worked on after it got smoothed out. I'm making sure this is clarified, because I'm quite sure there are some here under the mistake that this is a long awaited big content title. But with that nonsense out the way, let me tell you about Hiveswap!

Read Homestuck?:  While many will say otherwise, I say ReAd Homestuck before playing Hiveswap (or watch the awesome dubs). Yes, it's not mandatory, but trust me. You will most certainly miss the importance of countless direct plot points such as [spoiler]scratch's appearance, mention of the condesce, comical reference to the Signless's death, possible involvement of the midnight crew, the fact that Joey's mom has a frickin juju, knowing why the household is full of blue ladies and odd animals, what a lusus is (they don't fully explain it), the untold fact about what grubs are,[/spoiler] and many many other points only a Homestuck reader will understand. Just do yourself a favor and try reading the story this is adding onto, and if you do play Hiveswap blind, PLEASE keep your theories silent until you read Homestuck. It's improtant to the game's lore in so many ways already. So overall, playable and understandable enough for any, but intended for those that read. Also we know Hussie is a troll, and will use that specific wording "Homestuck hasn't even been made yet!" for a plot twist twistier than the windy thing.

Story: Hiveswap starts out perfectly. We are beautifully gifted with a  taste of the art from the main menu and introduction. You probably already know this part, but Jude n' Joey get attacked by monsters, and flee to their little hideaways to get a grip on the situation. It's a fast introduction that raises enough questions to get the train rolling! Our two main character siblings Joey and Jude make no hesitation to engage in conversation and show off the qualities of their character and writing the moment we are interested to learn. I'll let you learn more about them when you play, but have my word they put no shame on the Homestuck name. Oh, and given the E rating, you will here a lot less cursing in this story, but the humor is dark enough to feel at home. I don't have any harsh feelings towards this development, as it goes with the aesthetic theme pretty well. Oh yeah, and obviously our lovely narration text is detailed and filling our eyes with pixel letters as ever. Every object and interaction have endless possible text to read. What's better is it's mostly all optional to try, letting the player choose just how much detail they get to read. I'll lastly say in regards to the story that is pretty short, even for an Act. But seeing as they also plan the Hauntswitch series, I think there will still be lots to see in the future.

Art: Beautiful! ..But not perfect. Every single background is hand drawn fantasicly, and the classy approach definetly shows. Homestuck's original style feels well left behind aside from the obviously inspired character designs, but the new background approach is very welcomed. My only complaints being that the combat animations don't feel all that inspiring, but being as this is a point and click adventure game, that shouldn't matter (but there is a reason why it's not usually attempted in the genre). The bigger problem being that some room areas feel a little too cramped, and you can't always tell what you're looking at (Might just be me with the weak eyes here, but I don't know). This is difficult when the game doesn't have a scan feature, but I can't say it messed up my game progession. Also a quick seizure warning as there are flashy light moments.

Music: It's Toby Fox hun', what more to say?  Though I don't feel as in love as I did with Undertale's, it's still great and atmospheric. The battle themes have to be where the talent mostly shines, to no surprise. Honestly... I wish I had more to say here. Just try to avoid getting stuck anywhere, as some themes can last a while through the story and get drilled into your head until you progress.

Gameplay Technicalities: It's what you expect of a point and click boy! While I have heard of issues with framrate, none of that really interupted my experience... Honestly it's a very nit picky complaint to make on a game that doesn't require intense movement. And all the glitches I experienced on launch day have since been fixed, you may still find some, as well as some crazy exploits if you search. It also managed to play on my steam link pretty well, which is rare as hell.

Gameplay Features: You have an inventory, stuff goes in, there's endless possible texts. Okay, so what isn't dead obvious or not talked about yet? I guess the progession rate. Hiveswap is one of those games where talking means you did something right. Though the ammount of talking can be quite intense for even the smallest of progress, this is something all us readers are already used to, actually it's far more mild here than in Homestuck standards. It is best to get lost a few times just to explore and see everything, and with everything you are tasked to do between the dialogues, I'd say it all fits well enough. Plenty of easter eggs and optional interactions too, as an essential to any good point and click. The only two lacking points I can think of are the difficulty and the "battles". Hiveswap's description may say it goes for logical and non-dreamy solutions, but it gets a bit too logical... In the sense that any sense of logic can follow the directions it hints at. But I'm not saying it's all the time, as I had a decent ammount of head scratching moments. It just didn't feel as satisfying to solve a majority of the puzzles when the answers were so obvious. So about them battles? Well, while I do appreciate that the battles change the pace of scenes and throw in new ways of thinking for the player to react to, they don't translate to the genre well. Enemies don't really act monstourous, and kinda just stand around until you throw the right random item at them. The game over screen is considered a secret, if that says anything. 

Price and recommendation:  A Daedalic title is 30$ off of a sale, and Hiveswap will be 32$ if it continues the 8$ tag ::::) I feel that Hiveswap would be either long as or longer than a Daedalic by then, so can't say the price ain't proper. But I do hope upon finishing it they do a discounted complete bundle by maybe 10% or so if you buy it whole. So is Act 1 worth it now? Yes if you're a big Homestuck fan. If you're a fan but are unsure, I won't argue waiting for more acts to be released. If you aren't a Homestuck fan, wait for a sale because it may be a dissapointing buy, especially if future acts raise the knowledge requirement. And if none of these apply to you but wanna see the story anyway, watch a playthrough!

I can't wait to see the rest of this story!

I sat down to play the game, and by the time i closed it again i had already finished the whole act. Was it good though? Heckin yeah it was. 35516011.review:
Before you read, if you think you should buy this, do yourself a favor and at least wait for a sale. Not worth $8 dollars in its current state.

I absolutely, positively cannot recommend this game to anyone. For the time it took from the ending of the kickstarter and the poorly aged jokes that Hussie made about how much money he earned in total(while absolutely ruining the chance to get any of the stolen money back), Hiveswap is already looking like a worse version of Broken Age, with the beginning starting out decent, then having to buy each "chapter"(aka an actual part of the game that should already exist) with nearly immediate diminished returns. Two things that I can talk positively about the game is that it... looks pretty, and appropriately sets the scenes according to the time period(WOW, REMEMBER POGS AND LITEBRITES? WE'RE SO QUIRKY).
That's it. 
Hiveswap is still showing Hussie's absolute mastery of color coordination(which I always deeply appreciated from his Problem Sleuth days), so while what I said was sincere, nearly every single other aspect of the game is severely lacking. Puzzles, if they can even be called that, depend on you having two eyes and a mouse. There is literally nothing challenging in the game itself, even for a point and click: how do you get a key? Don't worry, every single step is described in excrusciating detail, or you have to click on a teddy bear on a whim. 

For combat, I'm not even sure how to critique it: The girl won't use guns because it would make combat last one t-sorry, because she doesn't like guns. You can tapdance, you can pirouette, you can flash a light, but it takes you out of having any sort of fun with it when 'options' turn into 'one solution you have infinite time/turns to choose accordingly'.

Characters are absurdly flat, with gems such as "I hate my dad but I'm the main character so I'm also nice" and "I BUILT MY TINFOIL HAT OUT OF CHILDHOOD DREAMS AND FOX NETWORK SATELLITE DISHES", as well as "Tavros, but worse". As having read all of Homestuck, I could not in my wildest dreams expect anything better than what we have now for the characters, but I'd be willing to change my opinion on this as the different chapters come out; looking in from a lets play, as it stands right now.

$8 after two million and waiting months for chapters after years from the kickstarter campaign disguists me, but I'm only holding so much vitriol for this and writing a review longer than I ever would want to read because I KNOW Hussie and the What Pumpkin staff at large can do so much better.
