The writing style is amusing, coming across in the narration boxes when you interact with things.  For example using the pigeon on stuff he's clearly not compatible with!

Dialogue is done solely through a walkie-talkie and an online IM.  No voice-acting, only text.

I...THINK it does a decent enough job explaining itself, so I don't THINK you need to be familiar with the Homestuck webcomic to play it.

35481453.review:
Hiveswap is what it says it is. A tribute to 90's era point-and-click games. What it has an abundance of is fantastic music, made by Toby Fox (The creator of Undertale), a great story (One that you don't need to watch HomeStuck to gain interest in). As a standalone story, it shines through with moments of hilarity, and unlike what it says in the description, som frustration. May not come in the form of pixel hunting, but make sure you try everything. EVERYTHING. Not kidding either, it'll save you some time, instead of spending an hour pixel hunting only to realize it was something so obvious. Banging your head into a wall for ten minutes is a quick way to a migraine, one I wouldn't recommend. Anyways, back to the review. If you have some experience in HomeStuck, then you will have some nice little eggs left from Easter to enjoy. My Ratings:

Music: 9/10. There are a few tracks i'm not a huge fan of, but I love most of the music in this game.
Story: 9/10. I will not spoil anything about the story. But, I can say wholeheatedly that prior experience with HomeStuck is not required to play this game. Two seperate, although connected, stories.
Replayability: 6/10. I haven't replayed it, but on my one playthrough, I only got half of the achievements that are present. Will be fun for Achievement Hunters to go through. 


I simply hope that Act 2 will be out within a year, but that is a pipe dream. I'm not a very patient person, but when the product is of a quality like this, I will wait. Not forever, but I will. Unlike most of the people who have boughten this game, I hadn't followed it religiously, and I didn't even know it had come out. I stumbled across it by accident, and I haven't been disappointed yet.  I haven't even finished HomeStuck yet, hell, I'm not even a third of the way through it. For $8, It is worth it.

[h1] ===============LET ME TELL YOU ABOUT HOMESTUCK==================[/h1]

[b]Homestuck[/b]是由美国漫画家Andrew Hussie制作并连载于MS Paint Adventures(小画家冒险故事)网站上的含有文字、图片、音乐、动画、游戏等等的[b]网络漫画[/b] 。官方对其之介绍是“一个男孩跟他的朋友们一起玩游戏的故事。”因着它可观的长度和复杂的情节而受瞩目。【删改自百科百度】
[b]Hiveswap[/b]是在原作基础上的衍生游戏，故事设定发生在与原作同一世界观下，原作故事开始之前。作者说游戏并非是单纯的粉丝向，所以不用太担心未深入了解过原作是否会干扰游戏的剧情进行。当然如果阅读过原作的话会获得更充实的游戏体验。
[url=mspaintadventures.com] HOMESTUCK【原作网址】[/url]
[url=zhhomestuck.blogspot.com] 【繁体汉化网址（需翻/墙）】[/url]
[url=komica.dbfoxtw.me/hstwproject] 【前两章汉化的网址（无需翻/墙）】[/url]
HOMESTUCK贴吧交流群qq:272045801
HIVESWAP游戏交流群qq:106051960

[h1]===============以下是游戏评测==============================[/h1]

+精致的画面场景，精美又不失原作精髓，乍一看很乱，实则信息量巨大,小物件上多是为了角色塑造[spoiler]和梗[/spoiler]服务.
+音乐不用多夸啦，建议与ost一起购买。
+角色非常可爱www，CG动画都很良心，辛苦画师们了。
+对白，描述都非常用心，很多非常小的细节和毫不相干的物品间都有大段大段的旁白，【[strike] 让人觉得作者到底是有多闲。
[/strike] ，[spoiler]比如说万能的鸽子[/spoiler]。
+成吨的梗，很多能令粉丝会心一笑的原作梗【和乱七八糟作者的私货，
+剧情上ACT1看起来还只是在引入，一点一点深入，[spoiler]结尾激动地一身鸡皮疙瘩[/spoiler]。但是非常让人期待后续展开！鉴于原作也是前期慢热后期超展开停不下来，相信后续剧情应该不会令人失望。


-游戏时长短！！不够玩！翻着字典玩还卡了几次关一周目下来也才四个小时。[spoiler]但如果HAUNTSWITCH也是四个ACT的话那就是4*4*2=32个小时了呀[/spoiler]
-虽然说是说不是单纯的粉丝向，但就目前来看对没看过原作的玩家还是有点不大友好。原作里非常复杂又迷人的世界观放在游戏对话里，很多东西目前在ACT1里还没解释清楚，如果对原作不熟的话多少会看得一脸雾水。
-有些谜题感觉就起来没啥成就感，明明在对话、动画上都费了很大功夫，谜题的设计上反而不大对得起其他方面。


总体下来还是很棒的！！从原作粉丝的角度来说还是非常满意的！单纯从游戏的角度上也瑕不掩瑜。即使多次跳票有过不安，成品出来还是远超预期的。期待ACT2！！！[strike]以及期待这次不用等那么久[/strike]

【虽然就HOMESTUCK在国内的人气而言不大可能有汉化，英语废啃起来痛并快乐着。
还是非常希望有更多人能了解HOMESTUCK这部优秀的作品的，也希望HIVESWAP能吸引更多人入坑。
请不要犹豫，去补原作和来玩游戏吧！！！

35436763.review: If you are a fan of Homestuck and the games than inspired it and its aesthetic, you will love Hiveswap. While it may only be Act I, Hiveswap is looking fantastic so far!

35435732.review:
Hiveswap Act 1. - A spoiler free Review-

A point and click adventure, just as MSPA's Homestuck was intended to be or at least simulate. But unlike homestuck, this takes place outside the SBURB game in the main homestuck lore, but also takes place in the same universe in the beta timeline but about 20-25 years into the past, the 90's.

Now let's talk about the game's illustration and mechanics.
The artstyle is really charming and refreshing, incredible detail in the background illustration left and right, top to bottom. The music fits the mood perfectly, hell one part reminded me of the typical 90's rugrats music if you remember what WOOONK WOOONK instrument I'm talking about. The game's movement, interaction and flow is basicly....DURRrrr, point and click, with options that pop up on objects or items of interest. So far it needs to be polished for the system itself feels a bit clunky at times, buggy i might say. You progress by using items you find along your journey, sometimes even combining said items to make a puzzle or door work. Requires the minimal use of a braaaaaain.

Story-wise I'm really digging the direction this game is headed. There is an obsessive amount of dialog if you use the pigeon on pretty much everything that is clickable in the background illustration, and incredible amount of story dialog as you progress the game. You can skip dialog, but some dialog is mandatory to progress and unskippable. The game is really short but will feel complete once the other acts are done.

Would i recommend this game?
Yes, but Only if you're into point and click adventures. Like, seriously. You could be a huge homestuck fan, but if you dislike Point and click games you wouldn't like this game.

Yes if you don't mind a short game. Act 1 is about an hour the first playthrough and will leave you wanting for more.

Yes if your computer isn't a toaster. I had a fair-share of discovered bugs in-game, but others with inferior computers downright have games that crash upon startup or have broken cut-scenes. Please purchase this game if you are absolutely sure you can run it.

Would i recommend this game to people who just want to explore without someone telling you what to do?
Maybe. Personally i found Joey's brother Jude a chatterbox, and i mean, a big chatterbox, half the times i didn't even read what he had to say since he kept draggin on and on. Thankfully however the reason i say MAYBE is because there IS an option to just fast forward the dialog or completely ignore his walkie talkie calls. Some calls are mandatory, but you can fast foward through them.

Is this game easy?
It requires thinking and problem solving. But you can beat the entire game without reading any other characters dialog, The narrator or self dialog tells you what you think or think you shouldn't do as you interact with random objects in the world, which is a direct hint. This game does require minimal use of a brain, please check the status of your brain or borrow or steal a new one if needed and preserve the tissue in formalin in a container before use.

Overall i do recommend this game even if you never read homestuck, you don't need to read homestuck at all to dive into hiveswap. You might spend about an hour or two trying to beat the game the first time, especially if you read every single dialog. Second playthrough once you know exactly what to do, you can beat the game in about 10 minutes or less.

What can be done to improve the game if you're WhatPumpkin dev and you're reading this?
Well iron out those bugs and for the sake of the people who can't run this game, try to make this game more compatible. Advertise the game once all the Act's are out, some people who are homestuck fans are unaware this game is even out to this day. I'm sorry but this game was poorly advertised, everything including the greenlight was pretty much community spread word2word.

What can i suggest for you, the person who's reading this that might purchase the game, to do to have an ultimate experience with this game?
If you have the patience made out of iron. I would recommend you just wait until all the ACT's are released, that way you can experience a clean flow of uninterupted content, and possible performance bugs fixed. Having a cliff hanger and waiting for months for a new act is a real drag unless you're chill and ok with it. But if you're new to Homestuck in general or a veteran with patience, wait until all the acts are released. And if you're new to Homestuck, you can pass the time waiting for the other ACT's by reading Homestuck : )

Well that's that, review is done.
I'm looking forward to the other ACTs, as well as the rumored but somewhat unofficially confirmed "Hauntswitch" which is an additional game that coincides with Hiveswap. Consider Hauntswitch as "SIDE-B" or Player 2, it takes place in the shoes of the character that swaps in your place on earth.

Эх, Хайвсвэп... Ну что сказать. Сказать можно то, что игра НАКОНЕЦ выходит из производственного лимбо. Она конечно вышла 15 сентября, но только 1 октября я мог его попробовать на вкус... эхх. Разработка была у него долгой, и таинственной. Как ХЛ3, только менее мистически, и в антураже Хоумстака. Сколько бы там не спойлерили, но одно было ясно... Все было трудно. Но хей, ХС закончился, и у Хасси было полно времени чтобы доделать этот спинофф, получилось ли у него, и стоит ли идти на програмиста, и получать 99999 фунтов в день, ну или хотябы на шахтера и получать 200 Беларусских рублей в год, ради игры в Хайпсвэп? Это мы сейчас и узнаем.
[h1] Суть [/h1]
Жила была девчонка Джой и ее странноватый братец. Но тут напали монстры, и разгромили все. А дальше... [spoiler] ДАЛЬШЕ ТО, ЧТО ДЖОЙ НАЧИНАЕТ ИЗБИВАТЬ МОНСТРЯКОВ ФОНАРИКОМ, НАХОДИТ СТРАННЫЙ КЛЮЧ, ПРОДОЛЖАЯ ИЗБИВАТЬ МОНСТРОВ, А ЭТО БЫЛ КЛЮЧ ОТ ПОРТАЛА К ДРУГИМ ИЗМЕРЕНИЯМ, И ОНА ПОПАДАЕТ НА ПЛАНЕТУ ГДЕ ЖИВЕТ РАСА ТРОЛЛЕЙ ПРИШЕЛЬЦЕВ, И НАЧИНАЕТ КОНТАКТИРОВАТЬ (Не в том смысле, грязные извращенцы) С ОДНИМ ИЗ ТРОЛЛЕЙ, И ОНИ ТИПО... НУ... КОРОЧЕ ОНА ЕГО СПАСАЕТ, И ОНИ УХОДЯТ В ЗАКАТ, А ТЕМ ВРЕМЕНЕМ ПРАВИТЕЛЬСТВО ОТ НЕФИГ ДЕЛАТЬ ФИГАЧИТ ГОРОД... КОНЕЕЕЕЦ ЖДИ 2 АКТ ЧЕРЕЗ 8987656 ЛЕТ ХАХАХА! [/spoiler]. Я же говорил что игра теперь в 2D? Так вот, переход был мудрым... и правильным чтоль, ну мне так кажется, все 3D который нам показывали не вписывается с атмосферой Хоумстака. И да, на счет атмосферы. Ну, тут все более лампово, хотябы родственники не слягут от инсульта, не знаю хорошо ли это то, что атмосфера игры отличается от комикса... ну... на вкус и цвет товарищи. Музыка тут тоже годная. Все же, Тоби во второй (Или в Третьий, если вы качали альбомы по ХС) раз доказал что он не просто левый музыкант и создатель скелета по которому в 2016 текла каждая девочка, а создатель кошерной годноты. Ну а про сюжет я еще не могу сказать, на данный момент он ламповый, но зная Хасси, он может все поменять к акту 2. Да, Хасси тот еще тролль, и Фанов троллит, и своих персов троллит, и себя троллит... Только пока такого еще я не замечал в игре... 
"хееей, некро, а минусы есть?"
Ну... таких особо минусов я не нашел, но один факт меня немного расстроил. И это продолжительность дети... Не то что бы это был уж глобальный минус, конечно это не как в Бэнди, но меня это немного расстроило... типо... хей игру фанаты ждут как триллион лет, и все ради 3-10 часов? Неее.. Ну и да, отстутсвие русского это не минус, далеко не минус... Подождите Русика.... если он не выйдет ко 2 акту. А еще я слышал о такой проблеме, что катсцены висли. Видимо я везучий, и у меня они не висли, либо это уже до меня пофиксили. Ну вот так вот.

[h1] Итог [/h1]
Достаточно годный Пойнт энд Клик, который старается угодить фанатом Домашнего Застрявания, и новеньких которые нифига не смыслят во всех этих квадрантах и троллях. Все же, когда Хасси получил основу, у него достаточно времени... он может и сделает АКТ 2... ИЛИ НАМ ПРИДЕТСЯ ЖДАТЬ ЕЩЕ 5 ЛЕТ!
8 Инопланетных порталов из 10 Троллей.

[b]Current grade:[/b] 8.5/10

Fun, effective and... too short sadly. it took no more than 2 hours to complete, but it was honestly worth it. I can't wait for the sequel though. I have no doubt it's gonna be as awesome!

For those not familiar with Homestuck, this is a spin-off that involves earth before Homestuck's plot and Alternia before Her Imperious Condescencion came back with her ship. There are no adults on Alternia, their casts are split by the colors of their blood. Easiest representation of those in homestuck had been by signs, such as red/rustbloods being aries and fuschia being pisces, the highest caste. 

There are many easter eggs for homestuck fans, but even if you aren't, you are probably gonna like it, because it can be played as alternative universe/timeline.

35262544.review:
Pros:

[b]For homestuck fans[/b]

Has the same style of writing, world rules-such as people leveling up or "strifing- and the trolls you love. It has fun (but new) characters.


[b]Graphically great[/b] 

the abstract simplicity of the characters/enemies and so on really stands out with the high detailed but bright backgrounds. Everything pops out at you and in terms of game play you don't feel like the world is meshed like you can get in other point and clicks. It's real eye candy. Almost every room is jamed with stuff, but clearly defined.

[b]Animation [/b] 

Following from the art, the animation is generally smooth and nice. The cute scenes don't feel like interruptions into the game and they don't come in for minor crap alot.

[b] Music [/b]

Music is good. Which is great, because you're going to be listening to it for an hour when you trying to find an item you need.

[b] Writing [/b]

The writing is good. The characters have instnatly distince personalities as soon as they speak and almost every item you can interact with have some sort of personal, and new, dialogue. Wich is a relief as many games resort to bland, recycled commentary.


-----------------------------------------------

The cons:

[b]Against Homestuck[/b]  If you weren't really a fan of homestuck to begin with, I doubt this will really flip your opinion. It's not exactly made to break away from it. It brings to the table what the audience ordered and you probably don't like the audience.

[b] Gameplay[/b]

Honestly, there are not a lot of puzzles in this. While you do have to overcome obstacles, chances are that most of them you already know the answer and will simply need to find the right item. However, in its defence. It dosen't have stupid, obscure, convulted solutions to a really obvious problem. Except for maybe one case which you will figure out in 5 seconds because it still makes sense.

Strifing is also a bit weird, it presents itself like a turn based battle-which is keeping with the theme of homestuck- but it's actually just a differently framed Puzzle. 

[b] Length [/b]

It's pretty short, honestly. Is it worth 6 bucks, I don't know. I would of liked a bit more to it for the costs. What in it is fun though and it got a few hours at least.


[b]Overall[/b]

Rating: Theme Park Tour.

You basically are on a ride in this game most of the time. Your input is still needed and it simulates a sense of urgency fairly well, there is never a case where SOMETHING isn't happening SOMEWHERE and it requires your controlled character to do something, with implied stakes being life or death. So, feel at ease that the game at least put weight on your actions even if you are bound by story to simply see the actions through.

The writing is nice, the animation is nice, the world is nice, the art is nice. It's a very casual, very fun roller coaster of a game, which, it being a point a click act 1, you probably expect.  

Is this ride worth the price of admission...well...if you want to kill some time with a story. Yes. 

if you're a homestuck fan: yes.

If your a massive fan of point and clicks: yes

or you're a very casual type of gamer who likes to explore but it keep it laid back: yeah.

If you're searching for intense puzzles, open ended choices an freedom, then no. At least not in this act.

35251263.review:
Hiveswap offers a beautiful world with fantastic and humorous characters and dialogue. Not so strong on the whole gameplay aspect, but it makes up for it in story. It's designed to be understandable by non-Homestuck fans too, and even they will most likely enjoy it.

The good:
- Art and music is fantastic
- Compelling dialogue/story
- Clever and humorous interactions
- Unique object interactions- every object has a unique interaction with every other object and everything in the background. That's a ridiculous amount of interactions.


The bad:
- Uninspiring puzzle design (they're not really puzzles, more like tasks. You find which object interacts with which thing to progress. Nothing really mind-challenging- many puzzles are more of a grind than they are difficult)
- Some video bugs for certain users, not sure if they've been patched.
- Cluttered-looking UI
- Way too many items at one time- few are ever removed from your inventory but are never needed again (did I really need to keep the dog treats for that long?)
- Under-utilised abilities

Overall, you can tell that the creators were primarily writers, music creators and artists over game and level designers (which makes sense, for a game based off a webcomic). It excels in the areas that Homestuck itself excels in, and falls flat on actual gameplay. If you enjoy story and humour, the game is fantastic. If you're looking for a game with high quality gameplay, though, it'd be best to look elsewhere.

35234241.review:
I say this not as a Homestuck fan, but a fan of Point and Click adventure games.
Despite it's unfortunately short length (Just over two hours), this was one of the best point and click adventure games I've ever played, bringing back memories of the original three Monkey Island games and Day of the Tentacle.
The interface reminds me a bit of Beneath a Steel Sky, having the items on top laid out in the way they are, though any reminders of that masterpiece are certainly appreciated. 
Aside from the feel the game gives off, being ever so reminiscent of the aforementioned games, the actual game itself is actually a bit simpler. The puzzles are all fairly simple, and the advertised 'homage to classic adventure games while lacking the frustration' is true, save for a single instance, with the second version of a certain minigame, where the undesired letters would spawn immediately in front of me and I wouldn't have the chance to react (I won't offer any context to that for sake of spoilers), though it still took me less than five minutes to do.
The humor doesn't rely at all on knowledge of the comic, though the style of humor is very similar, if a bit less wordy, removing one of the huge barriers of entry the comic has. 
I can see myself replaying it many times, just to see the stuff I missed, and even beyond that, just because it was a charming and fun experience.

All in all, it's a fantastic experience, and I'm glad I picked it up.

35217850.review: Hiveswap! The game we Homestuck readers have been waiting for since the 90s (or at least that's what it feels like). What can I say? It's utterly enjoyable. 10/10 would put birb in microwave again. In all seriousness, this is a short game. It felt, fittingly enough, like the first act in a longer game. If you focus on solving the puzzles, you can easily beat this in 2 to 4 hours, tops. But one quickly discovers that this isn't the kind of game where getting to the end is the main focus; instead, so much care and focus has been put into the journey that you can spend half a day combining every item you see and still find something to make you laugh. Strong but not overbearing connections to the source material? Check. Unique characters with fascinating quirks? Check. The greatest and bravest pigeon of all? ABSOLUTELY. I mean, DANG SON, those were some fine avians. OK, time to fax this pigeon somewhere else! This game is wonderfully humorous, and you can combine pretty much everything with pretty much everything else and there's a unique splash of text for 99.95% of those combinations. Most of those splashes of text are side-splittingly funny. If you want a good laugh and a relaxing trip down high-adventure lane, with great tunes thrown in to boot, this is absolutely the game for you. The puzzles are not challenging. The challenge is seeing how many stupid things you can do before being forced to continue through process of elimination.

35191768.review:
Hiveswap took all the things I liked about point and click games that have a linear storyline, and managed to keep that while dropping most of the things I dislike in such games. The only real con I'd say the game has is the fight scenes, but only because I was expecting a system that delivered semi-challenging fights wer you could lose. I suppose the puzzles could also be considered a con if you go into the game expecting challenging puzzles. Don't.

Basically, Hiveswap is a story told through an interactive experience where you get much more flexibility to choose how fast things go than in a movie or such, and can spend massive amounts of time looking into details in the setting. Or you can speedrun things to some degree. Basically, if you want an enjoyable story to go through, buy it. If you're looking for something with challenging puzzles or fights, Hiveswap probably isn't for you.

35173102.review:
The Homestuck game we all waited for is here! Except not.
I'll be the 100th person to admit that the more recent announcements for the game were not what I expected. I didn't even expect it to be for the PC, let alone have nothing to do with Sburb. But that didn't stop me from buying it the day it came out.
Initially, I was pretty skeptical. In the first 10 minutes of playing, I'd already spotted to in-game glitches and I wasn't impressed. My cynical mind could only think, "How many years had this been in the making? How much money did this earn again?" But it was whatever. I was here to support one of my favorite webcomics turned game with three of my favorite creators boasting a hand in it's production, and get in on those sweet, sweet references. Quality was the least of my concerns (but still a concern none the less). But after the latest update, most of those quality concerns were swept away and I enjoyed the story in it's entirety and let me tell you. I finished it today and it was more than I would have ever hoped. I'm in love all over again. The characters are so well made and while I don't love all of them, I do admit that it's not because they're poorly written. In fact, their flaws make them enheritly better fleshed out. The game is FUN, though more story-based, with little player interaction other than telling the character where to go and some amount of puzzle solving skills. As the description says, you don't NEED to have read Homestuck in order to get into the game. In fact, the actual Homestuck references that would go over an unknowing player's head are rather few and far between, but just enough to make a old or new fan go, "O SHOOT SON." 
My only REAL complaint is the length. I thought $7.99 was a steal for a brand new game, but after beating the entirety of it in two not overly lengthy sittings, I can honestly say it was about 8 bucks of content. Which is to say it was about the length of one graphic novel, which is accurate pricing. For a more frugal and savvy fan, they may consider waiting until all the Acts come out and buy them in bulk. But you won't find me putting myself through that; You can bet I'll be buying Act 2 on it's release date as well, and I feel like that says something on my opinion of this game as a whole. 

Tl;Dr: If you're thinking of checking it out, just do it bro. Make it happen. It's a good intro.

35160746.review:
I love it.  It has more than enough subtle homestuck references to keep please its fan (and raises quite a few questions about how it fits into the existing canon) but is certainly understandable without having read homestuck.  There are plenty of jokes and humorous observations to be found by examining the environment; homestuck fans will appreciate the familiar sense of humor, but the humor is not based upon homestuck-references, so new players should have no issue getting it.

For the most part, it's puzzles are able to be reasoned through (I only ran into trouble by doubting the bending strength of alien culinary utensils), and the variety of mini-games keep things interesting and promote the feeling that you're solving a variety of challenges.  Pieces of the characters' backstories are tucked away inside environmental descriptions, so if that's not your thing, don't worry: you don't have to know any escoteric knowledge from examining every object just to progress; it's there solely so that you can enjoy it if you want to.

I really appreciate the musical and visual techniques used to craft each scene, as each displays a well-crafted tone and feel.  The build and release of tension this game exhibits is masterful.  It enables you to empathize with the characters and truly makes you feel like you're a part of the action.

Overall, I thoroughly enjoywed HIVESWAP: Act 1.  I am so truly thankful to everyone who worked to create this game; your determination to stick with it despite numerous obstacles is no small feat.  I am thrilled with this game and cannot wait for the next installment!

35156365.review:
This game is priced perfectly, though I would have payed more. 
Whether or not you like Homestuck (the franchise that inspired this game), I would recommend this to anyone who loves oddball humour, 90's nostalgia (and consequently the self-aware humour of 90's nostalgia being kind of overplayed), gorgeous hand-animated visuals, and incredible attention to detail.
The characters are loveable and charming even if you so choose to play them antagonistically.
The game rewards you constantly for being creative or curious, instead of scolding you for not solving the puzzle like other games of it's kind. Nothing is perfect, and this game is no exception. It can't appeal to people who just aren't into it, but a pretty wide margin of people will be charmed if they take a chance and play.
My only complaints are that despite it's great replay value, it's still pretty short even with three playthroughs. 
Furthermore (and this is understandable), the fact that so many things are interactable with one-another, makes it more dissapointing than it would be when you find a combination that the developers didn't think of, and don't get a witty remark about it. 
This game is absolutely worth beating, I would posit that it's even worth trying to complete it 100% (Though, the final achievement is tied to playing it's sequel and isn't obtainable at the present).
Hiveswap is a delightful experience, and I could hardly have enjoyed it more.

35144775.review:
If you're reading this review, you're one of two sorts of people: either a lapsed Homestuck fan ready to dive back in, or someone who has no idea what's going on, but wants to find out. For the former: yes, this is the Homestuck you know... in video game form!

If you're the latter: I can't think of any better way to dive into this franchise. The art is beautiful, the music is amazing, the characters have more depth than a tunnel, and overall the whole package is just so full of heart. At its core, the plot is straightforward: teenage girl Joey Claire finds herself stuck on an alien world with no way home and must find a way to survive. You know, the usual faire.

As you play your way through the admittedly simple puzzles though, you'll find something else: like its parent Homestuck, Hiveswap is about relationships. As you search Joey's home to find flashlight batteries, you'll quickly find signs pointing towards the distressed relationship she shares with her absent, adventure-loving father. You'll learn about Jude, her paranoid dweeb of a brother whom she still loves. You'll learn about her mother, her dearly departed role model.

And that's just while you're still on Earth.

While Hiveswap is far, far more accessible than Homestuck, there are still a few artifacts of the franchise that will disorient newcomers a little bit. Battle sequences mimic a traditional combat system, rather than being one in of themselves. The game also jumps to different points of view every now and then. They don't last too long, but they can be disorienting. The hint function is completely useless as of this review.

These flaws aside, I still wholeheartedly recommend this game. I can't wait to find out more about the characters and the utterly chaotic situation they've been thrown into, and I suspect you'll feel the same way.

If you were a long time homestuck fan like I was, it's worth the buy. Hell, this game made me wanna re-read the webcomic again. If you never read homestuck, or are just new to it, it's a good game still. To me personally, this is a very tame version of Homestuck. If anything, this game is like a gateway to Homestuck. You like the jokes and funny dialogue in this game, you'll see more in the webcomic. To me, I wish there were more obscure jokes that would be special to the long time fans, but to be honest, I'm glad they didn't put any of that. I'm glad that they decide to pull back all the old Homestucks and put some new quirks. No need to bring back old jokes when you can just make some new ones.

This has been something that dedicated fans to homestuck have been waiting for - myself included. Hiveswap doesn't require you to read the heavily popular webcomic "Homestuck" though, if you have you'll understand a lot of references and some of what's going on already. This game is rather short as a warning, but it's packed full of details where you can interact with the environment and get different reactions for doing so. Think of older games like Discworld where you can retrieve items to advance with puzzles and can use these items where they don't belong to get some rather funny responses.

  The music is great, the amount of detail and humor is great, it still sticks to the same algorithm as the comic for the most part while fitting into a side scrolling world. There's been a lot of hardships for this and it's finally here - I'd say this is exactly what we were wanting too. I'd reccommend this for everybody since the characters have wonderful personalities that you can grow attached too, like they should be.

My only complaint is there are some game breaking bugs that are pretty severe in some cases or just silly and not harmful in others. Play carefully and save often.

Overall I give this game a 9/10 like it has already.

35134389.review:
Hiveswap est un jeu "point and click" développé et édité par un studio à première vue énigmatique, What Pumpkin Games, souhaitant rendre hommage aux jeux d'aventure de la fin du second millénaire. L'une des raisons pourquoi ce jeu a explosé, c'est parce qu'on peut retrouver de grands noms dans les personnes qui ont développé ce jeu, avec notamment Toby Fox, le créateur du fameux Undertale et de sa soundtrack incroyable, et Andrew Hussie, le créateur de MSPaintAdventures et, bien sûr, de Homestuck.

Pour ceux qui ne le connaissent pas, Homestuck est un webcomic totalisant plus de 8 000 pages (et ce sur plus de 8 ans) ayant amassé un fandom massif mais à très mauvaise réputation. Et c'est dans l'univers de Homestuck que le jeu se passe, ce qui là encore a beaucoup contribué au succès de ce jeu: après l'annonce du développement d'un jeu vidéo basé sur Homestuck sur Kickstarter en 2012, il n'aura fallu que 32 heures pour qu'Andrew atteigne son but de 700 000 dollars, et au bout d'un mois sa campagne aura amassé quasiment 2 500 000 dollars, soit trois fois plus que son but original, preuve du dévouement des fans du webcomic.

Malgré tout, il aura fallu un peu plus de cinq ans pour voir le premier acte de ce jeu sortir; en effet, à la manière des jeux de Telltale Games, l'histoire de ce jeu sera divisée en quatre actes, puis un autre jeu, nommé Hauntswitch, sortira et prendra le relais (d'après ce que j'ai compris). Le prix d'un acte étant actuellement de huit euros, on peut supposer que le jeu complet rassemblant les quatre actes sera au prix de 32 euros. Mais alors, est-ce que tout cela vaut vraiment le coup ?

Eh bien, tout d'abord, penchons-nous sur ce que le jeu a à nous offrir. Dans Hiveswap, ou du moins son premier acte, on incarne successivement Joey Claire, Jude Harley et Xefros Tritoh, le dernier étant un troll (oui, les fameux trolls de Homestuck) à l'instar des deux précédents personnages qui sont humains. Chaque personnage a une personnalité très précise (peut-être un peu moins Jude étant donné qu'on ne le joue que très peu comparé à ses deux congénères), nous rapprochant beaucoup d'eux.

L'histoire se passe au beau milieu des années 90, ce qui donnera lieu à de nombreuses références à son sujet, ainsi qu'au sujet de Homestuck: beaucoup d'éléments paraîteront assez flous aux yeux de ceux qui n'ont pas lu le webcomic (on peut citer le concept des lusus et des moirails, par exemple) tandis que les habitués de Homestuck sauront reconnaître des choses que les autres seraient incapables de distinguer (notamment les références aux cherubs ou le fait que la babysitter de Joey et de Jude est (sans doute) Roxy Lalonde de Homestuck). C'est sans doute l'une des choses qui peuvent repousser les nouveaux arrivants, mais rassurez-vous: même sans avoir lu le webcomic à la base de Hiveswap, il n'est pas nécessaire de l'avoir fait pour passer un bon moment.

Le jeu est un point and click: bien que cela puisse sembler assez ennuyant au premier abord, ce qui démarque Hiveswap c'est le fait qu'on peut utiliser (presque) n'importe quel objet de votre inventaire sur (presque) n'importe quoi, donnant lieu à des textes de narration plus intelligents et marrants les uns que les autres. Parce que oui, Andrew Hussie lui-même a été chargé de l'écriture des textes, donc si vous espériez trouver quelque chose très similaire à Homestuck, vous ne pouviez pas tomber mieux. Il y a quelques scènes de combat dans Hiveswap, mais elles ne consistent que à trouver quelle combinaison d'objets utiliser sur quel monstre; cela est malgré tout compensé par les textes cocasses s'affichant lors des tours, rendant une expérience ennuyante à la base très sympathique au final.

La difficulté n'est franchement pas un problème dans Hiveswap: le jeu vous aide lors des énigmes et s'assure que vous ne restiez pas bloqués car vous avez loupé un objet irrécupérable. Lors des combats, il est impossible de perdre: le game over est impossible dans cette partie (mais tout de même possible, même si très difficile à faire !), vous laissant le temps de tenter chaque item et chaque combinaison en paix.

Ma partie favorite est sans aucun doute la bande son. On nous a promis du Toby Fox, et on ne nous a pas déçu du tout, au point où je me suis senti obligé d'acheter la soundtrack à 8 euros pour soutenir le travail des compositeurs (oui, Toby Fox n'est pas le seul compositeur dans Hiveswap). Je n'ai pas grand chose à vous dire dessus, si ce n'est de bien profiter des musiques de Hiveswap ou, si vous ne comptez pas l'acheter, [strike]le cracker[/strike] écouter ses musiques sur YouTube. Les animations aussi sont très raffinées, mais là encore je ne peux pas vraiment tout vous décrire de manière précise: allez donc regarder les bandes annonces de Hiveswap où vous pourrez vous faire une meilleure idée de la qualité globale des animations et du dessin.

Il y a malheureusement un point qui est assez négatif: la durée de vie. En effet, malgré le fait qu'il m'aura fallu quelques cinq heures pour terminer le premier acte, le terminer en deux, voire une heure est possible. La rejouabilité ne compte que sur la multitude de combinaisons d'objets possibles dans et en dehors des batailles, et même avec ça, il sera difficile de continuer à éprouver beaucoup de plaisir à jouer à Hiveswap après une dizaine d'heures de jeu. Les mauvaises langues pourront dire que c'est très faible en citant le fait qu'il aura fallu attendre cinq ans pour la sortie du jeu, mais pour huit euros, je ne dirais pas que tout est gâché à cause de ça. Il y avait aussi quelques bugs à la sortie du jeu, notamment avec la résolution, mais après avoir joué à la nouvelle version, je pense que tous les bugs majeurs sont partis.

En conclusion, au même titre qu'Undertale, Hiveswap est un très bonne expérience si vous êtes à l'aise en anglais et si vous aimez la lecture. Il ne reste plus qu'à espérer que le second acte sort avant 2022 ! En l'attendant, lire Homestuck pourrait être une bonne idée si vous souhaitez comprendre la multitude de références à celui-ci éparpillés dans le jeu.

35126419.review:
Hiveswap is a very interesting game to begin with.
It's a point-and-click adventure game based upon the webcomic 'Homestuck'. In fact, it all started because of a kickstarter for a Homestuck adventure game!

On its own, Hiveswap is a very fun love letter to old point-and-click games, like the Monkey Island series. It also is chockful of references to the real world and its webcomic counterpart.

The puzzles, albeit quite easy to get the hang of, are very intuitive and is still very satisfying when solved.
The music is FUCKING AMAZING. You should buy the soundtrack. Seriously. The soundtrack is just beautiful.
The art is rich in detail, and almost every detail in each room has its own specific line of dialog. Hell, all item combinations and item-detail combinations have their own unique text!

This game is something that I've been looking forward to for a very long time now, and it's very nice to see it come out. It's such a beautiful game and I cannot stress enough how great it is.

So please. Buy the game and play it. It's 2 hours of fun that you'd never trade for any other game like Hiveswap.
(Of course, this is just Act 1 though. Act 2 when???)

THE GOOD AND THE BAD: 

[*] took a while for the plot to really get started so you will need to commit to at least 40-60min of gameplay before it gets going, but by the end I was hooked (eagerly awaiting Act 2!)

[*] the game is very VERY text-heavy, so your enjoyment of this game is really going to depend upon your sense of humour. (I absolutly loved it, but if it's not your style of comedy then it might feel a bit tedious)

[*] despite being set in the Homestuck universe, no knowledge/reading of the webcomic is needed to enjoy/understand this. Game explains nessicary plot details, very acessable to newcomers

[*] no tutorials, game just kinda...lets you figure things out for yourself (which can be a bit frustrating) 

[*] lots of 90's nostalgia (if that's a pro or a con is really up to you)

[*] BG art is amazing, characters themselves are done very cute, simple and stylized - you'll either find the designs adorably quirky, or jarringly out-of-place against to the deatailed BG art. 

[*] soundtrack perfectly sets the mood for every area 

[*] nearly EVERYTHING on the screen has flavour text 

[*] overall VERY enjoyable, but could have been longer. Act 1 feels a bit short, although this will depend on how long it take you to solve the puzzles

FINAL VERDICT: personally, I loved it. However, it's definatly not going to be everyones cup of tea.

As a Homestuck fan and a child of the 90s, I had a great time with this. References. References everywhere. 

The character-building was delightful; I loved both Joey and Jude, and I very much enjoyed finding out about their lives via environment interactions. That said, the fact that this is part 1 of an 8 game double-series is a definite weakness. 

Even as a built-in fan, I didn't feel like the narrative accomplished anything of import in this first part. It was very much set-up for further installments. My advice to folks new to the franchise would be to wait for more Acts to be out before trying this out; you'll probably be more satisfied once the story has more beats to it. Speaking selfishly, I'd say I hope you get it anyway. I would very much like the devs to be funded enough to get through the entirety of this project.

35106533.review:
This was probably the first time I’ve experienced video game nostalgia…ever. Edutainment games were the only kind our parents let us play as kids, and well, a lot of those tend to be p&c adventure games. So it stands to reason that Hiveswap was a major throwback for me, from the familiar routine of clicking everything in the environment and using everything on everything in frustration (except that the interaction text went a long way in attenuating that frustration), to the manual saving (and forgetting to do it), to the awkward BGM-filled pauses as you pondered the solutions to the puzzles, etc etc.

Basically, Hiveswap recreates the feel of 90s/early 00s p&c adventure games incredibly well, and to its own benefit, because that drew me right into the world. The game is beautiful; the art is atmospheric and lush and just a treat to look at. The spaces truly feel lived-in and the attention to detail is magnificent. The music complements it perfectly, too–none too dramatic, and atmospheric without overtly dictating how you’re supposed to feel.

Also outstanding was the way that the story of Joey and Jude’s family was told just through interaction text. They managed to pull off a backstory for Grandpa Harley that not only flows seamlessly with the HS canon and does not feel like a forced afterthought, but is also affecting and kind of heartbreaking. It's a deftly-handled exploration at the lives of the children of an absentee parent. It’s all just superb storytelling (and rather reminiscent of HS).

Basically, Hiveswap absolutely does stand on its own merits; knowing Homestuck offers depth and insight into certain characters, but is ultimately not compulsory.

My main complaint is that the cutscenes initially didn’t work on my fairly low-end laptop, but that’s mostly a problem on my end. The interface got in the way at times, and I felt a little jilted by the Strife scenes which turned out to not be real combat–but I’m less bothered by it in hindsight.

I have yet to find every secret of the game--there's just so much to be discovered--so I'm definitely going to give this a second playthrough. It's a very relaxing and engrossing game, and reaching the end gave me the feeling of having finished a satisfying first book in a series.

35103300.review:
Hiveswap is an easy introduction into point and click games. It doesn't take any explicit instruction to understand its gameplay, with a few pointed comments in the narration serving that function organically. This makes the story front and center to enjoy. The smooth simplicity is a perfect vehicle for the vibrant art and animation, the dense story-world, the distinctive music, and the engaging commentary of the protagonist.
As far as I can tell having read Homestuck, Hiveswap: Act 1 fulfills its promise to be accessible to newcomers. Fans of the nineties get thrown as many references as fans of the original webcomic, and characters and concepts are well established over the course of the game. All the dynamic style that made Homestuck popular is in full force, being presented in a condensed and digestible form. 
The game took me 3.2 hours, playing casually. I tried to click every object I saw, but I didn't test through every object/inventory combination possible. You might be able to shave off the .2 if you ignore flavor text, or get another hour  messing around some more. Either way the price is worth it. 
(I couldn't play the cutscenes at first, but that doesn't affect my rating because the issue resolved itself.)

I got into Homestuck a bit after the tragic "[S] GAME OVER". Was quite sad when it ended, it was definitely something I'll never forget experiencing. Of course, I had heard of Hiveswap, but I sorta just forgot about it after all the delays (yes, I understand that it wasn't Hussie's fault).

Come the day before the release of Act 1. My friend comes up to me at lunch time during school and says "Guess what comes out tomorrow?" I had actually forgotten, so he had to tell me it was Hiveswap. Since I wasn't able to purchase the game myself, he gifted it to me. 

I start up the game, and take in the title screen. Oh boy, the music is great already.

Even though this Act is short, it really shows a lot of personality in the characters and builds a memorable cast easily. The humor in the game is very similar to the comic's humor, which I absolutely adored. The soundtrack is great (Rustblood in particular I remember well because the gOD DAMN SLOTH TREATS) and I've listened to it many times over without it getting old to me. The effort put into Hiveswap shows in the animation, environments, and pretty much the entire game. There's plenty of hidden achievements for achievement hunters out there. 

In it's entirety, this game is amazing, and in my opinion it was definitely worth the wait. I really enjoyed it and can't wait for Act 2 (hope it doesn't take another 5 years!)

35096476.review:
Overall I really enjoyed this one. The animation is well drawn and detailed with quality sound. I like how unique the text is for nearly every possible use of an item against another object. The shift in perspective of characters in the story kept it interesting too. I didn't have any technical issues (Win10/Intel/Nvidia) along the way unlike other reviews that I've seen. It takes about 2-3 hours to finish this act which isn't bad for $8 assuming full price. I'll likely be playing the future acts if/when they release.

As for the negatives:
- This is only Act I. Honestly I'm a bit tired of games releasing in episodes/acts/etc since who knows if the rest will ever come out and how consistent the quality will remain. Plus sometimes they've nickel and dimed you by the final release.
- Animation is a bit clunky... the walking pace at times is a bit jittery with the character animations.
- Can't re-examine items in inventory... this is a strange absence for a point & click since you can only identify your items by memory/icon alone without trying to use it
- Inventory dropdown would persistently open at times even though I previously closed it 
- The forced perspective of character in the room seemed a bit off, and sometimes it was confusing figuring out which way to move to walk around a room that's open to exploring.

35096426.review:
So far, I'm impressed! It's only Act 1, but the little bits of story and character development we've gotten so far have sucked me in. I want to learn about and do more with the four main characters! The art and animation are really great, and the music is as fun as I had hoped! So much detail put into the world you get to explore and the things you get to interact with! There are so many references to the 90's and to Homestuck that a bunch of people are bound to love!

I personally didn't mind exploring and reading it all, though some people might find it tedious (anybody familiar with Homestuck already knows what to expect). Some people might also find the puzzles and battles too easy. I didn't mind too much, plus it's only the first Act, so who knows what else we'll be put up against. I also didn't have any of the issues I've been hearing about with the cutscenes or black boxes, so I can't really comment on those. Some people are satisfied with the length of the first Act, some are disappointed, it really depends on the person and how much time you spend exploring.

The quirky charm and humor that I was hoping for was also there in the way the characters interacted with each other and the world around them. (A particular scene with Jude is my favorite so far in this game).

Overall, thrilled it's finally out, felt like it was an awesome intro to a 4-part game (and then we get Hauntswitch after that!), and can't wait for the next Act. Just hoping we don't have to wait forever for it, but even so I plan on playing every Act!

35082459.review:
[b] [i]  «Хайвсвап…как много в этом слове фанатам Хомстака…»[/i] [/b]
[i] (Не самый лучший эпиграф, но пусть будет). [/i]

[b] [i] Итак, Хайвсвап. [/i][/b]
[b] [i] Сразу стоит сказать, что в данной игре много отсылок к такому веб-комиксу, как Хомстак (Homestuck). Собственно, и популярность данной простенькой, но, довольно-таки милой игрушке принесли именно фанаты Хомстака. [/i][/b]
[b] [i] Пересказывать сам веб-комикс я не буду, да, и смысла как такового нет, т.к. Хайвсвап стоит несколько особняком от Хомстака (хотя и располагает аналогичными реалиями/является своеобразным приквелом/сиквелом? к основным событиям серии) … [/i][/b]
[b] [i] Поэтому, данная игра вполне подойдёт и для тех, кто Хомстак не читал и вообще не знает, что это такое и с чем его едят. [/i][/b]
[b] [i] Хайвсвап: Акт 1 представляет собой первую часть (из четырёх возможных частей?), эдакую завязку истории о девочке по имени Джои с Земли, которая на один день «поменялась» домами с представителем планеты Альтерния по имени Даммек. [/i][/b]

 [spoiler] [b] [i] 11 ноября. Обыкновенный осенний вечер. Девочка Джои вместе со своим братом Джудом играют во дворе с собачкой. Всё мило и приятно. Как тут, внезапно, на них нападают полчища монстров. [/i][/b] [/spoiler]
[spoiler] [b] [i] Джои прячется в доме, а Джуд в своём маленьком домике на дереве, во дворе. [/i][/b] [/spoiler]
[spoiler] [b] [i] Оказавшись дома, Джои, находит рацию и связывается с братом, который советует ей отправиться на чердак и спрятаться от монстров там, пока всё не утихнет. Но, вот беда, ключа от чердака у Джои нет. Спустя некоторое время, проведённое в подвале в поисках ключа от чердака, Джои находит и его. [/i][/b] [/spoiler]
[spoiler] [b] [i] Попав на чердак, она обнаруживает странный портал, который переносит нашу героиню…на другую планету! [/i][/b] [/spoiler]
[spoiler] [b] [i] Далее, спойлерить уже не буду, ибо тогда игра потеряет всякий смысл. А смысл подобных игр, в жанре кликабельного квеста, заключается, непосредственно в преподнесении истории, при помощи компьютерных технологий. [/i][/b] [/spoiler]

[b] [i] Лучше, рассмотрим основные плюсы и минусы игры, которые были мною замечены: [/i][/b]

[b] [i] «+» (о плюсах). [/i][/b]
[b] [i] 1. Первое, что мне, безусловно, понравилось в данном квесте – это великолепнейший, нет, замечательнейший, нет, превосходнейший …саундтрек. (Стоит добавить, что веб-комиксы авторства Эндрю Хасси всегда славились приятным музыкальным оформлением, и игра от тех же создателей достойно держит марку в данном плане). [/i][/b]
[b] [i] 2. Приятная 2-D графика и красивые фоны. [/i][/b]
[b] [i] 3. Много хороших шуток и иронии. [/i][/b]
[b] [i] 4. Добрые и милые персонажи, которым даже начинаешь сопереживать. Несмотря на свою простоту, они – живые. У них есть свои особенности и прописаны они хорошо. [/i][/b]
[b] [i] 5. Ачивменты достигаются довольно легко и на них не нужно тратить половину своей жизни. (за исключением ачивмента >BOROS, чтобы его открыть, нужно долго ждать выхода второй части игры). [/i][/b]
[b] [i] 6. Вышеупомянутые отсылки к Хомстаку. [spoiler] Doc Scratch, The Felt, Alternia, The Signless, Flarp, and so on… [/spoiler] [/i][/b]

[b] [i] и «-» (о минусах). [/i][/b]
[b] [i] 1. Во-первых, это баги. Куда же без них. При первом запуске, катсцены и флеш-переходы могут зависать или не прогружаться вообще, из-за чего большая часть истории попросту теряется. Что, кажется вдвойне обидным, ибо первый акт Хайвсвапа и без того коротенький. [/i][/b]

[b] [i] «+/-» (мне было сложно определить, хорошо это или плохо, поэтому и плюс, и минус): [/i][/b]
[b] [i] 1. Языковые проблемы. Если вы плохо знаете английский язык, то, вы наврятли поймёте о чём говорят персонажи, не поймёте вы и шуток, и иронии…[/i][/b]
[b] [i] С другой стороны, не это ли хороший повод выучить для себя английский язык? Или ещё раз повторить и проверить своё знание английского, если вы его когда-то изучали? [/i][/b]
[b] [i] 2. Игра слишком короткая. С одной стороны – это хорошо, ибо время – наиценнейший ресурс…с другой – жалко, что почти за 200 рублей вы получаете такой коротенький и довольно простой квест. [/i][/b]
[b] [i] 3. Гипер-популярность игры. И, невольно начинаешь задумываться: а что, если бы Хайвсвап создал не известный веб-комиксист Эндрю Хасси, а кто-нибудь другой…был бы ТОГДА Хайвсвап популярен? Стали бы играть в него люди? Понравился бы им он? Ответ неясен. [/i][/b]

[b] [i] И, наконец, вывод [spoiler]после которого я уже перестану мучить вас своими длинными и бестолковыми речами, которые вам начинают порядком поднадоедать [/spoiler] : Хайвсвап – неплохой квест (в жанре point-drag-and-click-adventure) с приятной графикой и достойным музыкальным оформлением, но, коротенький и местами лагающий. Хотя, как завязка к полноценной истории – очень и очень хорош. [/i][/b]
[b] [i] Поэтому, покупать или не покупать – [spoiler]как обычно[/spoiler]  вам решать! [/i][/b]

35081104.review:
I'm a long-time Homestuck fan who's been waiting on this game since I spent probably way too much money backing the Kickstarter for the seer pack and bro pack reward tiers (I didn't know at the time the Gamebro tee and the tarot cards wouldn't be exclusive).  After years of production drama hearsay and lost faith, I've been nervously anticipating this game and trying to keep an open mind.  Overall, I'm relieved with the results.  And full disclosure, this review is voiced from the perspective of someone comparing it to the webcomic, which may or may not be fair, but is the only way I can personally judge it.

The positives:
-Beautiful, atmospheric background art and cutscene animation.  The illustrated backgrounds strike a sharp contrast with the aliased photo-manipulation art of the original comic, but the art team did a great job creating scenes that fit in well with the vividly colored worlds of Homestuck.
-Fantastic soundtrack.  James Roach struck me as an unusual choice for music lead back when it was announced, given the vast arsenal of music team members from the original comic, but it's clear now that it was the right one.  The music is quirky and fun, and it never gets tiring (except for maybe one song, you know they one).  I really appreciate the FFVII homage pieces.  And, of course, Toby Fox's song-writing cannot be beat.
-I love the characters.  Joey is such a likable protagonist.  She strikes me as the sort of character Jade was always supposed to be.  Both her and Xefros have some very nuanced personality traits and flaws, and learning more about their lives and their thoughts from exploring the environment was my favorite part of the game.  And the end of the act threw an emotional punch that I was not expecting, but was happy to see (especially after some character arcs were rather clumsily handled in the conclusion of the webcomic).
-The flavor text.  There is SO much optional flavor text.  I've been trying every combination of item/action on object I can manage in the game, and nearly everything gets its own unique flavor text.  Even though the playtime of this act is short, if you're dedicated to exploring the environments and interested in milking out every tidbit of lore you can spend hours with it.
-The setting.  Specifically, the background of 1994 (It's difficult for me to judge the depiction of Alternia just in this game, given how I'm already familiar with it, but additional tidbits of world-building were lovely).  I love the way this game acknowledges nostalgia without shoving it down our throats.  The fact that that the game is happening in the early-mid Nineties is completely incidental to the plot, and if you were too young to get the references then there's not much lost, since the text is more interested in pointing out the absurdity and humor of ancient trends then reveling in their greatness.  The setting mainly serves the purpose of being a cute, refreshing backdrop and sometimes the butt of a joke.  I think a certain popular novel-soon-to-be-movie can take a lesson here on the proper way to use nostalgia in your science fiction.

The cons:
-The most obvious thing here are the glitches and they typos.  I was lucky enough to not be hit by any of the bugs that effect the cutscenes and the music, but I did play through the entire game with the resolution/letterboxing glitch.  These along with the VAST amount of typos and grammatical errors give the impression that the game wasn't playtested enough (or really at all).  Hopefully a patch will be released to fix these.
-The UI could have been better.  Nothing game-breaking, but the overlay is large and gets in the way of some clickable objects.  Additionally, there are some instances when you have to click the edge of the screen multiple times to, say, descend some stairs because the screen doesn’t move enough.
-The combat.  The puzzles in this game were fairly simple.  The game basically tells you what to do most of the time, and I don't think that's a bad thing, especially considering that most people playing this probably won't have much experience with point-and-clicks.  But the strife sequences are confusing and unintuitive, especially with the flashing text that disappears before your eyes have a chance to figure out what they are looking at.  Luckily there is no way to fail, since you don't have any HP.
-The humor.  And this might not be fair, since the humor wasn’t really bad, but I had some expectations going into the game.  This is a warning for the Homestuck fans who are curious about how the writing compares to the comic: the humor is very tame, and it's plainly not written by Hussie (you don’t need the credits to see that).  If you asked me what my favorite part about Homestuck was, I'd probably tell you it was the characters.  But if you asked me why I loved the characters, it would have to be because of the brilliant comedic voice given to them by the author.  Karkat's disgustingly colorful and creative strings of profanity read like poetry.  Dave's long and uncomfortable metaphors filled to bursting with human sexual innuendo still make me double over in laughter all these years later.  Fists full of penis, heads full of empty, babies dual-wielding flintlock pistols: nothing in this game can really compare to the wordsmithing hilarity that was found in the comic.  Humor is subjective, and there were plenty of moments in this game that got a smirk out of me, but if you are looking for more of the magic that was Homestuck's comedic gold you will not find it here.

Overall, I rate this game as not a disappointment.  Most of my complaints a fairly minor and they didn’t ruin the experience of the game.  I honestly think that fans of the franchise will look more harshly at it than newcomers due to that high expectation left by Homestuck and the frustration with production setbacks.  However, there is plenty to enjoy for both camps, and Hiveswap deserves to be taken as its own body.  I’m eager to see it get more exposure and pushed into the mainstream.  Since this is only the first part of 4 I can't say much about the plot yet, but I'm excited to see where it goes.  Hiveswap is charming, fun, and deserves all the praise and fans it can get.

35078603.review:
I would recommend it to those who really like point and click, have read homestuck, and wouldn't care much if they lost 8 dollars. Everyone who doesn't fit that exact bill I would warn away for a few reasons:

There isn't much content. It was only three hours for me and I am very very bad at puzzle games. It could be about 1 1/2 or less for someone good at games and focusing on it. The background art is pretty but the actual sprites are choppily animated and when it goes into detail shots it looks like they haven’t finished painting it. I can clearly see brush strokes in ways that do not look artistic. It looks lazy. Some of the animations look like they've been slid to the side rather then properly done too. The screen postion glitches like crazy and if you are not in the exactly correct angle you cannot click things you can clearly see. There isn't any explanation for anything, not even basic game mechanics, and it starts out slow and rather boring. It gets progressively better but honestly doesn't even remotely live up to the hype. The best part of the entire game were the chatlogs and you barely do any game-like things with those. If I had brought this while still excited about it I would have been severely disappointed. 

If you look at it from an indie perspective it’s a cute game that could be worth your money if you like puzzle games, but from a professional perspective it’s under finished and lazy. I don’t regret buying it because I want to support hussie and thought the idea was cool, but I left feeling severely underwhelmed and like I’m missing the other half of my purchase.

I'm really hoping the lack of qaulity in act 1 is from Hussie rushing to finally get something out and not actually laziness, and that the rest of the arcs will be better. I will buy the next one but reluctantly. If it has the same issues with not enough redeaming qaulities I'm quiting hiveswap.

35077902.review:
A bit of background- I'm a huge Homestuck fan. Hearing about this game immediately got me super-pumped, and while it did take 5 years, I was happy to wait for this game. I wasn't able to back it, but I was as eager as everyone else to see this game release, and finally it was!

Now, upon first purchasing the game, I experienced some bugs. Cutscene skipping, specifically, which is a common bug with the game. It's NOT your computer, guys! 
++A fair reminder, What Pumpkin is a new developer studio, and even huge AAA-Title games, devs and studios have huge, HUGE game-breaking bugs in their games at launch. (Mass Effect, anyone?)

That being said, I was able to test the new build and the game worked FANTASTICALLY! I was able to watch the cutscenes, and there was minimal lagging- due to my computer's low processing. But still, the game was playable, I had no hitches that hindered gameplay.

Now, the actual game...is wonderful. Homestuck fan or not, casual or serious, no experience with the fandom whatsoever- this game exists peacefully in all realms. The references were there, but made to cater to all audiences, not alienate. (Which is something I HATE in other games, making obscure references that only hardcore fans would know)
The animation is lovely. The music is ASTOUNDING. The UI is intuitive, simple, attractive and thematic. The dialogue written between characters is natural and nothing is forced to resemble Homestuck in any way. While the first Act is only a few hours long, for a person like me who has problems focusing, it was the perfect length, especially for an episodic that is $8 a pop. PLUS, I got the Soundtrack Bundle, and the OST is fantastic. 

Not to mention, ALL OF THE 90S REFERENCES. The moment Pogs were mentioned, I was thrown back into my youth where pogs were everywhere and Clarissa, indeed, Explained It All.

Overall- this game is WONDERFUL. I'm looking forward to the next Acts and Hauntswitch as well. Bravo, WhatPumpkin, Bravo!

35077577.review:
An amazing game with fantastic design, cute animations, charming dialogue, and lots of great jokes whether or not you've read Homestuck (though obviously there's a lot more eastereggs and references for those who have read it to enjoy). While the game had a few bugs when I played (specifically two, in my opinion, minor ones with screen transitions not being smooth and one incident of an slightly off-center screen for a bit of dialogue) it didn't overwhelm the story or experience and were easy to play past. The characters are great, and I love how their personalities are constantly expressed whenever you explore the world (Earth or Alternia) from their perspective. And they have WONDERFUL personalities at that! I love practically all of the characters in the game, the ones from Homestuck and the new ones who are introduced!
While the combat/strife is somewhat pointless the puns and entertainment from them are still a great experience and fit with the whole "puzzle and solution" focus of point-and-click adventures to an extent. The artwork is spectacular and the design of the environments have lots of detail and help immerse the player into the game even more.
A GREAT game for Homestuck fans and people looking to try out the point-and-click genre (though if your looking for complex puzzles to really challenge yourself this isn't really the game to do it) and a fun way to spend a few hours and have a couple (or a lot) of laughs. Some people are complaining that ACT 1 is too short, but there's so much too look at and have fun with that the game takes up a couple of hours (mostly if you're intent on exploring EVERYTHING, which I recommend you should) and the quality overall is outstanding, even if the quantity isn't as much as one would expect because of the time in production. But then again, this is only the first ACT and the real meat of the game will most definitely be in the ones to follow as was the case with Homestuck itself.
Sorry for the essay, this is just an AWESOME game that I would recommend to anyone who has a ten dollar bill and I'm hyped for what ACT 2 will bring to the table because if it's anything like ACT 1 it's going to be AMAZING!!!

35075888.review:
This game is a delight to experience. I’ve played a few point and click adventures in my time, but none that feel as full and vibrant as Hiveswap, with its beautifully rendered environments and wonderfully fitting soundtrack. The areas you explore feel alive, like actual lived-in spaces chock full of personality in their own right. This, along with the clever and humorous tone of the writing, means the way you learn about the characters from examining objects and areas in their homes feels natural in a way that games seldom land. Speaking of the characters, they’re all wonderful. One of Homestuck’s strong suits has always been its character writing, and it really shows in the main cast of the game. They’re just a bunch of kids, each with their own hobbies and interests, but also their own aspirations, worries, and problems that they have to reckon with. I won't go too deep into specifics, because you really ought to meet these kids for yourself. They all feel unique and human (or er, not, as the case may be) and interactions between characters were frequently my favourite parts of the game.

If you’re worried about getting Hiveswap because of the convoluted behemoth that is the source material, you shouldn’t be. Even though they take place in the same universe, the events of Homestuck proper haven’t even technically taken place yet, and familiarity with that story is not required. Everything that is relevant to the game is explained, and the stuff that isn’t is just sort of hinted at in the background. The kind of stuff that might make fans of the comic go “huh!” but isn’t critical in order for new players to understand and enjoy the game. Hiveswap completely stands on its own as an adventure game, and a darn good one at that! The solutions to the puzzles always make sense, even if they’re not always immediately obvious. No combining a magnet and some human hair to make a fishing line or some such nonsense; the most convoluted these solutions ever get is putting some liquid in a bowl, or choosing the right moment for a refreshing energy drink. Even if you do get stuck it’s not so bad, as mashing items together to try and find a solution is fun in its own right. The game always rewards you for trying to interact with it, even if you’re not exactly accomplishing anything by doing so. There’s unique text for seemingly EVERY combination of items on each other, and for using them on almost EVERY object in the environment. Seriously, it’s mindboggling just how much optional text there is in this game. I’m very tempted to go back and replay it just so I can try clicking everything on everything else, just to see what happens.

All that’s not to say that Hiveswap doesn’t have its own problems. Anyone who’s followed the project from the beginning knows this game has had a troubled development, and at times I feel like it shows. There’s definitely some bugs that need fixing, like the game loading in the wrong resolution the first time you play it, requiring you to manually change the settings and then restart it to apply them. On another occasion, I solved the puzzle in the trophy room only for the game to keep acting as though I hadn’t, rendering the item you get for completing it unpickupable until I loaded my save and tried again. Only a minor time loss for me, but definitely the sort of thing I hope they patch out before it messes anyone else up. I have some other nit-picks too, like, why does the screenshot button advance the text? For that matter, why does any button other than the spacebar and mouse advance the text? It’s annoying. And while we’re at it, why doesn’t my boy Xefros have an idle animation like the other kids?! He deserves one, dangit! In practice though, these are all things that I can (mostly) overlook because the majority of the game is just so good.

Act 1 of Hiveswap is not a long game. I finished it in a little less than four hours, and that was including time spent exploring and finding most of the flavour text around the environments, though I’m sure I didn’t see everything. It definitely comes down to how you feel about quality over quantity, and I at the very least feel like the quality is absolutely worth the price. This game is witty, funny, and at times just a little bit moving. As the credits rolled, I felt the way you might feel at the end of a really good book, only to realise as you turn the last page that you already want to read it all over again from the beginning. It’s a really good video game, one that’s rekindled my love of a series I thought I’d given up on years ago. Hiveswap has wormed its way into my heart, and it is my one true, sincere hope that Act 2 doesn’t take another five years to come out.

Please. And thank you.

I don't really understand why this was cut into acts. Anyone who was interested has been waiting YEARS for it to come out (to the point where they probably didn't think it would ever actually come out at all), so why not just take a little more time to complete everything and release it once? What have they been doing for the last 6 years? 2 hours of gameplay is not reflective of a 2.5 million dollar kickstarter and 6 years of work. For a game split into acts I wasn't assuming it would be very long, but I really didn't think it would be this short and shallow. 

For anyone who was a kickstarter backer I'd reccomend waiting until the entire game is out before starting so you don't feel let down.

For anyone who is interested in buying it, wait until all four parts make it into a cheap bundle and buy it then. The cost per part will not be worth it at full price, especially if each act is only 2 hours long.

35075139.review:
Oh, man. Hiveswap. The game long awaited by the Homestuck fandom. Long awaited by me. I was really excited to play it, but once I opened it up many of my worst fears came true and most of my hopes were crushed. I like the plot and the storyline and all that jazz, I'll give you that, but the gameplay. The gameplay is sort of decent at best. Now, I'm not sure if this is because my computer is just a tad bit out of date, but a lot of the cutscenes are very laggy and some of the frames blur together into a glitchy amalgamation. Half of the time when I'm in a battle, attempting to do something will make the game freeze, and the only way to keep playing is to force quit it and load it up again. About 20 minutes of my gameplay is me crashing it by making a wrong choice in battle, and going back to try and correct my mistakes. It's the game we've all been waiting for, but in my opinion, there are too many bugs and glitches for the game to be ready for the market. What Pumpkin Games just HAD to put out a release date when the game was in this stage. I am a Homestuck fanatic, but I gotta admit, the game needs a LOT of bug fixes. Although it may have its major downsides, I still reccomend the game.

TL;DR:
It's a decent (at the least) game if you are a hardcore Homestuck fan like me and have been awaiting it's release for a VERY long time. 3.8/5 stars.
It's a very bad, extremely buggy (at the least) game if you have never heard of Hoemstuck and want to get into it by playing this. 2.5/5 stars.

EDIT: 9/20/17
Oh my god. The new update is perfect. It fixed EVERYTHING I just listed up there that made the game horrible. Once again, this fandom and series has managed to capture me with it's perfect imperfection. 5/5 stars!

35063094.review:
Speaking as a longtime Homestuck fan, I'm sadly disappointed by Hiveswap.
I'll first outline the positives and negatives.
Positives
- An incredible, immersive soundtrack. I regret not purchasing this with the soundtrack included as the soundtrack is my favourite part of this game.
- Jam-packed with pop culture references and callbacks to the original webcomic.
- Many great nostalgic 90's references.
- Very witty writing.
- Gorgeous environmental art.

Negatives
- The art and animation is inconsistent, there is a dip in quality as the game reaches it's conclusion.
- For the $10AUD I paid for this, I really did expect there to be more content. I was able to finish this game at my own pace, whilst interacting with everything I could find in the world, in just under 2.5 hours. The pricetag is fairly hefty for what little playtime you're getting. Whilst I understand that this is only the first act in presumably many to come, value for money needs to be taken into consideration here.
- For a point and click game, it's incredibly vague. I had to consult a walkthrough several times just because the game often doesn't make it clear enough what steps you need to take.
- The battle system is quite confusing, and is in desperate need of a tutorial. Whilst it's not set up for you to fail (at this point) it can be quite frustrating.
- The GUI doesn't make it clear enough as to what items you're utilising.

Some improvements that could be made.
-Cutscenes need to be better optimised.
-GUI and strife/captchalogue system could use some tweaks to help make it clearer what you're actually doing with it. Visual feedback is important and unfortunately somewhat lacking in this game.
-Some form of tutorial.
-General polishing of the story and reasoning behind the items you're required to pick up.
-Some new sound effects - that one constant bleep sound began to do my head in very quickly.
-More content for what you're paying for - just because it's only one act doesn't mean it can't be more indepth.

Do I believe this was worth the several year wait since the Kickstarter project? No, I would have expected several more acts to be released in this time frame with a much higher level of polish. This game pays homage to years of dedicated Homestuck fans, with clever callbacks and references, however it's just not [b]enough[/b]  for what you're paying for.
I was so excited and enthralled as soon as the game started, but my enthusiasm very quickly dulled as I found myself getting confused and frustrated quickly, and before I knew it the game was over. 

Here's to hoping Act 2 is an improvement of Act 1.

35061839.review:
Played through the full Act in two and a half hours, with only one puzzle that truly stumped me (and then was actually easy for me to solve) - absolutely worth the $8 for the game if you want the first chapter of a fascinating story with gorgeous art, engaging characters and a true sense of humor. People who worked on this game worked on the likes of Undertale, Unbeatable Squirrel Girl (the comic), the original webcomic Homestuck whose multiverse the game is set in, webcomic Neo-kosmos and many other highly regarded narratives and works of art.

Play this if you like stories, if you like fun, if you like 90s references or if you just like good characters, regardless of whether you're a homestuck fan or not. It's worth the $8.

If you're reading this after playing, and you like the game, the writing style, and the world(s) the game is set in, consider checking out the webcomic that started it all, Homestuck. It's a long read, but the depth, characterization, humor, animations and plot make it more than worthwhile.

Looking forward to Act 2 and onwards!
