35055578.review:
In April of 2009, Andrew Hussie posted the first live updates of his comic Homestuck, although calling it a comic does not give full justice to the inventive ways that work played with the medium. It would take seven years to complete, but it was largely created by a single man, and it was massively long. It's impressive it did not take even longer.

Andrew Hussie is a gifted writer. His comic is inventive, funny, and he did a remarkably good job of writing the complicated story as he went without tripping over himself. The characters were multi-faceted and interesting, the world was well developed, and the exposition was never dull to read. His artwork was also excellent - low detailed and made for speed, but expressive and visually appealing, and although he was a crude, novice animator, he had a real talent for making engaging flash videos. He was especially good at timing the action to a piece of music, which was even more impressive given that the songs were composed first, before the videos were even conceived. There was a constant sense of learning and escalation in the delivery - it began with simple GIFs and short flash projects and expanded to include inventive 10-minute short films. That progression made a nice motif for a story with themes of adventure, discovery, and coming-of-age.

The music was always done by volunteers. Homestuck's website carries two contributor pages - one for music and one for art. Beginning from a little over a year into Homestuck's run, Hussie would take some art submissions for use in his comic. At first this was only for the larger animation projects. But it grew increasingly more frequent, and when the comic ended, one could be forgiven for thinking that Hussie was no longer contributing to Homestuck at all: the final panels and the last animation were done entirely by others.

This of course brings us to Hiveswap, a kind of side-story video game set in Homestuck's multiverse, the creation of which, unbeknownst to the people who backed it on Kickstarter over five years ago, hardly appears to have involved Andrew Hussie at all. He is credited by the game as a writer and producer, and information from Hiveswap's dedicated tumblr indicates that he acted as a kind of creative consultant to the real brains behind the project: Cohen Edenfield.

Who is Cohen Edenfield? According to an autobiographical update on the Hiveswap tumblr he is an English Lit graduate who shared an internet forum with Hussie over a decade ago. The body of his previous work consists of a twitter feed and Hiveswap's promotional material. Before release this did not encourage positive speculation: his former work is written in an insufferable self-aggrandizing voice that tries too hard to be funny.

But to his credit, his scripting for Hiveswap is not that bad. It's hard to say how much Hussie's advice helped, because What Pumpkin have been tight-lipped about the process of their development. About the only thing we do know is that they repeatedly failed to deliver on the release dates they promised, and that the project changed hands at least twice. But for the most part the dialog in Hiveswap is tolerable, and occasionally even funny. Edenfield does sometimes lay it on thick though. In Homestuck, the main character had a book titled "Colonel Sassacre's Daunting Text of Magical Frivolity and Practical Japery." It's a minor joke how overly long and whimsical that title is, and it works for Homestuck's outwardly quirky tone. In Hiveswap, a book is similarly titled "Pistols to Pelts: How to Turn Sweet, Intelligent Animals Into Weird Rugs and Stuff." The first example works because it's actually a plausible title, but the second really overdoes the joke and bungles it.

In Homestuck, the child characters have complicated, ever-changing views of their parents and their relationships. They were confused about who they wanted to be and what their roles in life were. All of this is to say that it did a good job portraying adolescence. Hiveswap doesn't really have that. Joey is fully decided on how she feels about her parents. She shows next to no self-doubt, and her dad is cartoonishly negligent to make that work. It's the same with the story's themes of revolution: the alien regime is entirely, ridiculously wrong and the characters are plainly meant to rebel against it. What exactly is that meant to portray? That monarchy and genocide are wrong? In conversation, the characters spout their life-stories unprovoked, especially Joey in the final scene of the game.

To be fair, this is only the first episode of many, and the later acts might resolve some of these story issues. I wouldn't be too surprised if it at least turned out to be a nice, classically structured adventure story with some decent character arcs. That much potential is there. The backgrounds are nice to look at and the animation is generally good, although there is a problem of the game being so visually cluttered that it sometimes hides the things you need to interact with, and there seems to be no way to tell what's a usable item and what's just background besides mousing over it all. The music is fine and works for the atmosphere but it's not memorable, so that I wouldn't recommend buying the soundtrack. Toby Fox has done much better musical work than this.

And I understand that it isn't fair to compare such a short game to something like Homestuck. That's the point though. Adjust your expectations accordingly: Edenfield is no substitute for Andrew Hussie, and Hiveswap is not and will probably never be Homestuck. In one news update on the Homestuck website, Hussie promised that this game will play with the medium as much as Homestuck itself did. Nothing like that has been displayed so far. This is a decent, standard-fare modern adventure game, completely toothless in terms of both puzzles and story. I'm willing to give it a thumbs-up in Steam's system, and I would score it about a six and a half out of ten. But the recommendation is conditional: if you don't like adventure games this won't change your mind. And if you haven't read Homestuck, your time is much better spent with that.

I could say I spent 8 bucks well but I could also say I pretty much wasted it.
I had some high expectations because the game had been worked on for more than a year but when I first played it I kinda ignored that because I'd been waiting so long to play it. 

[b]the pros[/b]
the graphics are good, the cutscenes are nicely animated, it runs pretty fast (depending on your computer I guess?), it's like a standard point and click adventure, I wasn't sure what more to expect. I could go on and on listing more but I'd like to skip to
[b]the cons[/b]
some parts were boring. this is a puzzle game for sure, but there could be a room with a million items but you have to choose only two to go together. there are frequent hints telling you what to do in the game but often I'd expect a bunch of people to get stuck at at least 2 different parts.
there may be some parts that are confusing as the directed audience is mostly homestuck fans, but it shouldn't stop you from playing it, because later on the game explains itself. 
last but not least, it's short. for its price I expected it to be that type of game with multiple different endings and that you'd have fun playing over and over again. but to me, it's not. it's like a game that once you play, you're done. it'd just be boring to replay it. 
 
TL;DR overall, it is a great game and I felt excited my first play. but do you want to get it?

if you have spare $8 to spend and like adventure games, [i]do it.[/i] it will sure throw away your boredom [strike]for 3 hours[/strike] but it was still pretty fun and I'll be looking forward to ACT 2. and don't worry, you don't have to read a 10,000 page web comic to understand it.

if you don't like click and point puzzle games, have low patience, looking for something exciting and haven't been looking forward to this release since the beginning, don't get it. I'd say this game kinda [i]was[/i] boring and there are parts that you'll probably get stuck but figure out eventually.

35052574.review:
Lets be real here, As far as "problems" go with this game, its mostly how long this game took to come out. End of the day though, if they hadn't been over zealous about release dates, i don't think this would be a problem, the game came out in reasonable amount of time (a little over 4.5 years from the blank slate to the finish) which isn't unusual for games, especially one with so many complications, and this being a first time company.

With 10 hours and 100% completion of act 1 on record, i think its time to put in my review. First off, the art goes without saying in that is extremely attractive and well done. Although the characters themselves and much of the art did mimic the simplicity of the Homestuck style, the backgrounds were rich in detail and the animations smooth in movement, excluding from the nasty loading screens however, which hopefully will be fixed in a patch. Despite the clutter of some of the characters homes; such was well placed and built on each's personality very carefully, as well as many enjoyable references to the time period this game was set in. The plot was quite enjoyable for just being the beginning to the story, as the main character Joey interacts well with both other characters, and background characters, even ones we had presently been aware of were we fans of Homestuck itself, were handled well in explanation. It's especially important to notice that this game has very little relation to Homestuck at all, except for the apparent fact it is the same universe. A few people have been overlooking plot points as "probably references to Homestuck" but in fact I personally found very little references to the webcomic myself, and the ones that did exist explained themselves rather thoroughly, In fact, putting Homestuck aside entirely, people can still easily understand and enjoy this game.


There are of course, a few things on the downside to it. Theres a bird that dies, rather sad, some slightly strange interactions, and bugs in loading between cutscenes, as well as there being a deal of typos (specifically a name recall fail with several of your item uses) when interacting with your Deercat in the final cutscene. I was also a bit puzzled by the fact that e consistently mention the troll main character bleeding under the rocks (presumably to death?) up until the point where we move him out, and he is inexplicably scarcely injured. they did draw the Deercat bleeding, although i have some suspect drawing the troll not bleeding was to keep a rating, since his blood is red? 


The game was a little short, I completed my first run in about 4-5 hours, including the annoying cutscene lag, but completed a speed run in under an hour, with similar lag issues. I hope that the second act will be greatly longer, with that release being without the cutscene lag, but regardless, I'll probably end up playing and enjoying it as well. I'm a simple person.

35042328.review:
I was in high school and heard about the Homestuck Kickstarter. I was ecstatic. I got into college and remained excited. I graduated college, and remained hopeful. Hiveswap arrived. And all is forgiven.
I'm the kind of guy that goes into games exploring and checking everything possible. I've played point-and-click games Venus, where I get disappointed when I'm constantly barraged by the same soundclip of the protagonist saying "I can't do that". When I began playing Hiveswap, I was astounded. I got stuck in Joey's room for a full hour. And not because of a puzzle, but from my own volition. I tried every single item and hotspot combination. And I was fascinated by what I read. I became satisfied when I began getting achievements for trying seemingly innocuous combinations, which was super satisfying. After 8 hours, across a couple of days, I managed to finish Act 1. I was extremely satisfied. I even tried my hand at playing the game all over again, this time skipping all the flavor text. It took me around 15 minutes. That's when I realized my first playthrough was exactly how this game is squeezed out of its content.
I for one found myself relieved with the change of graphics from 3D to 2D. It feels so much more like Homestuck in that way.
The music is just absolutely marvelous. I found myself tapping my foot, my knees, humming along with the music in each room. Even the characters, I gotta say, are a big step up from the source material. Through the constant use of the items and skills in the characters' sylladexes and strife specibi, I got to understand their motivations. Joey's feelings against POGs, Bubsy and her father as well as Xefros' feelings towards his own hobbies and culture.
I really can't wait to see what comes next. 5 years of waiting were worth it, at least for me.

Some time ago I dropped out of the Homestuck scene and forgot I ever backed the Kickstarter. This game has me waxing nostalgic for the old days I read webcomics and played point'n'click escape games. Thoroughly charming writing and settings lovingly imbued with character. 

The major issue cropping up with some players is the cutscenes either lagging heavily or freezing the game entirely. More's the pity since cutscenes are well-animated and abundant. Heard the devteam's aware and working on a patch.
Gameplay for Act: 1 weighs more in exploring the aforementioned charming setting for cheeky humor than puzzle solving. Wouldn't mind half so much if the navigation weren't a little janky, which brings up my only non-bug problem with the game. 35034948.review:
I adore this game! The writing is hilarious - full of clever wordplay and pigeon antics and witty dialogue, but it also delves into some affecting subject matter (absent parents, classism, toxic friendships) with sincerity and sensitivity. The characters are really lovable, especially the main playable character Joey and a certain sport-loving butler boy. The soundtrack is terrific, with loads of catchy beats and haunting melodies - if you loved Undertale's music you'll be well at home here since Toby Fox co-composed! The backgrounds are absolutely gorgeously drawn, and they complement the writing by giving you a strong sense of the characters’ lives and interests. The character designs and animations are just as wonderful – Joey’s nervous fidgeting, peppy tapdancing, and acrobatic pirouetting are endlessly cute ‘n charming. The animations have a snappy, bold, keyframe-heavy style – maybe some extra in-between drawings could have been added here and there, but given how enormously time-consuming hand-drawn animation is I understand why they used their frames economically. It already looks gorgeous and communicates the characters’ personalities perfectly anyway!

Don’t feel discouraged if you’ve never read Homestuck - you don’t need any knowledge of the comic to enjoy Hiveswap since the story is so far self-contained and set years before Homestuck’s events. Long-time fans will find tons of subtle Homestuck references hidden throughout the game, some just for fun, others filling in characters’ pasts and adding an extra layer of intrigue.

My only complaint is that there’re a few minor bugs and typos at the time of writing, but these will all likely be patched by WhatPumpkin soon. The most bothersome one is a resolution/camera-panning hiccup that can appear the first time you launch the game, but it’s easy to fix since the bug seems to disappear for good if you relaunch the game after changing your resolution settings.

Overall I give Hiveswap five out of five transuniversal tapdance teens… I can’t wait for Act 2!

35033639.review:
Full discosure, I used to be a huge fan of Homestuck and backed this game on Kickstarter, so my impression is not so much "I paid $8 for this; was it worth it?" and more "Holy shit this game actually came out; is it any good?". For instance: the game's got a ton of dialog, and it goes on longer than I'd like, but I enjoy slowly getting to know the characters' via their banter and the jokes sometimes make me cackle with glee. However, I almost didn't realize that because it's exactly the same way I felt about Homestuck five years ago, and I took it for granted here. So yeah, take my praise with a grain of salt.

This game is a bunch of fun. The strife puzzle-solving sections are especially good, because they're inventive combat that leverages the game's true strength: Having jokes written for pretty much every bullshit combination of inventory item and puzzle object in the game. The puzzles aren't insane - you're not going to be spending an hour wandering around before you think to use "Fork" on "Pile of Spaghetti" to turn it into a fake hairdo - but they're odd enough that you'll try a couple wrong options, and there will always be something written for it. Hell, one time when I was stuck I tried to use a pile of pogs on a staircase crammed with guns and there was a response for *that*. I got into a fight I didn't know how to win and resorted to throwing everything in my inventory at the monster, and the monster replied with a pun for every single one. I might replay this game and just spend all my time mashing my inventory on the environment.

Speaking of replaying, the game's pretty short! About three hours, I think. I super wanted more - but I know there were some (for high values of "some") production problems, and I'm really glad they spent the money and time they had left on making a short game that's crammed with jokes and crazy visuals rather than a longer, blander game.

Speaking of crazy visuals, holy shit this game looks crazy good! Every scene is crammed with excellent bullshit going on, weird things scampering outside the windows, every shelf jammed with trash literature and nonsensical occult bric-a-brac and leg lamps and conspiracy theory diagrams. It's awesome.

So yeah! I recommend this game, and I'm definitely gonna buy Act 2.

35033249.review:
Homestuck fan or non-Homestuck fan, I think Hiveswap is enjoyable by anyone who plays it and enjoys games involving a good story. I have to warn anyone who wants to buy this game: do not buy this for the puzzles. The puzzles and combat (which itself is still a puzzle, really) are fairly easy. Hiveswap is enjoyable mostly for its story and flavor text when trying to solve puzzles. If you're still here knowing that the puzzles aren't too amazing, then go for it. At eight dollars, this game is certainly worth it. There are many complaints about how short it is, and it is short, but it's not like it feels incomplete considering the price on it. It left off at a good point, and while I'm going to hate to wait for act 2, the game gives you enough content. If we had to wait another 5 years, then yeah this would be ridiculous, but What Pumpkin said that it shouldn't take nearly as long for act 2 to be released.

The game breaks down into about three different categories. I'll briefly talk about each one.

Exploration/puzzle solving: Like I said previously, the puzzles aren't anything special at all, but they're still fun for the most part, and the exploration to figure out the puzzles is entertaining due to the flavor text. However, I wouldn't buy Hiveswap if you're in it for the puzzles.

Combat: The combats are actually small puzzles. You have to use the resources you have along with the terrain around you to defeat enemies. There were a few times that I got frustrated with the combat because the game didn't do a good job of visually displaying the problem with why <insert some item/ability> didn't work how it should've, but it was only like two times, and it did make sense afterward. Might've just been me brainfarting, but I do think there could've been better telegraphing for some of the combats. I really enjoyed this kind of combat/puzzle, however. It felt pretty rewarding to escape or defeat whatever it is you're facing, and the little quips used when you attempt to do something were a nice touch. Overall a small part of the game, but pretty enjoyable when it was there.

Story: I think the best parts of the story are the interactions between characters. The interactions feel natural and stay interesting throughout the entire game. This was definitely my favorite aspect of the game, especially after interacting with the thing in the attic (no spoilers). The interactions were completely solid. As for the other aspects of the story, such as reading your diary or looking at pictures of family on the wall, etc., I enjoyed the sort of "already know but thinking about" perspective. It feels natural and gives you an idea about how the characters feel about each little story blob. 

Yes, there are references to Homestuck in it. While they were very enjoyable, they're a small part of the game that aren't required to pick up on at all for a full enjoyment of the game itself. This game makes you care about the characters within itself, not characters from another story. 

I would certainly recommend this game! There are people who definitely wouldn't care for Hiveswap, don't get me wrong, but I think Hiveswap has a lot to offer to people who like more story-based games. I hope this review was helpful in your decision!

35032254.review:
I just finished playing this game and I have some good as well as bad things to say. To be upfront on my mindset going in: I'm a fairly longtime homestuck fan, and have enjoyed a lot of the franchise for several years now. To say that I was looking forward to this game was an understatement, as I'm sure can be said about a lot of other people! However, as much as I was looking forward to this game and making sure to go into playing it with a fair mindset, there are a lot of things that need fixing for an episodic game that we've waited 5 YEARS for with each part to the game being 8 USD a pop.

[h1]THE GOOD:[/h1]

The visuals are absolutely beautiful! I love how unique they look, yet so close to the original comic we all know and love. I like the detail put into all of the backgrounds, animations and thensome, there was obviously love put into them.

The music is equally beautiful and served quite a bit to keep the flow of the story 'feeling' the way it should. The music was tense when needed, happy when it needed, uplifting when needed. I never found myself feeling odd or off with the choice of tune while I was pulling my hair out for the various little riddles or battling a local beast.

The characters are nice! I like the fact that the cast is entirely new, with the occasional throwback or reference to the older characters we know and love. The two human and troll characters, despite being introduced within a 2-hour game, have some sense of uniqueness to their design, and the good writing that accompanies them helps to flesh them out into quirky, lovable characters. I'm interested in seeing their progression through the story

[h1]THE BAD:[/h1]

The depth of the game itself isn't good. Many times while playing did I find myself outright bored with what was going on--I felt like it would have been far more entertaining to just WATCH all the characters interact rather than trying to pick apart a riddle that, really, shouldn't have taken more than a few seconds to figure out. Instead of enjoying the silliness of the character's adventures through this game like I had with the characters of Homestuck, I found myself begrudgingly wasting fifteen minutes of my life for something that was so out-of-the-way that I don't understand how there weren't more hints to help me figure it out.

Imagine being on a road, and it's going in a very specific direction. Sure, there are cool stuff you'd love to do and investigate, but they're all off the road and you are absolutely not allowed to do that. You can appreciate from a distance all of those cool things, but you have a specific path you have to follow, which quickly depreciates a lot of possible fun when you realize that road is this game. You have little to no options other than the ones you are given--where I was imagining the battle system to be something like Pokemon (turn-based with a fair bit of choice) you get absolutely none of that, and yet it's still tagged as an RPG? No. This is a very linear game that gives you little-to-no options outside of the designated path programmed in it. Linear games can be great, don't get me wrong! Just don't lie and make it look like you are giving the player options and variety when you really are not. This game has the same branching story options as the Homestuck webcomic did: none.

There was no sense of appreciation or pride whenever I got through a challenging bit--more akin to a feeling of relief after you've finally finished all of your homework and want nothing more than to rip it to shreds so you don't have to keep looking at it and the countless minutes you've wasted on something that was stupidly difficult for no reason whatsoever than to make you take more time figuring it out.

Bugs. So many. Bugs. Whether it was the buttons not working or the screen of the game going askew and bugging out, there was no shortage of bugs. I shall remind you that this game took FIVE YEARS of development, and the first visual bug is on the OPENING SCREEN. For a game that has taken this long, cost 8 US dollars for only a less-than-2-hour experience (it personally took me about 1 hour and 45 minutes), this is absolutely unacceptable, especially for such a high-profile game from a very successful webcomic. Images below (if they work) are just a few examples of the visual bugs I'm talking about.

[url=https://i.gyazo.com/a4d545b789eb68bae5f86c6fd0c92168.jpg]Image 1[/url]

[h1]FINAL OPINION:[/h1]

[b]I wouldn't buy the game in its current state.[/b] Don't get me wrong, it looks and sounds beautiful, but that doesn't alone make a good game. 35030780.review:
Alright, so here's the deal. Most of the reviews you'll read on here are going to be people who either just found this game and are wondering what all the fuss is about, or people who've been waiting for this game to come out ever since the Kickstarter launched in 2012, and are just overjoyed to finally play it. I will admit, I belong to the latter group.

But if you want an honest review of this game, it's fantastic. The music is beautiful, the animation and artwork is fantastic, and it captures the comedy and storytelling style of Homestuck perfectly, without being completely impenetrable or falling into the bullshit the original story did. Is it more enjoyable if you've read that monstrosity of a webcomic? Yes. Is it still a really good game? Also yes. Hiveswap doesn't limit itself to Homestuck references, but branches into every aspect of the 90s, right down to poorly-disguised cameo posters for Metroid or The Neverending Story.


One of the biggest complaints I've seen is that there isn't enough play time to warrant its 8-dollar asking price. And it is certainly true that you *can*beat the game in two-ish hours. You can also spend twice that time and not even clear the house you start out in. It all depends on whether you feel like discovering every hidden dialog line and reaction. When they say you can combine everything with everything, they mean it. Every item can be used on every piece of background and every other item. Pog jokes abound, and there's a shocking amount of story you can discover just by poking around and trying things. 


tl;dr:
If you just want puzzles and nothing else, Hiveswap is not for you. If you want to explore a beautifully drawn and written story with some puzzles and gameplay on top, Hiveswap is a great game. Homestuck not required.

Puede que llegue con cinco años de retraso, pero el primer acto de Hiveswap sabe como encandilar al jugador en su mundo, ya sea un recién llegado a la franquicia o un veterano de guer... digo, de Homestuck, el webcómic en el que se basa este juego por episodios.

No es necesario tener ningún conocimiento previo de la otra obra del autor para disfrutar de este juego en su plenitud, lo único que te perderías serían pequeños guiños que aluden y enriquecen la historia original. Todo lo demás es perfectamente autocontenido.

El juego es un point-and-click al uso. Toca cosas para investigar más sobre ellas, usa o combina tus objetos para salir adelante y habla con varios personajes para estar más al tanto de tu situación. Dos cosas caracterizaban a los point-and-click de antaño: su sentido del humor y que los puzles en sí eran rebuscadísimos. Afortunadamente, el humor de este juego, sin ser del mismo palo que de Homestuck, no deja de ser variado y ocurrente. Del mismo modo, los puzles son bastante evidentes y es bastante difícil quedarse atascado. Puede que demasiado fáciles, algo que me gustaría ver enmendado en futuros actos.

Hay diálogo y texto narrativo para rato (unas 150.000 palabras) y hay respuesta para todo tipo de situaciones, algunas de ellas con logro incluido, por lo que se fomenta mucho la rejugabilidad para volver a ver escenas antiguas con otro giro de tuerca.

Un punto negativo es que el juego no está traducido al español aún, y el nivel de inglés que se requiere para entrar en materia es, como muy poco, intermedio. Dicho esto, los fans de Homestuck de habla hispana no son pocos, y es posible que en un futuro se habilite una versión al español para mayor disfrute de estos. No tiene nada que ver que sea el propio traductor quien lo diga, EJEM.

En cualquier caso, juego recomendadísimo, ya sea para entrar en el mundo o para conocer la historia de Joey Claire... una gran mujer. ;)

35030245.review:
This game is incredible, though a bit short.

This game is also incredibly beautiful. The drawings of characters , backgrounds, monsters and the super fluid, beautiful animation - just about everything looks fantastic. And the art style it all combines into ends up being one of my favorite in a video game - ever. 

Then there's the music which is also incredible and fantastic. Composed by Toby Fox and James Roach from the homestuck team (one of which also made the game and music of Undertale, which has one of my favorite video game soundtracks) the music fits every scene perfectly and has a very unique aesthetic. From big haunting melodies to quirky little songs based on short samples it all just fits and just pleases my ears to an orgasmic level.

The gameplay of this game definitely isn't for everybody. It's mostly just point and click (except for the snake puzzles) and is based on solving puzzles. The puzzles are kind of inconsistent. While some feel very well thought out and fun to solve, some of them feel very off and in some cases plain unnessecary. 
For the gameplay you walk around areas clicking on everything to get information and dialouge (more on that in a second) and find items that you will have to use and combine in different situations and with different objects to progress. There's also a couple of battle sequences against monsters. The battle sequences will initially just look like it's a turn based battle, but the battles are also just puzzles (but with some rad exciting music and cool looking monsters). You can't just beat the monsters to a pulp (cause you're just a kid) so you have to use imaggination and find another way.
Personally I love the gameplay to bits but as I said, it definitely isn't for everyone. There's a LOT of reading, which is what brings life and character to the game, but if you have a short attention span or just hate reading this probably isn't for you.

Speaking about reading, what you'll be reading are mostly descriptions, Joey Claire's (main character) thoughts, dialouge and chatlogs. All of which have freaking fantastic writing. I cannot stress enough how important the writing in character/story based games is. The writing is usually one of the defining factors for me in how immersed I am. And this game just nails the kind of geek dialouge and writing that actually exist. Sometimes games will come off as if it was a 50 year old bussiness man in a suit writing what he thinks kids say and how they talk without any help from anyone else and the whole thing just ends up feeling completely disconnected from the world. But this game just nails the great nerd speak, webhumor, references to both homestuck and other work, and you know, everything that you've come to expect from the writer of homestuck. Amazing writing, major props to Andrew Hussie for pulling this off so excellently.

The detail in the game is also extremely high and something I kept noticing. They have written extreme amounts of text responding to almost everything you do. You'l have about ten items in your inventory that you can click and use on pretty much anything in the game. Depending on what item you use and what you use it on you will pretty much always get unique dialouge written just for that action and I can't imagine how much time they must've spent on writing that. Sometimes they even make it so if you do the same obscure action that has no impact on the story or progression over and over again the dialouge/text will continue to change and sometimes mock the player.
I just really love this stuff okay?

I haven't talked much about the story since you get a brief description of it on the steam page and I feel that it is meaningless to talk much about in a review except for saying that it's good or it's bad. This story is good. A lot of plotholes as of now (there's more to come obviously, the story isn't finished yet) but it is very good and interesting.

One thing I have to point out is kind of weird and cluncky is the map layout. The perspective often changes violently when you walk into a new room and you're sometimes left wondering where you came from.

That's  a summary of my most important thoughts that bumbled around my head while watching the credits. If you enjoy good writing, music and art style, get this game, or you'll be missing out. If you enjoy the game you should probably also read homestuck, though it might be intimidating seeing the incredible length. The length does make for very deep character development and such though.

35030019.review:
Now that the release of HIVESWAP: ACT 1 has come and gone, and now that I have received all the achievements I can get, it's time to input my review on this game.

[h1] STORY: 9.5/10 [/h1]
Now listen, I'm a sucker for a game with a great story. And HIVESWAP certainly delivered. There's clearly more coming, since we were left with that huge cliffhanger. And being a fan of Homestuck, with its contrived plot twists and wild and wacky storytelling, I was certainly impressed by the amount of character developement and craft that WhatPumpkin packed into the game!

[h1] GRAPHICS: 9/10 [/h1]
The game looks gorgeous, straight out of a storybook. First we were promised a 3D adventure game, but we came out with a 2D point and click genre game, and I couldn't have been more pleasantly surprised by the smooth cutscenes, animations, and detailed backgrounds. It's like if you took a Humongous Entertainment game and gave it a huge texture revamp. I love it.

[h1] GAMEPLAY: 8/10 [/h1]
I hope you're not expecting too much out of gameplay. It's solid point and click. [spoiler] There is a part of the game once you get to Xefros' hive that you play a short minigame that you use the arrow keys for. It's Snake. But besides that? All point and click. [/spoiler] That doesn't mean the gameplay is boring. Just basic.

[h1] (RE)PLAYABILITY: 7/10 [/h1]
If you're a puzzle expert or are using a tutorial, odds are you'll finish the game with the basic story-driven achievements in under 2 hours. If you want all the achivements, including the hidden ones, well, probably another 2 hours. There isn't much to replay the game for. Unless you want to use the spice on every object and record what it does. In which case... probably more.

[h1] OVERALL: 8.5/10 [/h1]
I have to say, yet again, I'm impressed. After The Odd Gentlemen took all the Kickstarter money and made their own game, I thought HIVESWAP was a goner. Then, WhatPumpkin turned into a game making studio, and saved the day! Through blood, sweat, tears, and weird alien liquids, this game finally came out. Any fan following this game early on might be disappointed -- not me. I wished for a bit more playing time, maybe a bit more on the mysterious Tetrarch Dammek, or some on Jude. But I'm sure we'll see that in Hauntswitch... when it comes out in four years!

Honestly, I was so terrified going into this if it was going to be good or not. But I'm glad to say my fears were put to rest. Hiveswap isn't the greatest most wonderful game. But it's a pleasant jump into the world that I'd missed and with new characters who are very compelling and a treat to watch and learn about. If you're a Homstuck fan, this is a must buy as it unfolds a totally hidden portion of the continuity that, I beleive, most of us completly missed and has all the trappings of what we expect from homestuck. For newcomers this is a great stand alone treat that, while some refrences and jokes may fly over your head, it is deffinetly not required to know anything about the series, in fact, this could be a more pallatable way to dip your toes into HS without fearing for drowning in the chaos.

Gameplay wise it's a basic point and click adventure and it's engaging and fun enough, if you enjoy such games. There is combat, though, not traditional combat, but more puzzle solving combat but it's not a big focus of the game but it's very welcome. The puzzles aren't all to difficult and only really got stuck once but they're fun and not too easy enough that it's engaging. I would also be remise if I didn't mention the music which is such an integral part of Homestuck that I'd have been so destraught if Toby Fox hadn't graced us with his talents again also a composer who's name, I'm sorry, I unfortunatly can't recall. I had only a few bugs mostly with framerate but wasn't really breaking. Only one during the first strife that made it so I had to restart it.

All in all a nice romp in a familiar but new setting and people with a story that grabbed me and by the end made me beg for more. Reccomened if you love Homestuck or Point-and-Clicks or if you want to get into either. 8/10

35023837.review:
Well, it's finally here. This game has been through STUFF, alright. Alleged theft of kickstarter money. Overestimated budgets. Development of this game was restarted twice. It took, what, four years or something for this thing to release? Point is: I've been wanting to play this game for a long time. One question remains, though: Does it hold up to half an eternity of being hyped up as "The Homestuck Game"?

Let's look at the facts. Or the opinions, I guess.

PRESENTATION: 4.5/5

The game is beautiful, both visually and acoustically. Though much of the soundtrack isn't usually the kind of music I personally enjoy, the game was definitely pleasing to look at and listen to throughout. Not much else to say on the matter. I'm not really a stickler when it comes to presentation, but I can see that HIveswap's Music and Art team did their best, which is definitely enough in my book.

STORY, WRITING, CHARACTERS: 5/5

If there's one thing people should read Homestuck for, it's probably the music I mean come on the music's great go listen to it right now. But if there's TWO things, the second one is definitely the characters. Hiveswap, in my opinion, lives up to its legacy here. Which is fascinating, because there's really only a handful of characters in Act 1!

As for the writing, there are lots of great jokes in Hiveswap. If you're going to play it for that, though, remember to combine all of the things, as this is where most of the humor is stashed away.

GAMEPLAY: 1/5

Look, I'll be honest: Hiveswap is easily one of the worst Point and Clicks I've ever played, gameplay-wise. This is mainly due to one thing: Lack of Difficulty.

The game is super easy. Some What Pumpkin employees must've thought they were making a modern FPS, because this game has so much handholding it's not even funny. Here's a little taste of what awaits you in Act 1: Throughout the entire game, you are required to combine items in your inventory ONCE. There's dozens of situations where just LOOKING at a problem tells you how to solve it.

If a What Pumpkin employee reads this (which is highly unlikely, but still), PLEASE, for the love of gog, MAKE ACT 2 MORE DIFFICULT. This is embarassing.

Also, make it longer. You can beat the game within two hours, even if you don't know what you're doing.

These issues go hand-in-hand, and they both seriously need fixing.

OVERALL: 3.5/5 Hats, to keep it real

Despite all my nagging about the lack of difficulty, I still thoroughly enjoyed Act 1 of Hiveswap. In spite of all its gameplay-focused shortcomings, I don't think gameplay is what most people want from this game. But as for me, I just... I really, REALLY want Act 2 to be enjoyable by a wider audience.

If you're a fan of Homestuck, it's a must-have. If you want an extremely short and easy, but cleverly written game, the game is also recommendable.

But if you're looking for a Point and Click Adventure where this cleverness extends to the gameplay as well? Hiveswap Act 1 is just not for you. Go read Problem Sleuth instead.

Finally I just want to say that the artists did a great job! There is so much detail in all of the areas to explore. I give HIVESWAP: Act 1 a 9/10 since I only wish that it were slightly longer.

You will not understand lot of references unless you read comic.

Sometimes you might get stuck with a puzzle, and tips won't really help you figure out how to get unstuck. about 50% of times when I got stuck the solution turned out to be inspecting everything in sight. There is also thing with flashlight batteries, where just stupid amount of people get stuck on obvious puzzle, just becouse the place on a certain thing didn't look like something you can interact with. [spoiler]The goddemn radio battery socket.[/spoiler]

I really, really disliked the snake puzzle. I just felt bit slaped on the face when i saw that after having a budget of 2,5 milions to create this game they decided to put in for some reason just snake minigame instead of actual puzzle. Shame. But then again it's probably just me complaining. But it really did feel like the weakest and most unnecessary puzzle in game.


To finish this up my honest thought and opinion. Game took way tolong to make and feels like it should be at least half longer considering time and budget. It felt like it ended where it should really start but that's ok since next acts are on the way and at least it didn't end with a clifhanger. Which really brings me a relieve since we have no idea when 2nd act is coming out. Overall game felt more like a demo of a game than actual act.1. Although to be fair it felt like really well made, advanced and prepared demo. Game does certainly have potential as a series, and biggest problem I had with the game was the fact that it ended a little bit too quickly. First achivment you get in game pretty much foreshadows that.

Overall good game, but next acts need to be kinda longer to justify the price/wait. If you like adventure/puzzle games you will probably have a lot of fun ignoring the length. If you are Homestuck you probably already bought it.

I give Hiveswap with a honesty a 413/720 which is around 7/10. It's well made, but ends way too soon. I look forward to next acts, and I hope some things will be improved.

35023051.review:
I funded this game (Senator Lemonsnout is sitting on the shelf right behind me) 5 years ago, and given the horrors Andrew Hussie has gone through trying to get it made (being outright conned and robbed from by one studio, and dumping another before making his own from scratch), I had long written off it ever being completed. Glad to be wrong!


I am SO glad that he went with 2D instead of 3D. The artwork is super-saturated and gorgeous, there's a huge number of text slapbacks to "squawk like an imbecile and shit on your desk" attempted shenanigans, and practically every pixel is flooded with homestuck lore, there for fans (like figuring out that Joey's babysitter is Rose's mom as a teenager) but not needing explanation to enjoy the game. 

There are some visual glitches that need fixing (sometimes cutscenes misfire), and I think it should be slightly more obvious where exits are (and some more care should have been taken to maintain room orientations, at least as you enter and exit). The biggest problem is that it's TOO SHORT. I am going to play it again to overdose on interactions, but even doing a bunch already, it took less than 4 hours to finish, and I didn't feel like I was rushing (I was enjoying myself too much).


Hopefully the game does well and he makes more chapters. At least he's got the framework for the game done this time, so it's mostly going to be content development.

35018299.review:
Yeah, okay, sure you're a Homestuck fan. So am I. But I actually know what I'm talking about and enjoyed both Homestuck and Hiveswap: Act 1.

After developement hell, this game finally gets released. My review will be more based on the game itself and less about what people hoped it would be.

Hiveswap: Act 1 is the first of 4 episodic Point and Click adventures and is supposed to set the tone for the rest of the series. Besides a few visual glitches and some spelling errors, it's done it's job at introducing characters and setting up the story for the other 3 acts. Visually, the backgrounds look amazing, the animation flips from fluid to choppy, and mechanically, there isn't a puzzle too hard to figure out with all of the visual cues you're given. A new feature packed along with the game is the dialog response for each combonation of "inventory item X item/environment". No longer will you get the same old "You can't do that." over and over. Each interaction has something different to say, and can encourage the player to try to combine everything out of curiosity. The soundtrack is composed from James Roach and Toby Fox, both of which are very talented musicians. If you get the chance, you should buy the sound tracks for each act. You're bound to fall in love with at least one song. (Also, I don't believe "The Grubbles" have had a chance to play yet, and the two songs released are pretty damn good as well. So hang on to your underwear when they finally make their debut.)

Now onto the Homestuck Perspective Review.

LOTS of references to Homestuck. Being based in the same universe, it's really unavoidable. For anybody who's kept up with the story, you're going to be combing through this game with a super secret cypher thats not easily obtainable. Plenty of stuff will already be common sense to big fans of the series, while everyone else will be just as clueless as Joey Claire. And for those that are wondering what is up with the combat system, it's modeled after some of the early Homestuck flash fights. If it doesn't make sense, it's not supposed to. It's purely cosmetic.

With the tone set, Act 2 is going to deliver just as well, if not better. Let's just hope it delivers on time!

I was like, what?
So to sum it up, this game is a point-and-click mystery adventure game circled around the main female protagonist, occasionally hopping to the side characters' POVs to help MC get to the objective.

35017630.review:
Hiveswap: Act 1 was an absolutely fantastic starting point for the new series.

If you enjoyed Homestuck immensely, wished to play a Homestuck style game based upon the format the webcomic was in, or just wanted more out of Andrew Hussie, Homestuck, and MSPA Adventures, this is absolutely the game for you.

The game is moderately short, I beat it in 2 hours and 13 minutes, and its generally a Point-and-Click game with a set storyline.  The style however very clearly shouts Homestuck, with the visuals and all references to pop culture still prevalent, and a few puzzles, minigames, and even Strife sequences to play in.

Overall, I was definitely happy with Hiveswap, and I'm looking forward to Act 2 and the rest!

Had a really good time with this! 

I'm a big fan of the classic adventure games that Homestuck was sort-of-emulating, sort-of-parodying, and it's cool to see the creator of that return to the genre more sincerely. The puzzles all flow from the plot, and while they're never too difficult in the long run, a few of them did stump me momentarily, which really is just about exactly the difficulty curve I want from a game like this.

It made me laugh and get excited, and trying all the possible combinations between items was a fun side game. Hype for more, but I wish there had been an hour or so more gameplay on this Act.

Possibly the only downside to it is its a little short, it's only about a couple hours or so (more if you love to read the flavor text, but if you've read Homestuck that's about 85% of the comic anyway), but that's to be expected with chapter games--the first chapter of Tales From The Borderlands was shorter than Hiveswap Act 1--and this is supposed to have a whopping 7 *more* Acts. Plus a sequel?? Or maybe they'll just split up the Acts between 2 games..

Either way, it's gorgeous, funny, has awesome music and tons of Homestuck easter eggs (of course); really worth the wait considering all the trouble Hussie and the WhatPumpkin? development team had to go through to get this game made. Absolutely fantastic.


**And like other reviewers have been saying, you don't even need to know that much about Homestuck to get into it. You like old style point and click adventure games with aliens, charming sibling banter, possible world threatening scenarios and weirdly absent parental figures? Totally a game you should check out.

35016041.review:
I'd like to start this by saying I don't write many reviews. It's not that I don't think I can, and it's not because I don't think other games deserve them. There are a lot of games that deserves much praise and admiration. However, when this game strikes a special cord for me.

[b]The bad:[/b]

It's a relatively short game. Don't go into this expecting ten hours of entertainment. This is just one part of a larger whole.

It's on tracks, this is not a choose your own adventure game. It's a story-telling narrative.

As stated before, this is just part one. Part one took a very long time to come out. I can't say when the next part will be out, and you might want to save playing this until all the pieces are released.


[b]The Good:[/b]

It does it's job fantastically. It tells a story, gets you interested in the quirks of the characters. It flows smoothly from one point to the next in that style Hussie became famous for.

Though the game itself is linear, the things you can discover are so vast that in this short game you can and will spend more time reading about wall posters than advancing the plot.

Almost true to the description, there are very few generic 'combinations' in the game. Almost everything you can use on something else gets its own unique flavor, even if it doesn't work or do anything special. The few times that something lacks interaction or has a generic default are far between, and hardly immersion breaking. I was never quite left with the feeling of "I have an axe, but I need a hammer to get past this wood because it has nails." that you might get in older point and clicks.

Last but certainly not least it's beautiful. The work put into the assets and the way everything is composed is both beautiful and true to the original Homestuck style.


[b]In summary:[/b]

I'm happy with the end result, even if it took a very long time to get here. Now I'm just waiting eagerly for part 2.

35015492.review:
So I am sitting here trying to decide how to explain myself. I am here sitting at 2.7 hours of gameplay time on september 17th 2017, a few days after this games release, that is the amount of time it took for me to beat this game with getting stuck on maybe two (in my opinion) poorly telegraphed puzzles. Hint: You have to pull the deers horn. There is a red panel beside the bedroom door you came from. And frankly I don't think the game should have released in this state.

Though let's get something straight, it breaks my heart to do this, look at my icon, it's a goddamn fantroll so you know I want to reccommend this but I simply will not reccommend this until it's cleaned up. Even sadder is my expectations weren't even that high for this, I wasn't expecting much more than a simple, fun adventure game that probably had great music and what I got was a simple adventure game with a bunch of excess mechanics shoe-horned into the first chapter where they're not usable and a bunch of puzzle pieces that I am not allowed to fit together yet...with great music ... sure can't wait to wait another 10 months to see what happens with Jude and Dammek though.

FOR A NOT HOMESTUCK:
Pros:
+Incredibly adorable, if you're one of those people who can live off a game by how cute the characters are, then you can go ahead and stop reading here.
+Art is perty
+Humor is fairly on point, it won't really miss any beats
+Music is lovely
+If you're worried about having to have read homestuck to understand this game, don't worry it does an okay(?) job of keying you into the lingo slowly
+ I N T R I G U I N G L E V E L O F M Y S T E R Y

Cons:
+Some poorly telegraphed puzzles
+They don't even really try to give you an illusion of choice, mistakes you make are forgiven instantly to make room for a sloppy combat system and a linear narrative that they give you dialogue options for - for what I can only see as no reason- nothing you say or do can change anything and yet they still give you choices to do things for cheap 'interaction'
+AN ENTIRE SERIES OF PUZZLE PIECES THAT YOU GO THE WHOLE GAME WITHOUT USING. People are going to say "oh but this is chapter one, they'll probably use them later."- and I retort with, I don't care. If they are going to release this product as is then I am going to judge it as is.
+A completely pointless combat system that is basically a glorified puzzle (Though it wastes more time than any of the puzzles would)
+The game leans almost a bit too much on the text logs, and more to the point this entire first act is basically doing the housework to move you up to speed with the lingo, but since it has to do that your overall experience will suffer for it unless you're super into these characters
+You might find 1/3 of the characters annoying. Oh wait there's only 3 characters.
+Short play time. 3 hours. Act one. At the time of writing there is absolutely no scheduled release date for act two on a game five years in development and 3 years past initial scheduled release with vague development timelines leading up to this.
+A character switching mechanic that never gets used
+Spelling errors

FOR HOMESTUCKS:
Pros:
+All Pros mentioned above
+Joey is Cute
+Jude is Cute
+Xanax or whatever his name was is adorable
+References I guess...

Cons:
+All Cons stated above
+No Trickster Mode??
+Regurgitation of the same troll-lore exposition that you already know backwards and forwards
+Jake is an asshole (Honestly this isn't a real con I just thought I'd toss this in, in case you liked Jake English and weren't prepared to have him be a willfully estranged father to two angel children.)
+Literally nothing new to anything you already knew besides 3 new characters
+I cannot overstate how dissapointing the combat system is

All I can really hope is that the next three sections they take the few criticisms they get to heart (because love is blind, and so is fandom) and make chapter two at least worthwhile for the 2 and a half hours it'll take to beat that. Also ADD TRICKSTER MODE.

I feel however, as some things can be improved, such as improving the amount of RAM the game takes up, and me, with my crappy 2GB of RAM can definitely testify: DO NOT TAKE THE RECCOMENDED AMOUNT OF RAM LIGHTLY! 35014278.review:
This game! 5 years in the making and it really does show just how much thought and love was put into it. The visuals are nothing short of gorgeous. I love how crazy detailed everything is! And there's so many 90's references. I enjoyed looking at everything and reading all of Joey's commentary on her surroundings and some of the "failure" combinations. You get a great sense of Joey's character, as well as her brother's and our two troll friends just by looking around a little. 

As for the story itself, the game does a great job establishing Alternia and it's troubles, and I suspect we'll be finding out more about what all is plaguing Earth in a later act. I'm definetly hooked and I can't wait for the next act to come out! Honestly, the only real downside I saw to this game is how short the act was! It only took me about 2.5 hours to complete, and I'd say I did a fair bit of exploring and combining. 

Lastly, the music was absolutely fantastic and I am very glad I chose the bundle with the soundtrack way back when I backed this game on Kickstarter. 

So, uhm, yeah. Overall this game is great aside from being brief, though I am sure the time will stack up as more acts are released. Gorgeous art, gorgeous music, chuckleworthy dialouge that has come to be expected of Homestuck, and an interesting plot that begs to continue! 10/10 do love, thank you our lord Hussie

35013900.review:
I'm torn on this one.

I really really REALLY want to love the game, but in the current way I can't recommend it to anyone.
Would I really care about it if I would not be familiar with homestuck fandom? I doubt it.

It lacks the substance, lacks the proper character development and generally lacks the charm that homestuck had.
I'm not saying it is bad, it is just not what I expected. Worst, it reminds me of exactly the same problems that Armikrog had.

PROS:

Yes, it is really, really well drawn.

CONS:

1. First of all, it feels dated and unfinished. The game was in production for 5 years and you can feel it. Manual save system for 2h game looks archaic. Menu elements looks half-assed. The game is buggy. It's rough around the edges. Art quality is inconsistent.

Map layout is bizzare. A lot of game elements can be accessed from a very specific angle even if they visible on other screens. For example, in the 2nd act security terminal is visible but you can't access it *UNLESS* you realize that you have to change the view.

There is an option to swap characters, but there is no gameplay mechanic to utilize it. Why is it there? 
Combat/ability system looks unfinished. Once again, it feels like a forced addition that can be entirely cut from the game or be replaced by the scripted scene. I can't exactly say what feels wrong about it, but it feels wrong. Also, those abilities can be probably used, like, two times in the entire game? Why coudn't they just add another option to the popup menu and call it a day?

Those are minor complaints, but they are important, because they form the overall game impression, and generally break immersion for me.

2. It has a soul but it has *WRONG* soul.

The broad appeal and the art direction they took is understandable, but in my opinion it is detrimental to the game.
In Homestuck art always feels second to the content, and the whole aim of the narrative was to create this bizzare "meta" atmosphere.

I don't see it in the game. They tried to make classic golden age adventure with a team and creative lead who does not have experience in this field. As a result we have a game that has all of the weaknesses of the genre and none of the strengths of the Hussie. It is an attempt to play on the foreign field and I don't see the reason behind it.

Why creating another beautiful but mediocre adventure game? There are plenty of them, and it is very difficult to compete with them having such a small team. The game does not try bring anything new or try to achive anything notable rather than being very ambitious but very minor omage to the niche webcomic.

35012063.review:
[h1]來自過去的新的開始[/h1]
 作為一個Homstuck的粉絲，HIVESWAP：Act1的釋出令我雀躍不已[strike]噢天！幾年又算什麼呢[/strike]
遊戲一釋出馬上下載、犧牲睡眠完成了一周目[strike]離猝死又近了一步！thanks HS![/strike]

感想是非常、非常的感動。
對我來說，不單是劇情、甚至是系統、音樂等等整個遊戲讓我彷彿回到了當年閱讀Homestuck的時光
Homestuck式的幽默以及對人物深刻的刻畫，還有音樂/畫面，再次感受到為何我喜歡這部作品！
作為粉絲來說值回票價
讓我想起以前跟隨孩子們冒險的時光
現在這段發生在過去的新的冒險開始了，
因為是4部曲因此act1劇情也留下了不少懸念。非常期待接下來的發展


[b]劇情與系統：[/b]
對Homestuck不了解的人們也不要緊，
從角色口中已經解釋了不少世界觀、相信你會對獨特的世界觀著迷的X:）！
解謎卡關時建議多點周圍的東西（或者用東西點周圍的東西）

[b]通關時間與成就：[/b]
自己的遊玩時間大概大約3.8小時左右
但當你發現所有東西都可以點在所有東西上調查：[i][嘿如果我試著都點一次呢？][/i]
…………恭喜你來到地獄模式
我就是那一位挑戰者之一（…………）
但實話說，從點擊調查各種東西中能更了解人物/劇情/世界觀
還有成就[spoiler]很多得需要你仔細的點擊/調查各種東西[/spoiler]，普通通關時取得的成就大約是20多左右

[b]音樂：[/b]

在運行一周目時窗口化出現畫面出格的問題，不過二週目時（更新後）就沒再發生了

[b]一些對劇情的感想和解釋：[/b]

[list]
[*][spoiler]一些數字組在hs作品裡通常有著重要的信息：本作發生於11月11日，當joey宅停電時鐘錶停在11點11分；遊戲團隊本來打算在太平洋11：11發布遊戲[，這個數字很有可能在接下來的續集中繼續出現/spoiler]

[*][spoiler]傳家寶/傳送門的來源完全是謎。但關於joey取得傳家寶的途徑，其實joey媽並沒有親手交給她，而是她自己從珠寶盒拿的……而且也可以發現傳家寶有一種洗腦的感覺……可怕[/spoiler]

[*][spoiler]dammek的地下室屏幕地圖比照發現，爺爺的trophy room裡的其實是alternia的星球儀……同樣得閣樓上的海量球儀也是[/spoiler]
[*][spoiler]目前知道xef跟demm在鬧革命，結尾xef指出他們現在要去見他們革命的粉絲，不知道是哪一位呢》（有可能是之前流出圖的海居民troll）[/spoiler]
[*][spoiler]可以看出來joey和xefros都有缺乏自信的問題，xefros先不說，joey說她自己以為pa不回家也是因為她的問題……aw[/spoiler]
[*][spoiler]對jude印像比較深的除了鴿子命案【rip】之外，joey在進入閣樓後他極力阻止joey去靠近傳送門，甚至不用他平時高深的專業用語普通的懇求，看得出jude真的很擔心她。有點感動[/spoiler]
[*][spoiler]Byers太強了[/spoiler]

[*][spoiler]arena stickball應該是根據homestuck的felt成員的球類遊戲。老實說聽起來就很危險，擔心xefros[/spoiler]
[*][spoiler]這次的事件可能和白球的計劃有關係……？[/spoiler]

35011901.review:
***This is a spoiler-free review!***

I wish there was an option between "yes" and "no" for recommending a game on here. Because my response varies based on what you're wanting this game for.

Do you like Homestuck and want to get a little more into what kind of place Alternia was, and have a good chuckle every now and again? Then yes, I recommend it.

But as a point and click game, regardless of what franchise it's tied to, I can't in good conscience recommend it as-is.

My favorite part of P&C games is the puzzles. Even when I don't get them myself, I like seeing how clever they are in the end. But a lot of the puzzles in Hiveswap that stumped me wound up having really bizarre and illogical solutions. A lot of parts felt really over-written, and that in the process of trying to cram as many jokes in as they could, they also put in far too many red herrings that then became more frustrating than funny. On the flip side, some of the puzzles seemed like they could have had a little more player involvement, but were largely just handed to you.

 There's also a particular minigame that I wasn't a fan of that was required for you to proceed, that required you to look in multiple places on the screen at once. It wasn't that difficult conceptually, but the execution wasn't great.

The UI could have used a little work, it wasn't entirely intuitive and there was no real guide to how to use some of the buttons. There are also a lot of typos in the dialog, as well as a lot of very blatant bugs. More than once, a button would come up, giving me a dialog option, but it would be completely cut off.

These issues would be a lot more forgiveable if this was an early access game, and if it hadn't taken as many years as it did to be released. I understand that there is some unofficial banter about monetary issues, but given that I've heard competing rumors, I can't really take that into account. Still, money issues aside, I don't think it would have been particularly hard to at least run a spell check on your dialog.

That said, the characters are cute, and while the story is a little slow to get going, once it does it's pretty fun. I imagine it will feel a little more fleshed out when there's more actual game to play. The art is, of course, lovely and the colors are vibrant, while the world is well-populated and lived in.

So if you want to learn more about trolls, this is the game for you. But if you only want to play a good point and click game, I'd wait until they release a patch or two.

As someone who read through Homestuck back in the day, being able to play this game brought back a lot of the pleasant feelings of fun and intrigue that Homestuck always gave me. 
I enjoyed the game, and don't really have anything negative to say about it. If you were someone involved with Homestuck in the past, this game was probably enjoyable for you too. 
I was a little concerned with trailers before, seeing that some of the animation is a little choppy when the characters are doing actions or idle, etc. but after playing the game and seeing it all first hand, it really isn't a big deal. It actually, in part, makes it feel more like Homestuck some how.
The artwork is all beautiful, the cutscenes are awesome, the music is perfect, and the story is interesting so far! I'm really loving that we get to look more into the culture on Alternia too. It was a cool look into a modern town/area that you can't really see anywhere else! It was great!
Everyone did a great job with this game, and I can't wait for an Act 2 some day. Thanks to the whole team that worked so hard on this experience!

Besides, at least the parts of the screen you have to click on make sense. I found a bug towards the end game, where it wouldn't let me [spoiler]grab the sloth treats[/spoiler], but exiting and reentering the room fixed it. The strife system takes a bit to get used to, and some of the fights are non-specific as to whether you need to grab something in the background or not, but once you figure out the puzzle you need to solve to win the fight, the animations are clean and fun. I'll be interested to see where the further acts go, and I hope the wait for them isn't another few years.

Bom, eu acho justo falar sobre o jogo em topico, então:

Prós:
-Bela arte (Tanto de fundo, quanto dos personagens, alias, recomendo fazerem wallpapers com algumas cenas)
-Historia interessante (Digo isso tendo já terminado todos os atos de homestuck)
-Diversas opcoes de interacão (Todos os itens interagem com todos os itens, isso realmente é louvavel)
-Baixo custo? (Ok, eu sei que 16 reais por episodio pode parecer muito, mas se tu vender as cartinhas, cai pra menos da metade)

Contras
-Muitos bugs (Isso é inevitavel, porem esse jogo é realmente bugado, porem, nada que me impessa de jogar)
-Baixa taixa de quadros (Eu não sei se isso foi de proposito, mas nao posso deixar de dizer que me incomoda, fazendo o jogo parecer travado)
-Uma só lingua (Ok, admito, meu ingles não é dos melhores, mas isso não quer dizer que a opcão espanhol (que foi prometida) não deveria estar inclusa no ato 1
-Inventario (Eu realmente pensei que cada personagem possuia um sylladex diferente entre si, isso me decepcionou muito)
-Batalhas um pouco intediantes (Eu acho que elas poderiam ter sido melhor trabalhadas, mas ainda assim, eu diria que esta aceitavel)


Nota final: 7/10

O jogo não é perfeito, mas não é uma coisa que eu diria ''Terrivel, quero meu dinheiro já'', acredito que o jogo vai ser melhorado com o tempo e que  o jogo tem muito a oferecer. Para os não fãs de homestuck, eu daria um 5/10, pois quem não entende o contexto, concordo que achariam o jogo pouco atrativo.

35009651.review:
So, here's a review from someone who technically skimmed through most giant texts in homestuck and enjoyed the first Act better than the others starting with when we started following the trolls, noticed i say I like it better, dosen't mean I dislike it, very different things, anyways, starting with the quick version : 

+ Pretty good visual, music, despite me reading that some peeps had problem runnin' it, i haven't had any issue at all.
+ Quirkly well written, ignore the confusing names, they're just a joke most of the times.
+ Not old king's quest level of ''ey kiddo, forgot something back there? start again you dumb f###''
+- For me it isn't that big of a deal, but it's rather short, a lot of quality, but i clocked 3 hours, prolly 4 after the achievement hunting, which are fun in this, unlike in some games where it is ''finish the game on extra hard where if you step on the floor too hard you blow up in pieces I'M LOOKING AT YOU EVIL WITHIN YOU MOTHERFU---''
 - Pigeon Betrayal and Violence.
 - Not enough of the Heiress, but enough to base fanart on, i like fish ladies, any problem with it? hu? you talkin' to me sod?
 - For reals tho', there's way less things to examine than expected, for the amount of clutter, also, maybe a Encyclopedia function? where you can read what every new world or item you find is? i mean, yeah most people won't read it, but yo Hussie if you think your fans ain't gonna spend 10 hours reading everything about whatever weird troll things they find, well, you really don't know them.
 - Gotta wait for the next Act, feels...familiar, the feeling of emptyness and wanting more, nostalgic even, in a bad way.

This is very much a story in the same world, yes, and, for most of the part, it's quite stand alone, there's many nods, and many things aren't explained but the core is just new kids and new trolls, so it's...easier-ish for someone who never touched that crazy comic to just play it.

That said, there is so many things unexplained but i guess, and i guess if you read the comic you'd be like ''oh yeah, SCUMARCHFLOOPYWWEIRDWORLD totally know that'' , tho' most of those are just quirky silly names, but yeah, we're again in control of kids that serve as our views, and most of the nescessary things are explained well enough and fast enough to not annoy old fans, or alienate newer ones.

The art is amazing, visually and musically it's outstanding and hey, it's made on Unity, which despite it's bad press due to its moronic ''Free stuff you gotta have our logo, and that logo goes on shitty games cause of course clueless dummies won't buy it, so basically in good games that uses your engine, no one would find that they are using said engine cause they bought it, should be the opposite, do you get what i'm saying? why you reading this? go play the game DA''.

Lenghtwise i've clocked about 3 hours shoving everything into everything cause thats what you do in point n' click games, it's short yeah, but hey, it's one Act, maybe this will have 10 Acts, who knows, even so, it dosen't overstay it's welcome but i see why the riders of the hype would be disapointed, it does leave you wanting more however.

This is kinda of a more focused Homestuck, the texts are more to the point, i mean, Homestuck got carried away so much that i'd just be tired afterwards, and the art style seems to be the perfect evolution of the original comic.

Back to Homestuck Act 1, this reminds me a lot of it, and i enjoyed it, the feeling of discovery and silly puzzles and shenanigans, it's something it was lost after a while, and it's here again, obviously since this is LITERALLY a point n' click game, an obvious one yeah but i have enough nightmares of the old king's quest games, so thanks for not following that hell.

I really look foward to Act 1, and, should you play it? Hrm, maybe? I mean, if you never read the comic you'll be a bit alienated, but not as much as you expect, there's enough explanation to get you to speed, on things that matters that is, so yeah, can't say, it's on you, do what your heart tells you kiddo, my best of luck to ya!

35008903.review:
Good fandoms dont die, they just go godtier. this is Homestuck revival we´ve been waiting for.
Hello random person! Bringie the Knight of Void is here to help you decide whenever or not to give this game a chance.

First important thing: quite obviously, this is a Homestuck inspired game, so there are many great references for Homestuck fans (would feel unfair if there werent since we waited so goddamn long for it.) BUT if you´re not a Homestuck fan, its okay! the game itself does a great job of being indipendent, so there is no required Homestuck knowledge to enjoy it. But if you enjoy the game experience, the mechanics and the storytelling, i´d wholly recommend Homestuck for you: Act 1 is a bit slow, but once you get past it, you´ll discover a rich world full of complex characters and excellent story and humour.  

Now, without futher ado, lets review the heck out of this game.

Lets start with the esthetics and animation. The colors are beautiful, the visuals vibrant, and, should i say, alive. Each character has a set of tiny animation while standing, walking etc. There are animated leaves, moving chains, closing doors, each detail carefully taken into consideration. Fighting sequences are fluid and fun. 

Music created by crazily talented duo of James Roach and Toby Fox (the latter being composer for quite a few Homestuck songs before moving to create his own game, Undertale. Undertale itself is also an excelent game worth checking out once you´re done with Hiveswap). The tracks are lovely and i myself am a happy owner of Hiveswap OST, definitely worth investing in if you´re electric/chiptune/orchesta enthusiastic.

The characters are unique, with their own quirks and interests. You mainly get to play with two out of four characters in this act, so i believe others get their turn in Hauntswitch (Act 2). But even with two characters, you get plenty of fun and experience a lot through them.
 
Game mechanics are simple and easy to use. The essencial of Hiveswap is to click everything, combine everything, and use objects on everything. if not for plot advancement then definitely for hillarious text that always pops up.

Probably the strongest aspect of the game, as mentioned above, is writing. Andrew Hussie has plenty of experience, and knows how to make funny, sad or silly commentary whenever needed. The storytelling is masterful, and i must admit i was close to tears about twice. 

As for negatives (every game has its bugs afterall), my personal problem was with short animated sequences, because they were choppy. But seeing as i have outdated computer with not very strong graphic card or CPU, i say its due to technology i am using, rather than the game itself. 
Another problem with the game is that at perhaps three points, i didnt know what to do. Again, understandable, since this is point-and-click game. You just gotta use your brain (or mouse and desperately click on everything again, like i did :D )
Lastly, the game isnt very long. it took me 5 hours to finish it and get most of achievments (still planning to play it second time to get remaining 5), but you need to remember there is a whole lot more coming. The story had only just begun.

In conlusion, Hiveswap is a tribute to Homestuck fans who will happily get nostalgic over their fandom years, as well as a well-made visual adventure novel for people that want to get into world of mysteries. Go try it on your own, and i believe you wont be disappointed.

I've only read the first few acts of Homestuck (~4-5 years ago), so I'm not exactly a fan and don't remember much aside from a juggalo. So, in terms of understanding the world beforehand I'm just barely familiar.

The game itself is a straightforward point-and-click adventure with a wealth of in-game descriptions. The game consists of solving some puzzles which vary from small games to just clicking on things until you find what you need (that's simplifying it but you really can't miss anything). The descriptions are entertaining, the author put effort into making everything you read worthwhile. The descriptions, as the other reviews can tell you, consist of mostly 90s nostalgia. 

The music is relaxing, old-school in terms of flash games (I think), and "nice" overall. The chapter only lasted me ~2 hours and I searched through everything (only got half the achievements so there are hidden interactions throughout). For $7.99, I think it was worth my time but for others it may end rather abrubtly.

35004625.review:
As a homestuck fan, i will try to give this review with as little bias as possible. I loved it. Here's a spoiler free review:

pros:
* The music is amazing, as excpected from the people at the music team.
* The artstyle is real easy to look at and appreciate.
* The story so far is interesting, taking place somewhere before the begining of the events in Homestuck (haha who am i kidding, pinpointing a beginning on the homestuck timeline is like trying to find the mean between zero and infinity), and the humor is cyoot.
* The gameplay is standard point and click fun, EVERYTHING is interactable with EVERYTHING, so if you're the type of peep who likes his games slow and rich, this can work very well for you. Puzzles are interesting but nothing you cant solve, so it's not gonna be one of those games you need to open the wiki for to search how to progress.
* This game doesn't require any fancy computer parts to run, and it ran smoothly on my potato i3 intel hd graphics 4600 on the highest definition, so if you are low end, you can purchase without fear.

with all that, here are some noticable cons:
* The most noticeble one: it's SHORT. Like, I'm a nerd who likes to use all the interactability and slow down to read in some parts, so I got 6 hours out of this game. But a man who likes his game fast and to the point, and people who just want to get on with the story, will finish it in 3. But you know a game is good when the most noticeable bad thing with it is it being too short. Hopefully the 2nd act comes withing less than a year, but you know how it is with homestuck titles. One can only hope.
* With the intentions of this game to be a complete standalone title and people not needing to read homestuck to enjoy it, you will miss a LOT if you didn't read it. I'm not saying you CAN'T enjoy it without Homestuck; but the first act fails to explain itself many times, if you're new you would miss half the jist. Maybe it's a way for the game to stay mysterious for the second act, but I know it's going to annoy some people.
* The game is simplistic, and can be predictable at some points. If you are searching for hardcore puzzles and mindblowingly complex gameplay, im afraid you wont find it here. The point of the game is to enjoy the feel, story and characters (which are all adorable btw), not to win.
* It had some visual glitches at some points, but that was because I was messing with the screen resolution while tabbing out. Also it had some lag loading certain clips, but nothing to worry about.
* Not even a con, just my petty nitpick: it has nothing to do with Sburb, at least not now. I know it's supposed to be focused on the troll-human relations, switching planets yadda-yadda... But what I personally liked best about Homestuck was Sburb, the concept of a game being connected personaly to you, with kids learning and becoming gods and most importantly: adults. Again, this is just a nitpick and I know it wasn't planned to be connected to Sburb in the first place but... A man can dream right?

I give a score of 7/10, great for me, maybe not much for other people. It's only 8 bucks anyway, you're not risking much by buying it, and I can say with confidence that 3 hours of this 8 buck game is more fun and rich than 1.5 hours for 15+ bucks going to a movie.

In short, I think heavy sums it up accurately:
https://wiki.teamfortress.com/w/images/e/e3/Heavy_goodjob01.wav?t=20110320053516
