35002667.review:
Pretty good game, even if it barely ran on my computer. It was fun, and funny, and even touching at times. Joey is a great portagonist, and I can't wait to see more from her and her friends in Act 2! The soundtrack was good too.

My only complaints are that there is one game-breaking glitch at one point involving a certain tablet disappearing forever if you're not careful, and there are lots of typos and mistakes in the writing. Not enough to ruin the game, but enough to be seriously noticible. Like, seriously guys. You're not writing fanfiction, and you had years to make this. Wasn't there any time to proof read the script? Hope that gets fixed in an upd8.

Still, I highly reccomend the game, and I suggest anyone with an even passing interest pick it up! You will not regret it!

35002604.review:
As a Homestuck fan, I was going to get this regardless but this is honestly just a very well done and fun little game. It's a Point & Click adventure that's beautifully done and well written. Is you don't know the webcomic that won't be an issue as the game generally explains everything with the in-player interactions.

Pros:

-Text for almost every interaction with the scenery and invertory items
   You can honestly use like every item on one object in the background and get interesting text and jokes/puns with very few exceptions. Heck you can even use items on each other which yield some funny results.

-Well written
   From the characters to the descriptions everything feels just well done and authentic. Though it is written in a 2nd-person style which might seem weird at first, you'll get used to it and this style works for the benifit of the game as you get the character's thoughts on whatever you've clicked on.

-This ain't a fairytale
   The trailers and images make it seem like a fun little adventure and it is, but there's themes in this game that are not all sugar and spice. It never gets bloody and nothing really dark happens but these themes add to the characters and makes them and the situations they're in seem real. It also makes you sympathize with them too (if you're worried about the potential themes because of triggers I'll leave a list of them at the end of my review).

-Puzzles
   The puzzles are mostly simple until you get to the battles. Battles in this game aren't really battles but act more like puzzles themselve in order to win which is pretty cool. 

-Music
   This music is very, very good and fits with whatever is going on scene. I'm not really surprized by this because the webcomic always had good music and it's obvious they brought people who contribute to it here on the game like Toby Fox (the man who created Undertale which makes me wonder when this game is going to get it's own version of Megalovania because I want it)

-Cheap
   Honestly I was surprized this game was so cheap but it makes sense since it's a short game, speaking of that...

Cons:

-Short, like, VERY short if speed running
   The game is very short if you just do the puzzles, you could probably beat it in 30 minutes top but that's not what these game are for. You're ment to explore and interact with stuff and that easily adds a few hours onto it. Another issue with the game being so short is that there's only so much plot and in hind sight there's really not a lot as it leaves you wanting more. It honesly only feels like the introduction to the game and then some.

-Character animation (more of a pet peeve)
   This may just be me but when I saw the introduction cutscene and then the animation of the character in the acutally gameplay section I was put off because it wasn't as smooth as I was expecting it to be. It took a minute to get used to but after that it didn't bother me in the slightest, it was just a bit jarring at bit.

The Conclusion:

   Overall, it's a very fun click & point game that is short but is also cheap. If you got the money to spare and you like these type of games even a little bit I'd say get it. There's more to come in the future and if it's anything like the webcomic we'll get up to 6 Acts where Act 6 feels like 5 acts on it's own merit to the point we got acts in Act 6 itself (e.g. Act 6 Act 4, it was very silly with how long Act 6 was getting). Oh and let's not forget the intermissions, there were several of them in the webcomic that would later tie into the main story... 

Homestuck is very confusing and LONG is what I'm getting at....


The End 
(the only thing below this is the list of dark-ish themes of the game which are kind of minor spoilers)




Themes (minor spoilers):
-a father that's never at home to take care of the kids because ADVENTURE
-a long since deceased mother
-an achoholic babysister (who isn't mean or cruel, just irresponsible)
-a dictator
-a revolution against said dictator and government
-a not-so-balance friendship between two characters (one is kind of mean to the other to the point one of them has pretty bad selfconfidence issues but we don't see their interactions in game)

35002275.review:
As someone who has a moderate experience of Hussie's work, "Homestuck", that this game is a derivation of, this is definitely up my alley. It uses the same level of humor and a deep story, but currently has more focus on world building than Homestuck did.

Hiveswap combines  that level of humor and lore of Homestuck with a point and click puzzle adventure game, and comes with a lot of inner monologues and quips for almost every combination of items and objects that you can interact with. You could spend the whole day just doing that. Currently this Act's length is about the same as Homestuck's so you can finish it in one seating if you blaze through it (but why do that in a story driven game?)

Music is made by the same people who did Homestuck's, so expect it to be good. Artstyle is a shift from Homestuck but otherwise still have the same feel (for those who read Homestuck anyway).

10/10 would buy the next Act and Hauntswitch when they eventually release.

Спустя два дня после покупки, я наконец выделила время и запустила игру HIVESWAP: Act 1.
Что меня ожидало? 
Восхищение.
Несмотря на все затруднения при создании данной игры, она получилась замечательно.
Конечно есть некоторые замечания. Во-первых, на мой взгляд игра всё таки ориентированна на аудитори, имеющую представление о фендоме HOMESTUCK. Человеку его не читавшему не будут понятны часть отсылок, шутеек и закономерных событий. Поэтому, конечно, рекомендую HS к прочтению перед тем, как вы сядете за эту игру.
Во-вторых, ... буду лгать, если у меня есть, в чём ещё упрекнуть данную игру.

О плюсах. Очень приятный дизайн. И фоны, и чудовища, и персонажи выглядят очень гармонично. Более того, они милы и приятны (по крайней мере на мой вкус). Кроме того, очень радует соблюдение стилистики хомстака: инвентарь, сумбурное окружение гг и т.д. Особенно хочу отметить восхитительные диалоги. Больше, конечно, понравился разговор тролля с человеком. Интересные характеры, интересный квирк... словом, всё весьма уместно.
Отдельно хочу обратить внимание на лусусов: эти божественные существа покарили моё "вдомезастрявшее" сердечко.
Спасибо Эндрю Хасси и команде. С нетерпением жду продолжения, а то очень уж быстро прошла всё.

P.S: вспоминая, как выходил Homestuck, надеюсь, что игра обойдётся без перерывов и гигапауз ^^

Adorable, entertaining, witty and charming. Not to mention completely, utterly ridiculous. Just what you'd expect from a story set in the Homestuck universe, in other words.

A couple of bugs and spelling errors can be patched and corrected, so I'm not gonna complain about that. My only complaint of any real significance is that the puzzles were never particularly challenging or complex, so it felt a bit more like a visual novel than a true point-and-click adventure game. 34999016.review: It holds up well as a game on it's own, which isn't bad (I love the new characters, settings, etc.), but I was hoping it would tie in a little more with HomeStuck. There were a few easter eggs I noticed, such as the poster for the movie "The Story Keeps Happening" and the default name for the slothbeast being "ZOOSMELL". Don't get me wrong, it's still filled with Andrew Hussie's great sense of humor, but it just seemed to lack the charm of the comic. Visually, however, the game is amazing. It's great to see a new art style, but like I said, it take away from the HomeStuck feel. In my opinion, you shouldn't expect HIVESWAP to be an extension to HomeStuck, but as it's own game, with some "Oh, I recognise that!" moments for the fans. It is fairly short, but the option for combining everything in the game does add some replayability. My original fear was that some big YouTuber would play it and not understand anything, while at the same time giving people a bad impression of HomeStuck, but now I believe it wouldn't be as bad as some people think it would be. I'd reccomend HIVESWAP to fans and non-fans alike.

34996714.review:
If it matters, I've read Homestuck all the way through and I did back this game on Kickstarter.  It's just the first act right now so obviously I can't rate the full game experience, but here's what I can say.

I'm giving Hiveswap a thumbs-up because I enjoyed it, and because I think it (for the most part) succeeds at being what most people expected it to be, but I only "recommend" the game under very specific conditions.  I meet these conditions, but I don't think most people do.

This is a good expansion to the Homestuck universe, sure.  So if you already know you love Homestuck, you probably want to get it.  But, if you already know you love Homestuck, then you already bought this game before reading this review.

The thing is, that's ALL it is.  It's an extension to Homestuck.  If you ignore that part and review it as just a game, it's a pretty bog-standard adventure game in the style of "rub all inventory items on the scenery until something happens".  That part, alone, is not worth the asking price in my opinion.  What IS worth the asking price is if you wanted to see more of the chaotically dense worldbuilding and goofy IM conversations that Homestuck had.

It's not BETTER than Homestuck, though, and while Homestuck is humongous and free, Hiveswap is tiny and costs some amount of money.  Well, Hiveswap is comparatively tiny, anyway--it's a short playthrough from beginning to end of act 1 (2-3 hours), but it's also dense with descriptions of all the stuff in the world you can click on, not to mention unique reactions for attempting to use different items on those same things.  But Homestuck is still massive in comparison to all that.

I'll say that Hiveswap is better than Homestuck in two major ways: The art is way better, and it gets to the meat of the universe-spanning stuff way faster than Homestuck does.  So although Hiveswap is shorter than Homestuck, that also means that it isn't the same slow burn that Homestuck is, and I'm sure that would make it a better experience for some people.  (It also means a whole bunch of stuff is dumped on you at once with very little introduction, but then again, being confused and overwhelmed by the complexity of the story is part of the Homestuck experience.)

But would I recommend the game to anyone who hadn't already tried Homestuck to see if they like it or not?  I don't think I would.  I'd be more likely to gift this game to someone in an attempt to get them interested in the idea of reading Homestuck.  Except I wouldn't do that either, since I'm not THAT big a fan of Homestuck.

I dunno.  Hiveswap is okay, but the only consumer advice I feel comfortable giving is "read Homestuck first to decide whether you would enjoy this or not".  You should probably give it a pass, otherwise.  If later acts turn the game into something truly unique, I may change my mind on that.

34996688.review:
HIVESWAP: Act 1, con le giuste premesse, vale il suo prezzo, ma se ci si aspetta più di un' avvincente introduzione ad una storia più ampia e complessa, si rischia di rimanere delusi.

Consiglio l'acquisto solamente se si è pronti a scendere a patti con la natura puramente introduttiva del primo episodio, mentre a chi vuole più ore di gameplay ed un'esperienza che scenda più in profondità in ciò che il gioco ha da dire consiglio di attendere almeno l'uscita di HIVESWAP: Act 2 (se non la completa pubblicazione).
A patto che gli episodi successivi mantengano il prezzo e la qualità di questo, a conti fatti il gioco varrà la candela.

Nel suo microcosmo introduttivo, HIVESWAP Act: 1 si presenta sia voglioso e ben volenteroso di calarci nel suo sistema narrativo, sia come incredibilmente piacevole da vedere ed ascoltare. Stupisce in particolare la quantità di testo e la cura che è stata riposta nella sua realizzazione: praticamente ogni oggetto dell'inventario ha un'interazione testuale unica con praticamente ogni elemento interagibile. Volendo forzatamente trovare una pecca, la prospettiva di alcune schermate di gioco risulta poco chiara ad una prima occhiata, cosa che può risultare in una difficoltà iniziale da parte del giocatore a spostarsi nelle schermate.
HIVESWAP: Act 1 risente della sua natura profondamente introduttiva nella complessità dei puzzle e del problem-solving: analizzato ad oggi, appare forse fin troppo facile ed intuitivo, in particolare nelle prime fasi; ci si auspica che negli episodi più avanzati la difficoltà degli ostacoli si alzi, visto che questo primo episodio sembra voler presentare al giocatore un sistema che, con l'avanzare graduale dell'esperienza, esige sempre di più dal giocatore, pur partendo da bassi livelli.

Dal punto di vista della narrativa, HIVESWAP: Act 1 si presenta immediatamente come un prodotto dalla fortissima impronta autoriale: ogni elemento a schermo esclama "Andrew Hussie", durante l'intero primo episodio è possibile incontrare una gamma vastissima di riferimenti, citazioni, importanti dettagli di lore ed easter eggs alla sua opera maestra, il webcomic interattivo "Homestuck". Nonostante ciò, il gioco sembra essere stato pensato per essere apprezzato facilmente anche da chi non ha precedentemente avuto a che fare con l'opera da cui origina (benché molti dettagli e indizi di trama risultino incomprensibili a questi giocatori).

EDIT [16/09/17 ore 16:44] Si precisa che, durante l'intero arco del gioco, non si sono presentati problemi nella sua esecuzione. L'unico imprevisto si è verificato al primissimo lancio del software e si trattava della risoluzione del gioco (bande nere laterali non previste). Con un po' d'accortezza e seguendo il feedback e le indicazioni degli sviluppatori (che stanno già lavorando per patchare il gioco), HIVESWAP: Act 1 è tutt'altro che ingiocabile.

Having been around for the original kickstarter all those years ago, I've since moved on from the Homestuck fandom. After having serendipitiously found out that this had actually been released from a YouTube comment of all places, and seeing the modest price (£5.99), I decided to indulge in a bit of nostalgia without really expecting to enjoy it that much at all after so long.

Boy was I wrong.

It definitely helps to already have been a fan of Homestuck to get the most out of all the little references and lore, and to properly understand the intricacies, however I'd recommend this even to people who haven't read the webcomic as the story is endearing and fun. Yes, it was short - which maybe should have been anticipated from the episodic release and the low price - however I already find myself invested in the characters and their interactions. If Act II were already available, I'd without a doubt already be installing it impatiently.

To say I'd lost all hope for a game ever actually being released given the trials that this game faced previously in development, I was more than pleasantly surprised!

34993590.review:
You have no idea what I've been through regarding this game.  I was one of the Kickstarter backers who put money towards this five years ago.  After five years, I expected more.  I really did.

I could go on for hours, almost as long as I've played the game itself, on all the things I hate about it.  It's really pretty, I'll give you that.  All the art, the references, the artifacts laying about, and the attention to detail in a purely visual sense is very strong.  It's meticulously crafted for the time period.  But in a point-and-click adventure game, it's kind of hard to know what's interactable and what's not when the background is so busy.  And in a 2D format, everything is warped to try and appear 3D, so your depth perception is thrown off.  Is that a hallway, an alcove, or a shelf?  Can I click on it?  WHY NOT??  I got lost in the fucking ATTIC.

Plus there's the clunky menu that (spoilers) ironically often gets in the way of the puzzle's solution.  You gotta close it to see everything in the whole screen.  ***And there's no WASD controls.***  You have to not only click on everything to use or interact with it, in an already disorienting setup, you also have to click on arbitrary points of what might be floor somewhere at some unknown distance.  If you click on something that is not floor, it will give the same message as when you inspected it the first ten times, all of which will be preachy and smarmy.  This will happen over and over, by accident.  

In a game that is 90% walking and using items from your menu on things in the environment, it sure makes it hard to do those things well or differentiate from them.  That is the first big gripe, one that will break the game singlehandedly in most people's eyes.

Meanwhile, the same looping midi track is playing over and over in the background.  You'd think composers with such experience in the indie game scene (the legendary Toby Fucking Fox being one of them) would have thought of making the soundtrack a little more tranquil, or just less in-your-face all the time, especially in the troll segements.  Nothing makes an obtuse, buggy, utterly garbage puzzle more infuriating than also having obnoxious band music playing on loop.  Here's a hint: loud, obnoxious music only appeals to us if it's FUNNY.  That's why Horsecatska was so popular, Mr. Roach.

And speaking of hints, hoo BOY HOWDY do we have a segue there.  The hint button is the most infuriating piece of shit you'll ever find in a game.  Navi from Zelda has nothing on the hint button.  At least Navi would tell you something useful some of the time, and her only flaw is that she would tell you too much too often.  But the HINT BUTTON.  It is not a hint button.  It is the greatest crime ever conceived by a developer: a feature which has no use.

The hint button does nothing.  Ever.  It's not a glitch, it's not a bug.  It just makes fun of you for clicking on the hint button.  You expected help?  In a game where nothing makes sense and the controls are garbage?  It's not like this is Zork here, we aren't typing commands into a prompt.  But apparently when you're stuck and can't find any sort of solution (and here's the kicker: (spoilers again) you are ALWAYS trapped in a room.  It is almost comical how stupid the hindrances become to your progress through this quadriplegic art mural.), it decides to say nothing of your situation and MOCK YOU FOR IT.  It's a "make fun of me" button.  For how sensitive and bleeding-heart the writers were about big game animals and fucking security cameras, they sure love to trigger people.  

After a certain point, the hint button just stops saying anything.  It would make sense if it started taking things seriously as the game progresses, and only make fun of you in the opening area when things are easy and (supposedly) self-explanatory.  But nope.  Its only purpose is to antagonize you, and then cease being funny.  It's the lack the lack of being funny that gets me.  It's like every piece of progress punishes you for you for daring to proceed, in the only way possible, by design.

You noticed the redundant words up there just now?  Get used to it.  There are grammatical errors and copy flubs throughout.  In a text-heavy game, just within the first few sessions of me playing, I've found six textual and punctual errors in the narrative prompt itself.  Missing periods, repeating repeating text, and just and just failed grammar in general

This has absolutely nothing to do with the characters' spoken words or typing quirks either, both of which are essential spice to the dialogue both here and in this game's source material.  This is just the writers being careless and not as diligent as I, which is a shame since they are supposedly older, more professional, and should just fucking know better.  This game was written in 2012 goddammit.  You should have found these by now in your last half a fucking year of bug testing.  I certainly noticed and I've only had the game for two days.

The very last question of this game, since it was set in the Homestuck universe(s), is "Is it funny?"  Well, it wasn't written with the sharp, cynical, nihilistic wit of Hussie, so no.  It was written by some vegetarian Tumblrite or something when Hussie couldn't give enough of a shit about his own game to bother after the first developer he chose to make this game embezzled him and then his father died.  I guess your ghost writer being a total pansy is the lesser of two evils.  They still burned through the better part of two million dollars pushing this platinum turd out on their own.

Oh, and did we mention that after the five years of development hell, the game was delayed another eight months for bug testing?  AND IT'S STILL BUGGY.  Eight months is enough to create a whole damn game, and they couldn't even get the screen to center properly in that time.  I CAN SEE ANOTHER PANEL FROM DAMMEK'S LIVING ROOM IF I WALK AROUND TOO MUCH.  

You wanna see what kind of game the Homestuck fandom makes?  This is it.  All doodle, no substance, and definitely zero fun.  Just like the SJWs who were fallen back upon to create it.

I mean, in conclusion, I should have expected as much.  This game was in development hell for several years, been through three developing houses essentially, and the only thing that's stayed true since the start was the gorgeous concept art which is the strongest point of the whole game.  Hell, I don't think they'll even need a "making-of art book" for their backers since the whole game is basically an interactive, annoying, hard-to-navigate art book that shouts preachy vegetarian slogans at you whenever you click on one of the taxidermied trophies.  Of which there are many.

Please, for the love of God do not buy this game.  Not until several patches have been made, preferrably ones with the words "we're sorry" in it.

34991930.review:
Hiveswap is a really fun game that blends the humor of Homestuck, the puzzles of adventure games and a surprisingly moving story into a stellar first act.

I'm someone who picked up Homestuck late so I didn't spend the years waiting for it to finally come out. I read it and then saw a trailer for it a few months later. That said I was very excited but also knew how the game was probably going to be utter garbage. It only makes sense. So I'm really happy that this game actually really nails what made me fall in love with Homestuck while not leaning so heavily on it to collapse.

Joey Claire is a fantastic main character, isntatlly likable as she looks through her room, remembering good times and bad as she looks through her house. Her relation with her brother is sometimes contentious, but ultimately loving. Seeing her naviagate her feelings for her father, her mother and the relationships she might have in the future was honestly one of the most interesting parts of the game. I put so many items together to see if it revealed another tidbit.

That's not to say their isn't a great sci-fi plot going on. If you can swallow that their are suddenly monsters out of nowhere you'll have a lot of fun. Newcomers will love learning their first tidbits of the world while longtime fans will enjoy all the little nods to things from the comic. I don't want to spoil much but there's a lot of exciting stuff going on.

The puzzles are good, never feeling like the worst of adventure games, solutions always makes sense. Having combat be it's own puzzle is great and removing the risk of dying there is a smart decision allowing you to play around to find a solution or just to find the perfect bad pun attack name. The second half gets a bit more obtuse but not to a point of being that difficult.

The art is incredible. Beautiful 2D animation and backgrounds make the homes of the characters feel lived in and very unique. You'll want to look at everything and you basically can. Little touches such as the way the kids draw or the toys they leave behind make their world feel so much more real and really bring this to the next level.

Basically this is a great game that worls great for old and new fans.

[Note: I recived this game as a gift from a friend.]

Overall, I thought the game was genuinely lovely. As a huge fan of Homestuck, it's really nice to see a new story take place in the same world, with the same style and sense of humour. The characters were likeable, the animation and art style was wonderful, the soundtrack is great, and the puzzles were simple enough to solve quickly, without feeling too easy. 

It did a great job of appealing to existing fans, but there were a few moments which felt a little too expository for people who are already familiar with the setting, yet not quite expository enough for those who aren't? I'm not sure that people who haven't read Homestuck would really [i] get [/i] the world, especially the troll side of things, just from the info the game gives you. I could be wrong though, and I'm sure future acts will add a little more world-building too. 

The only other complaints I can really give are obviously the length (plus the cost to length ratio for the rest of the acts together if they're of a similar length), and one bug I found where the cutscene after unlocking the attic wouldn't start and I had to restart the game. Aside from that, I would absolutely recommend the game to anyone who enjoyed Homestuck, maaaybe less so to anyone who didn't. A solid 8/10 imo.

34989292.review:
I kickstarted this back when Homestuck was still pretty popular and I was still a huge fan. But as much as I tried to like this, I really just can't.

Pros:
+The humor can be pretty funny from time to time
+A nice amount of interactive stuff throughout, usually giving a joke for your troubles
+Strife scenes are neat
+Soundtrack can get downright ambient
+Some of the artwork can be pretty beautiful
+That Sloth lusus is goddamn adorable
+Plenty of Homestuck references (I mean, of course there is) so fans will likely enjoy themselves
+Runs quite well

Neutral:
+/-The humor can get a little too reliant on references in places, the first half of this act being especially guilty of this

Cons:
-Animation is choppy as fuck, no matter your framerate, its just extremely choppy
-Hope you're a Homestuck fan. Cause if not, you'll likely end up really lost in a few places and probably won't get nearly as much from this as you would if you were a fan of the series
-Characters can be hit or miss. You'll either love em or hate em and the game doesn't last long enough to have any of them evolve in any way
-The overall setting of the game is really hard to get invested in when you're given two different settings to explore in such a small timespan, each with their own seemingly unrelated problems
-When the humor falls flat, IT REALLY FALLS FLAT, some straight up inducing a cringe from me
-Puzzles don't really go beyond "put key in door" or "mix item with other item" levels of problem solving, with maybe one or two points where that isn't the case
-The troll half REALLY drags the game down with boring puzzles and not exactly interesting enviornments if you're at all versed with Homestuck
-The troll half is also honestly really ham fisted with messages that might not gel well with some fans of the series
-The soundtrack can get a bit grating with the non-ambient tracks
-The game is maybe 2 hours long if you know what you're doing, more if you don't, like me; but maybe only an hour more

4/10.
I really wanted to like this game. I really did. However for every good aspect the game seems to have, there's seems to be a problem to match it. And with how short the whole experience is, you won't really have much time to get invested in the setting, characters, or the plot with how barebones it really is. It almost feels more like a proof of concept than a fully fleshed out game. Might be better to just wait for the whole thing to come out before buying unless you're a diehard fan that wishes to show their support along the way. Ultimately I don't feel this was worth the wait. [spoiler]Just like Homestuck's ending.[/spoiler]

34988364.review:
PROS

- Amazing, funny, nostalgic, sincere, absurd writing

- Amazing art

- Unique concept 

- I would say it's fairly priced for the content you're getting (keep in mind other visual novels with considerably higher price tags and less content)

- Amazing (X3) music

CONS

- It's fairly short if you play it straightforwardly, which is not how the game wants to be played and can be frustrating if that's your preferred play style

- Many of the mechanics, such as the combat and the "hacking" puzzles, are just not fun/intuitive. In these areas the game doesn't make it clear enough what it wants you as a player to do, and even when you do figure these "puzzles" out it isn't satisfying, it's just frustrating. I understand they were going for classic 90s computer games but they could have updated the responses a bit more to feel good to play.

- On the other end, some puzzles are TOO straight forward, and feel like they're spoon feeding the player the answer. I find this more frustrating than the combat/hacking puzzles, because it just feels like there was no reason or thought for those obstacles when it was so obvious how to get around them. How many point-and-click adventure games have done the "find a key" puzzle by now? Once could pass for nostalgia, but in the first act, let alone the first scene they do the "find a key" bit upwards of 3 times. I wish a bit more of the attention given to the writing side of the game was given to the....game side of the game as well.

Despite all this, I still recommend HIVESWAP for people who love point-and-click adventure, regardless of whether you were a fan of Homestuck or not. The story is accessible for new audiences as well as paying a lot of subtle fanservice to people who read the comic, and doesn't have to carry a lot of the exposition baggage Homestuck is so famous for. Most of it's pitfalls are in the mechanics, but as it is it doesn't really need to be super engaging on that front, just a little more polish would make the experience more enjoyable. I was totally absorbed by the story and characters from start to finish and am very excited for act 2's release, which will hopefully be soon. X:)

34987952.review:
It really is a 90's-style point & click adventure game.  For some, that will be fantastic.  Others may find it alien and peculiar.  There's one significant deviation from that formula though, in that the game features two minigames that are basically short sessions of Centipede.  The first is easy enough to be inoffensive to everyone, but the second is actually hard enough to be a genuine annoyance to P&C purists.  

Assuming you actually LIKE P&C games, and are fond of all the reading and clicking things on other things just to see what the game will respond, there's a ton of material here. It took me 6 hours, and that's with only minimal "I know this won't accomplish anything, but I'm going to try using the X on the Y just for the lulz" shenanigans.

But if you DON'T enjoy reading all the text, the game is actually pretty short.  This first installment BARELY feels like it even manages to get the main story off the ground, which is a bit odd, because I don't think there are actually all that many more Acts planned.  Without knowing what the rest of the story will be, it's hard to say much of anything more about that.

All in all, a good time.  A bit slower-paced than just reading Homestuck was, even in the dialogue-heavy parts, but still a good time.  Recommend to anyone who likes both P&C games and Homestuck.  Ideally both, but there's probably enough here to tempt anyone who only likes one or the other also.

34986904.review:
[i]NOTE: Despite this being a largely positive review, I recommend for most prospective buyers that you wait for certain issues mentioned below to be patched.[/i]


It's fun. It's really, really fun. And totally, unquestionably Homestuck. Let me elaborate:
[list]
[*]The writing is so far beyond great as to defy adjectives (didn't I just say that?).
[*]The utterly over-the-top (at least superficial) interactability of every item and ability you pick up with every object in the environment is the means by which you access the lion's share of text in the game, and one of the greatest sources of fun throughout is wondering what connection the characters/the narrator will make between the two wholly unrelated objects you just pushed together, and how the narrator will next insult you or voice their exasperation with your obsessive need to poke things with other things. When some of the especially ridiculous combinations lead to actual Steam achievements, the feeling is tremendously satisfying.
[*]Given that it is ACTUALLY a point-and-click adventure game, much of the humor has a more game-medium-oriented, "mechanical", Problem Sleuth/Homestuck Acts 1-3 vibe than the crazy [spoiler]"callback-within-a-callback-within-a-callback-too-many-dead-Nepetas-holy-crap-is-that-Shrek-HUSSIE-NO"[/spoiler] humor of the latter 2/3 of Homestuck. Which will be perhaps a disappointment for a good number of fans, but a HUGE plus for many including myself.
[*]The music is. just. SO GOOD. James Roach and Toby Fox composed the lion's share, and it's UHMAZING. It brings back the beloved earlier-Homestuck feature of "character music"--pieces or motifs that are specific to and meant to evoke the perspective of particular characters, and it does it damn well.
[*]The action sequences are not the game's strong suit, in my opinion, and the STRIFE system, while very visually evocative of its source material within Homestuck, is kind of a frustrating and mechanically insubstantial affair. What makes up for it is the puns that appear as "move descriptions" or "combat flavor text" when you try out various things in combat--they need to be seen to be believed.
[*]The art is real pretty. Just super, super pretty.
[*]The relationships between the characters are magnificent and mundane and dysfunctional and wonderful (again, it's Homestuck).
[/list]

Superlative praise so far. Now for the cons:
[list]
[*]There are a lot of typos. I mean a LOT of typos. 1 in 4 chunks of game text, as of launch night, contains one or more duplicate words, misspellings, or other typographical errors. This is the highest typo density I've ever seen in a game, outside the very worst/cheapest dating-sim visual novels and text-heavy flash games. Given how great the text (as intended) is, and what a huge part of the game it comprises, this is really disappointing to me--but thankfully for later players, it is much easier for the devs to fix than almost any other bug/mistake in the game, and I'm sure the bug reports are already flooding in.
[*]Clicking on objects in the environment is visually buggy. Some things that are not mutually interactable (i.e. poking thing B with thing A does nothing) nonetheless display the cursor change intended to represent interactability, only to switch back to the regular cursor and do nothing else when actually clicked to interact.
[*]There are more than a couple situational text mistakes, including one really profoundly disappointing "narrative sequence break" in which interacting with an important object provided text that was clearly only meant to be displayed when I came back to that area much later and had completed several intermediary objectives, and actually spoilered the immediately-following [i]hour[/i] of gameplay (by describing those as-yet-unintroduced intermediate objectives as if I had already performed them). Another such problem which prevents an obstacle to progression (to which I have yet to identify a workaround, though I know one either exists or else the objective in question is a non-required subthread of gameplay, because people have completed the game) involves an item nowhere in sight being described as right in front of you (and all the objects supposedly around it referring, upon interaction, to this more important object theoretically nestled amongst them). Another involves a character attempting to perform a complex operation, which they initially fail, followed by game text reminding them they left themselves instructions in another room. I looked high and low for said instructions, found no sign of them, and eventually went back to the original room and clicked to attempt the operation again on the off-chance some different text would display giving me a further hint to the instructions' location. Despite my having found/done nothing in the interim, this second attempt actually successfully completed the puzzling operation, and progressed the story beyond the need to find the elusive (and ostensibly necessary) instructions.
[*]Clicking the open spaces of an environment to walk around within it is quite clunky, and I experienced a fair amount of frustration trying to find the right spots to click to make characters walk across certain rooms so I could see what was off-camera.
[*]unfortunately, given the previously mentioned "real-pretty"-ness of the art, the animation during cutscenes is far from fluid--very few frames of animation per second. This is not a huge frustration, and it by no means ruins the action being presented, but it's noticeable.
[*]See near the bottom of the first bulleted list for my comments on the STRIFE (combat) system.
[/list]

At this point, I would say--if you are not one of the untold myriad including myself who are driven by a blood-compulsion to play and complete and devour and pick clean the nostalgia-spiced carcass of this game RIGHT NOW--wait a while for the less systemic issues to be ironed out before purchasing. After a bit of cleanup by the devs, you are sure to have the truly captivating, feels-inducing, laughter-provoking, magnificently bizarre experience you deserve, and which the wonderful people behind this game so earnestly wish to provide you. :)

34986688.review:
WARNING: IF YOU HAVEN'T READ THE COMIC THIS IS BASED ON YOU WILL HAVE A LOT LESS FUN THAN I DID. A lot of this first act has subtle references and callbacks to Homestuck and while it doesn't mean you can't enjoy it you will miss out on a lot of the fun and the theorycrafting that I think is a fundamental part of this game (and really any story in general).

Hiveswap Act 1 seems a lot like Homestuck Act 1: lots of character, really fun, interesting enough to hold your attention, but without it's other acts to build on it's foreshadowing it feels small, and it has some quality control issues. (I'm not qualified to talk about the potential plotholes since Homestuck's lore is extremely dense and convoluted and I've only read it twice, but there were a lot of typos).

Basically, don't expect God from Act 1, like how you shouldn't expect all of Homestuck to give out the goods when you first read it. Hiveswap and it's parallel game Hauntswitch will need time to develop before a comprehensive critique can be made but so far I'm pretty excited. I also expect the typos to be updated by the end of the week. Still, the game is written in Andrew Hussie's weird-ass but hilarious and endearing style. If you've read the comic you should DEFINITELY play this.

The game might also be a little short for you, and while I think a 3 - 5 hour solid narrative that expands on the lore of a word I love is worth more than $8, well, you might want to wait before buying into this. Hussie has a good track record with folowing through if you give him the time so I'm not worried at all.

34985768.review:
Lovely game! I don't usually enjoy this genre, but they weren't kidding when they said it had all the charm, but none of the frustration of most point-and-clicks. 

Story: 5/5 
   The perfect length for an episodic game, in my opinion. Enough callbacks and reference to the original comic to satisfy long-time fans, but you have no need to know the lore beforehand to complete the game. This game does tie some unanswered questions in the comic together and reveal things most people wouldn't even have speculated, but again, understanding them isn't needed to enjoy the game.

Gameplay and Combat: 4/5
   Favourite thing about the gameplay is how efficient it is. The walking pace changed depending on the situation to ease frustration. For example, if you were to click something at the far end of a room, Joey would speedwalk there to inspect it instead of her usual pace she takes when walking regularly. It's minor, but really pleasant.
   Combat is very user-friendly, but feels scripted (I'm guessing that was intended). The only challenge I felt was figuring out which option to use to win, I didn't ever come to a situation where I felt like I was gonna lose. Keeping in mind I have not yet tried to lose a strife.  

Graphics: 4.5/5
   Absolutely adorable! Keeps in line with Homestuck's style (notable addition: arms), and the animation is consistent. Really pleasing to look at. The contrast between living/moving objects and the scenes was good, they stuck out adequately yet were as elegant as the background itself. 
  The backgrounds were beautiful, but it was a little difficult at times to make out which objects I could inspect/interact with. Sometimes they were in a cluttered corner, or even a couple of items cluttered together, and a few just blended in to the scenery. However, this didn't take away from my enjoyment , and the middle ground between "completely hidden in the background" and "so obvious its basically telling you" is hard to reach. 

Music: 4.5/5
   Fitting and familiar. I shouldn't be surprised at how many songs there were, given the source material and development team. Transitions between songs when entering different areas was smooth and pleasant, felt mostly natural. I have nothing bad to say about the music, only that it didn't grab me the same way the Homestuck soundtrack did. 
   The price increase from the game alone to with the soundtrack was very fair. Would reccomend getting it with.

Characters: 6/5
   Oh my gosh, the characters. I don't know how to talk about characters without spoiling much, but this episode established more depth than I thought it would. Adorable characters, not without flaws, still adorable. I wish I could back this up more with words, but writing a review this late at night doesn't help me.

Overall: 4.5 stars
   Super nice and satisfying to play! Short but not too short, and full of story. Can't wait until the next installment!

(I didn'd read any reviews before writing this. If this is exactly the same as someone else's, then...oops?)

34985609.review:
I personally really enjoyed the game, but I am probably capable of liking just about everything so I've decided to make a pros and cons list.

PROS:
+The art looked really nice. I liked the simple character designs against a more complex background, and all of the backgrounds were detailed and nice looking
+I really liked the dialogue and the text that popped up when you clicked on stuff. Almost everything you combined or made interact with other things had different text, which was really cool to me.
+I liked the characters and was interested to see what would happen next, which is pretty good because a lot of the times I don't care.
+A lot of people complained about the mini games, but I really liked them. 
+The puzzles at the beginning were fun and nice to complete

CONS:
-The puzzles near the end were just clicking on random things and praying. The description said no dream logic but that was exactly what happened
-Very glitchy. This is probably the most major problem. If just this one problem were fixed, everything would be great. When I first played it, things weren't cropped right, and everything was just off centered. Sometimes I could see parts of other rooms I didn't even know about yet. [spoiler] In Jude's treehouse I could see the desk drawer off to the side of the screen and actually complete the puzzle without ever clicking the desk [/spoiler] I actually got rid of steam and reinstalled it in order for it to be functional, Now it works great, but my computer is suffering. Why should a few videos and dialogue cause so much suffering?
-The strife scenes were very... strange? I feel like they would be better if there was some sort of health bar so you could feel that you were progressing in some way, and have you use some kind of fighting ability instead of relying on the random stuff you just pick up.
-There were a lot of homestuck references. While this is a homestuck game, so it makes sense that there'd be references, but there were some characters that were mentioned whose implications only someone who knew the character would understand. The storyline still makes sense, and its not completely void of entertainment if you haven't read it.
-The character animations were kind of off. They were kind of jittery sometimes, and other times they didn't quite match the action. [spoiler] Joey throws spice at something and her "picking something up off the ground" animation plays. Why? is she picking up minuscule particles of spice off of the ground? maybe it's not a glitch, she's just talented. Who am I to judge? [/spoiler] Also, some times the door opening animation doesn't quite match up with the door but at this point I'm just nitpicking.
-The game is pretty short. I personally was fine with it, I wish it was longer but it's like how I wish a book I was reading was longer. I don't feel cheated, I just feel excited for the next one. However some other people feel cheated and I can understand that.
-Really long production time. Why did it take so long, I finished in about 3 hours.
-"Everything has unique text when interacted with another thing" is a lie. Some things would say stuff, so saying that goes against the description.
-This is more of a misconception than anything else, but I thought there would be multiple endings and they did not exist. This makes the 3 hours worth that much less.

OVERALL:
Wait until the glitches are resolved and only then should you think about buying it. You do not want to go though the pain I went through. After the glitches are fixed, then continue to proceed cautiously. I love homestuck and I love a lot of the things in this game, but watch a playthrough if you just want to see the pretty pictures.

34985401.review:
Let me start off by saying, if you liked Homestuck you'll like Hiveswap. Everything is here except this time around there's a lot less plot to deal with and only vague references and mentions. It helps to know the mechanics in Homestuck, but none of it is required. Now let me follow up and say that if you don't enjoy reading loads of text, using things with other things, you probably won't get a lot out of Hiveswap. There's cute characters, funny moments, and all sorts of little things going on if you just play the game through with the basic plot. If you start using everything with everything else you start understanding the characters as a whole. And that's Hiveswap's strength, getting you invested in the main characters through stupid completely optional interactions. And even if you don't do these interactions, the vast colorful cluttered environments come a close second, showing a ton of character in their own way.

But ultimately, Hiveswap is just a slightly more interactive version of Homestuck. Since accessibility to the craziness of the media is the concept, puzzles are very simple and interacting with objects will give you big hints that will tell you exactly what to do. It's a good thing that Hiveswap advertises this because adventure game veterans are going to feel a little underwhelmed. Again, however, this is a game where the completely optional acts of using things with things will fill in all those little spaces where the game may feel less than stellar. And nearly every thing you use other things with have unique dialogue! Hooray! 

Big tip: if you intend to play the game this way, DIGEST IT. There is so much text, so much text, Homestuck is near legendary for its ability to completely smother pages with texts, Hiveswap is no different. If you really want to use everything with everything, then my friend, you have a 6 hour game ahead of you. So yes, take your time to enjoy it because you will get tired out if you don't. If you decide to just run through Hiveswap, it's considerably less time at about 2 to 3 hours, probably less if you know what you're doing or don't bother checking anything. But again, a lot of the fun is just those optional dialogues.

If you're interested in Homestuck but haven't read it or read very far into it, Hiveswap is... somewhat of a good jump in point. There's almost no spoilers to the main series, or at least any obvious ones. And from what I've seen, Act 1 doesn't reference the webcomic's plot at all. If you're a big Homestuck fan, then you're going to like Act 1 and it'll be over too soon. Just think of it as an update followed by a megapause. It's like Homestuck never ended. And if I'm going to be frank, given how much dialogue and text there is in Act 1, I'm pretty relieved that there'll be time to talk and speculate about every little thing. I feel like I have a headache after using a pidgeon on literally hundreds of items.

34984654.review:
Usually I don't play point-and-click stuff much, but as someone who has followed Homestuck for quite a while, this was well worth the wait. You will definitely enjoy it (especially if you're a fan of Homestuck, But so far, besides some hidden easter eggs referencing it, such as the Signless plushie, and a few things that make a bit more sense if you're familiar with certain details,  it's a relatively clean slate for those new to the "franchise" as it were),

For the review, I will dodge the hype of being a Homestuck fan and look at it objectively. Even if you're someone who isn't familiar with the universe, you'll find a quirky storyline with very relatable characters (trust me, if you were a '90's kid', this is how you lived, besides the monsters of course. You will really appreciate all the little details you can find poking around even within the first few areas alone), humor, beautiful artwork, and an equally-great soundtrack. Those who have played Undertale may also notice some similarities in the overall "feel" -- which is no surprise, given that its developer has been involved in Homestuck to begin with (and this too, but more on the musical front). 

It's not 100% perfect, though; I did have a bug with the first battle (don't use abilities on the basement monster when you first see it, or you'll glitch into a white screen), and I'm also not sure if there is any sort of auto-save option or quick-save keyboard shortcut (which would have been useful given said bug.cause I ended up having to replay a good portion due to that). Besides that, it has been great so far, and I hope that the remainder of this first chapter lives up to expectations.

34984583.review:
Like many people I have been hyped for this game since its was revealed around 5 years ago. It seemed the wait was going to last forever but its finally come out. While the story is short, about 2 hours, I think this is a great introduction and they will continue to provide acts in the future, hopefully not 5 years again haha. There are some shortcomings no doubt. But it was amazing to play and if you like homestuck or even beautifully made games, this is worth it.

Heres some simple +- I think sums it up
+Art, it's beautifully amde and flows well with the movement
+Music, gain it is beutifully made. I love Toby Fox and his work
+Storytelling, just like homestuck the smallest details of writing seem to convey a huge amount of story and I feel like there is more to replay and discover. I am already hyped for act 2
+Combat, the combat is different, thats as much as i will say to avoid any small spoilers
+Exploration, there are so many hidden references and small details that make this game interesting 

-Puzzles, I think the puzzles were a bit too easy or laid out, but seeing as I am more interested in the story and exploration aspects it wasn't a problem for me
-Length, I never expected it to be excessively long but 2 hours does seem a bit short, however as an act 1 and introduction it is well done. Not to mention it is only $8. If it is like homestuck the acts will get longer as well.

Overall i would say it was 100% worth buying and I can't wait for the next one.

34984301.review:
This is very much a game for Homestuck fans, but it is by no means exclusive to them. It's filled with references to the comic galore, and manages to sneak them in without spoiling any of it. The art is beautiful, the music is relaxing, and the characters are very likable. I've noticed some people getting "stuck" on some of the early puzzles, but it's not really that hard. This could be because I wanted to click everything I saw, but I was never stuck on anything.

HOWEVER. This game is EXTREMELY SHORT! I understand that it's an episodic series and there's 3 more coming, but this took practically no time at all to complete. It just sort've rushed past me.

Not that big of a deal though, because it's only one part of a larger story. I definitely suggest you give this game a shot, even if you're not a fan of Homestuck.

34984218.review:
This is a promising start to a game. Fun characters, some actually laugh out loud moments, gorgeous art, and the beginnings of a rebellion plot on a zany alien planet. Almost all of the items/actions in the game can interact with almost all the other items in the game, meaning there are very few (if any) cases of being unable to get a unique text-box result when trying something.

But?

Well, it may be fun, but it's very, very short. I took my time clicking on as many things as I could, and yet I clocked in at just under three hours of gameplay. For someone less explorative, this means gametime could easily fall under two hours. I'd wait until further acts are released to buy it if you’re not already a Homestuck fan because as of this moment the game cuts off just at the point where I'd normally start to be invested in it. In the long run this may not be an issue (it's a decent place for a title drop), but it's certainly not a stand-alone title and will almost certainly leave people who just wanted to try it out wishing there was more to it.

That being said -- if you are a Homestuck fan? Yes, buy it. Lots of fun small nods to things, and the strife scenes almost make it worth the price alone.

Having finished Act 1, I can say that it's been well worth the wait! The art style seems to be a continuation of the direction Homestuck went in later on within the last few sub-acts and animations, something I can very much respect. The description doesn't lie regarding the music, though I never had any doubts given the author's incredible track record. 

As noted in other comments, while the game can mechanically be solved within 20 minutes or so, finding all the little details and references is well worth the effort and deepens the experience considerably. The text was creative and witty, something that encourages players to try out different combinations just to take in a sentence or two more.

The story itself is entirely independent of Homestuck, while keeping an amazing level of quality, which makes it entirely suitable for people who've never even heard of the webcomic before. While there are currently some UI mishaps here and  there (which I was expecting going in, seeing as the game's only been released for two days as of this review) they don't impede gameplay. Can't wait for Act 2!

34982860.review:
After 5 years and 2.4M$, the game's outcome was everything I had expected, and felt EXACTLY like the comic in terms of the writing and sense of humor (along with many refrences)

[h1] Pros: [/h1]
- The writing is very clever and humorous, and almost all interactions between items (no matter how strange) have text associated with them
- The backgrounds and scenery are very well made, with tons of detail put into every inch
- Even though the game takes place in a well-established universe, most pre-existing things are explained to the player without interrupting the game, making the game accessable to people unfamiliar with the story.
- Players who have read the webcomic will see tons of small details refrencing pre-existing concepts from the comic
- Incredibly upbeat and original music by James Roach and Toby Fox (yes, the Toby who made Undertale)

[h1] Cons: [/h1]
- Minor bugs and glitches here and there, such as display issues, audio glitches, etc.
- Cutscenes look a little crude in some shots
- Camera angle changes drasticially sometimes when going from one side of a room to another, and can be a little disorienting
- Minor spelling/grammatical errors here and there
- Pogs
- Bubsy

[h1] Things to Note: [/h1]
- If you haven't read Homestuck and are looking in buying this game, don't worry, the two have completely seperate stories that don't coincide with eachother. If you want to read Homestuck before playing, you probably won't be buying this for the next few months (8,000+ pages and 4 hours worth of video is a lot!)
- This is only the 1st of 4 acts, so don't expect a complete game
- There is very little choice in this game, don't expect this to be like a TellTale game

34982832.review:
I wasn't inclined to believe I had actually purchased "POGS: THE VIDEO GAME" until it was far too late.

If you thought there was going to be some other redeemable feature like an engaging story or varied but visually appealing art, then I hate to tell you that anything like the such is heavily overshadowed by the ever-reaching, ever-corrupting force that are POGs. SPOILER WARNING: You get them early on in the game and they N E V E R  L E A V E  Y O U. They are never used for anything significant and you can never get rid of them. Many of the item interactions that take place with the POGs involve you losing them or intentionally destroying them.

But you never run out.

They are infinite in their quantity and infinite in their terribleness.

Save yourself before you accidentally spend $7.99 on this glorified POG shilling program. (Or $11.99 if you wanted to listen to some neat tunes while reading POG flavortext.)

I am warning you now.

Save yourself before it is too late.

34982331.review:
Pros
+Great story with plenty of optional background flavour
+Interesting and well-portrayed teenage characters
+Great sense of humour, balances serious tone and jokes well
+Vivid and expressive artwork and animation
+Equaly expressive soundtrack

Cons
-Puzzles so far are pretty easy, just requiring memory/easy guesses
-Resolution issues (plays in widescreen)
-UI can be obstructive in some cases

Neutral
+- The game's playtime is doubled by all the object interactions in the game. (Remember, you can also use inventory items on objects for alternate text prompts.) If you like reading and are genuinely interested in the universe and backstory and not just the main plot, the game will last a lot longer for you. Players who prefer to stick to the main plot with little distraction may feel a little cheated as far as game length is concerned.

REVIEW

Incredibly charming game with a great main plot that stands on its own and TONS of objects to interact with that open text prompts that provide more depth and background if you want it. The art is very stylistic, similar to Homestuck's, but with MUCH more detail put into both art and animation. Speaking of Homestuck, you don't need to have read Homestuck to understand the plot, as it will introduce the concepts Homestuck readers already know about through the course of the game.

At least in my experience, however, there were some resolution issues (The game would only run in widescreen format leaving black bars at the top and bottom, regardless of windowed/fullscreen or what resolution I played in.) and the UI could sometimes get in the way and stick around in situations were it should disappear, but these were just minor grievances and are not nearly as big of problems as they would be in a more fast-paced game.

As a lore-loving completionist type who read every text prompt using every inventory item on every background object, 9/10. It may be an 8 or 7/10 for a more fast-paced player. But, my heart will say 10/10.
 
Because Homestuck.

34982001.review:
The first act of Hiveswap really set the universe. For Homestuck fans like me, you definitely won't be lost, and will be happy to go around looking at all the easter eggs while discovering the story. For newcomers to the universe, it totally seems to me the game has been made to be playable without knowing a thing to Homestuck, and you can just go through the story without worrying to be missing something.

It was nice to see again a new set of characters with totally different personalities. Joey is a totally fun and lovely hero, and I'm really looking forward seeing how she will evolve in this universe. The interactivity with all the decor elements is a major part of the game, as you can make any object of your inventory interacting with every item around, leading to fun reactions and sometimes some hidden gems.

The game is really pretty. I had a lot of expectations on the music side, and I was not disappointed. Most of the rooms and important moments of the game are ambianced by a different music, which really set the mood and don't trap the player in a specific musical atmosphere. So good job to James Roach and Toby Fox! If I had to pick my favorites from this first Act, it would go for Joey Claire, Extraordinaire, Final Spice and Filthy Nuclear Bunker.

Good job to Andrew Hussie, Cohen and everyone who worked on the game so far! The only drawback I would see there is that the first act is really short. I finished it in ~3 hours without rushing, and another time in ~30 minutes to sneak around and find all the achievements I was missing. But it was worth the time! And hey, ACT 1 of Homestuck was also really short if you compare it to the others, so who knows what will follow!

Looking forward ACT 2!

34981488.review:
I wasn't expecting the size of the nostalgia trip this sent me on, both for the game style and for the number of born-in-the-early-eighties references plastered across the Earth bits of it. (And the flavor text is consistently fun, if sometimes in a rather black-humour way. This game rewards looking closely at the environments.)

Short as it was (this definitely has a Part One feel, obviously) it managed to scratch my Homestuck itch pretty well. Knowing the source material isn't strictly necessary, but it definitely helps give you some context, and there's lots of references early on to where characters from the comic ended up that past readers might get a kick out of. Otherwise, the characters are about as confused about what's going on as any uninitiated players would be, so there's something to said for just rolling with the "WTF's going on" vortex you quickly wind up in.

Anyway, possibly an acquired taste overall, but I enjoyed it and will probably be jumping on Act 2 whenever it shows up. If you liked the original comic, or remember the point-and-click adventure/puzzle games of yore, giving this a shot probably won't hurt.

34981372.review:
An enjoyable romp through Earth and Alternia that left me wanting more (but in a good way).

PROS:
Excellent writing and humor
Immersive feeling of the 90's
Rewards inventory experimentation with clever dialog and/or achievements
Interesting but not frustrating puzzles
Very quality art and music
Enjoyable references and expands on the world of Homestuck, but doesn't require prior knowledge

NEUTRAL:
A few minigames exist, but they're nothing to write home about
If you don't like messing around with everything, you can beat the game, but you might not have as much fun

CONS:
Runs a little short, even with detail-hunting
Some audio and animation glitches, tho nothing game-breaking
Some puzzles can seem too simple, or are given away by the game
Would have appreciated a couple more battles in the second half of the game

Overall: As a Kickstarter backer of this project, I was worried that the gameplay might have suffered from its time in development hell. I am happy to find it an excellent, if not perfect, experience, and I look forward to more (hopefully before another 5 years pass).

34981246.review:
Not worth the wait, unless we only have to wait a month for the next act.

Not worth the money. The game is very short, and while it is sometimes funny, or heartwarming, or dramatic, it doesn't spend much time letting you explore any given place, and what it does let you do is extremley limited. It's the bad kind of adventure game where you pick up a bunch of "keys", find the "locks" where the "keys" go to find more "keys" and more "locks", where the keys and locks can be literal keys and locks or a bowl of milk and a door. Figuring out where to use what item does not make you feel clever, and is not rewarding, especially since the game often just tells you what to do. I guess like Homestuck it's more of a graphic novel, but with more stuff, but here the "more stuff" was wasting my time. 

I don't even know if I can recommend it or not. If you're looking for a adventure or puzzle game, look elsewhere. If you're a Homestuck fan, and you don't care about the gameplay, then you might enjoy having a new story with familiar events and settings. If you aren't a Homestuck fan and you don't care about gameplay, then it might be a fresh sci-fi story, filled with interesting characters, places, and cultures for you to discover. 

If you've never read Homestuck before, you aren't really missing out on much. Not knowing the source material will make for a more mysterious story, where you see pieces of the bigger picture and slowly discover more about the world you're exploring.

34981019.review:
Cute, easy game and definitely full of nostalgia for those who followed along with Homestuck.

I'm not a huge Homestuck fan, but the games, music, animations, and character interactions were my favorite bits, and I feel like this captured the essence of that well. 
The music is great, the artwork is cute, I enjoyed the dialogue, and the humor is pretty much the same corny sort as Homestuck (which is a pro or con depending on your sort of humor, but I generally enjoyed it).
It's especially a good sort of game if you're like me and like to go around looking for all possible reactions to combining items with things--because there are a [i]lot[/i] in the game, and I still haven't tried everything.

The puzzles are [i]incredibly[/i] easy (and this is coming from someone who constantly has to check walkthroughs on obvious things in other games). If you're looking for a game that will make you think much with its puzzles... probably don't go with Hiveswap. At the very least, Act 1 won't provide that.
That said, I found it relaxing to play through and overall enjoyed my time looking around at everything.

For people who haven't read Homestuck, I personally imagine it would still be fun and a good introduction, but I can't say for sure. A lot of the game's appeal is definitely to those who have read it, so some of that would be lost.

I personally feel I got my money's worth from Act 1 and will be sticking around for more, but I do hope future installments will have more interesting puzzles than this one.

Unfortunately, I can't recommend the game as it stands.

Technical issues:

The big one rendering this game unplayable for me.

I tried it on Windows 10 and OS X. It runs poorly on my Windows 10 machine, as in the game is laggy and unresponsive. On OS X, it runs fine but has odd UI bugs. In both cases I was unable to pass the first 'strife' scene due to the game going into a white screen with nothing to interact with.


Story:

A point and click, a lot of what is available is irrelevant and primarily targeted at Homestuck nostalgia. This game doesn't carry its own weight enough to hook a player without being familiar with Homestuck.


Gameplay:

Not much to the early puzzles. Key-focused. Unintuitive map layout.



The game's main appeal seems to be in getting the player to go 'oh, I understood that reference.' Not exciting on its own.

Bon! Je viens littéralement de finir cet "Act 1" (pas encore à 100%)... J'ai adoré du menu aux crédits! 

Le jeu possède une superbe patte graphique, des musiques épiques (que je vais écouter en boucle sur mes trajets) et une histoire prenante! je trouve que l'attente valait le coup. Pour les non-initiés à Homestuck ça devrait vous convaincre de vous y mettre, les autres, vous devriez bien regarder partout (objet anodins ,décors, dates, etc...) afin de trouver les références qui vont vous faire plaisir et qui restent discrètes afin de ne pas déranger les non lecteurs. Les personnages sont attachants et l'interface hyper sympathique. Un gros plus pour l'originalité des énigmes sous formes de combats d'une qualité rare pour un point and click (qui d'ailleurs sont rarement pourvus de combats)
Humour et émotions sont au rendez-vous pour peu que vous maîtrisiez un peu la langue de Shakespeare. 

J'ai eu un très léger bug sur une énigme de récupération de clé quand il fallait juste la mettre dans mon inventaire: si vous rencontrez le même problème à ne pas pouvoir la récupérer, cliquez sur la croix rouge pour fermer l'interface d'inventaire et cliquez sur l'item.

Pour finir je dirais que j'ai hâte d'avoir Hauntswitch et le reste d'Hiveswap entre les mains.

Mon gros coup de coeur en bref.


Merci Andrew Hussie pour l'univers, merci Toby Fox et James Roach pour l'ost et merci tous le reste de l'équipe (et merci les donateurs, j'aurais aimé être des vôtres).

34978313.review:
'AIGHT PEOPLE, BUCKLE UP BECAUSE I'M ABOUT TO WRITE A SPOILER-FULL DETAILED REVIEW ON THIS ONE

I've been saving up for this game for a long time and honestly, even if there are some bugs and visual glitches, I still absolutely love it.
Cons first:
Once in a while the screen will shift to the side so much that another window of other scene appears (and the scene is also iteractable), tho I heard that this will be fixed in future updates. The default movements of characters while not walking are a bit choppy, but I guess that could be the style of the game. 
And that's it, I didn't notice any other bugs, probably because I was too busy admiring the artwork.

[i] And now, a novel-lenght appreciation part of the game [/i]
First of all, ARTWORK. Man, the backgrounds, the animations, y e s. I would spend like 10 minutes just staring at the backgrounds, admiring the beautiful art. And then clicking furiously on everything with everything to get every single text box I can get. The humour of the game is also yes, very much like Homestuck, forced me to take out my translator app sometimes because it uses SO MUCH fancy words. Especially Jude. Jude's talking through walkie talkie kinda annoyed me. 
Music. Oh god, the music. Every single piece I heard in this game is beautiful. Toby Fox and James Roach did an amazing job. My favourite was Xefros' theme Rustblood, a.k.a. WHERE THE FUCK ARE THE TREATS. Can't wait to arrange the song to piano. 
Moving on. Strife scenes. They are a bit tricky, but I really enjoyed the generic Homestuck Strife texts after every attack. I loved that you needed to use stuff in your sylladex to win the fights. Rip bat monster, you will not be missed as you ate poor Frohiko. 
The animations are really fluid and beautifully drawn. The "The Door is Open" animation is amazing. The facial expressions of the characters are very funny and perfectly drawn as well. Man, this game's visual are great and I will proceed to talk about it for the rest of my life.
Moving to Alternia, I was happy to find out some more stuff about this world that Hussie has crafted for us over the years. The violent nature of trolls never fails to amuse me. As Xefros kept talking about his moirail Dammek, who was probably sucked in to the cherub portal at the same time as Jude, I started to grow fond of this little sweet cinnamon roll Xefros and kinda feel bad for the boy, because his moirail was clearly using him? Let Jude kick Dammek's ass later for that please. 
Where was I?
Discovered Alternian sports - Pusher ? I think? Later he referred to this sports as Arena Stickball so I dunno. Once again, morbid game: you win - cool, you lose - death. Like everything is in Alternia.
Also they have public transport which is great. 
My favourite part about the Alternia part of gameplay was the ability to name Lususes. Lusi? I don't even know. I don't know why, but I got really excited when I got to pick a name for sloth Lusus. 
Interactive walkie-talkie on Earth and trollian on Alternia was cool too. I wonder how will the real life dialogues go in the next Acts.
The personalities of the characters were also good. I feel like I know the characters as good as people I see everyday. Is that a good thing? Probably. Easier to write good fanfics :D
Man, I could go on and on about every single object in the game, but I'll spare you guys this time.

TL;DR: As it was just released it has some bugs but aside from those, the game is amazing and you all should check it out!

So where should I begin?
Alright, I'll start by saying this is the first time I feel compelled to write a review about a game, but I feel like this game is astounding by what it delivered despite all the development nightmares it went through. If all Acts of Hiveswap and Hauntswich are like this in art quality, witty dialogue, animation and character design this can easily become an indie classic.

This game is short, but that becomes very forgivable due to the meager asking price of 8 goddamn dollars, and if you think you breezed through too quickly, go again and do all item combinations you didn't think about at first, you'll uncover quite an amusing quantity AND quality of new text.

There were some minor animation bugs during transitional animations, like when the pidgeons are flying, which bummed me off a little bit at first. But I managed to fix the issue by restarting the game. Pro-tip, if you change the resolution of the game restart it, because I have a feeling that it's exactly the resolution change that caused the animation bug.

Still, not much to complain about tho. Music is fantastic, art is magnificent, gameplay is the standard point-and-click experience and delivered me exactly what I expected.

9/10

34977199.review:
I am going to make an adaptation of an reddit post I've made
Problems:
There are bugs. Which, leaving in account that this is an indie pc game is very normal. However, some stuff is really annoying, like cutscenes being skipped, and a resolution changing bug.
Most of the mid game cutscenes are just still images that change after one or two seconds. would not be too bad, bus most of the time there isn't a transitioning animation for the character before and after the cutscene, and some of the regular animations don't really interact withe the enviroment (I.E.: opening a door)
Joey opening doors animations annoys me. She should've interact with the door's handle. small nitpick but still
The puzzles are not challenging
It is Short. It can be divided in only two segments, and if you go running you can finish it in like an hour. Of course, that's normal for a point-and-click adventure game, since you usually have to interact with everything to extent it's time. but still, the game should have more playtime, speacially with the amount received with kickstarter money.

The good stuff:
The story. Nothing mind super blowing like the mid homestuck, but Honestly, it is probably because I know most of troll culture and have watched the trailers over and over again. It gives to me the same feeling I have with the initial acts of homestuck. If this indicates anything, Act 2 of hiveswap will be very good, like letters acts of the original work. It's a good introduction to both hiveswap and hauntswitch. It shows the protagonists of the games, the initial threats that they are fighting, the world(and house) they live in, and hints of other characters that will help or antagonize them. It has good potential, and I don't really like to criticize a story for it's beginning, the mid stuff is what matters. And a satisfying ending I guess.
Jokes: They are funny, and that's all I have to say on the matter
Music: I don't regret buying the album without knowing if the songs are good or bad.
Strife battles: They are all pretty nice, although there is a short amount of them
Characters: They are all lovely, and have all potential to grow, although if they do not in the following acts... they might look one-dimensional.
You can interact with everything with almost everything
You don't need to read homestuck to know what's happening. Everything  a new player won't know and need to know at the moment, the game will explain.

Neutral:
Animation: 
They are good, however I wish there were more of them, especially in the middle of the game, the lack of transitioning between a character in the screen and a still image cutscene get's a bit annoying. 
Dialogues: They are condesced in information and are funny sometimes. Although they can be a bit long.


Conclusion:

The price is a bit expensive for the size of the game, but might be worth it if the following acts are cheaper. like 4+ dollars cheaper

Now if you are a new player... even though I recommend this game you have to know that the game is around 3 hours, the following acts could get good or not. And you still will have to pay for them, are they going to be cheaper? What Pumpkin haven't given information on this yet. So, really think before buying.

BUGS: I had one cut scene mysteriously not play, this is after it played once? I do not know why this happened, but it played the third time I tried it. Sometimes things appear off screen I think, but when you play in windowed mode, things look too pixellated (mainly the character). Sometimes the click areas felt needlessly tedious and off, especially descending the stairs in the Harley house. This game wouldn't run with my GTX 430 installed, I had to plug in my r9 290. Technically the lower card could've handled it, but it just wouldn't open.
