34976889.review:
This game is so. cute.

As far as point and clicks go, the story is pretty short- but that's because it's only act 1, and that is reflected in the price of the game.

The game will be a lot longer if you explore the lovingly crafted environments to their fullest. Homesick fans are used to much of the charm of the series being the writing beneath the panel; similarly, the charm in this game is in the tidbits of writing you get trying every object in your inventory with every object you can interact with. There were very few objects that did not react in a unique way to every single item, and you get character background, 90s nostalgia (perhaps the term is more "90s mockery'), references galore, and plenty of humor for your time.

The dialoguelogs of the comic are implemented very well in game by form of walkie-talkie and tablet conversations. These come almost a little too frequently, though they're always enjoyable.

If I had one issue with the game, it's that the minigames that for the game are too short and easy. The point and click puzzles are almost non-existent, which is okay because they're not really supposed to be the focus of the game (with the exception of one important puzzle which is solved by another character, which would be a major flaw except that it allows us to explore another room and help out as said character). But the minigames could be much more. Let the Simon Says game go on for double the iterations. Take the background on the security system away or make it faster. 

Tentative score is 9/10.

But Joey is so, so gay.

So it's a 10/10. Buy it!

34976755.review:
Well, I don't really tend to write reviews for, like, anything. But this game here deserves this and much more.

I have to say that, being a Homestuck fan, I was really hyped waiting for it, but nevertheless, I will make this review as objective as possible.

It's an awesome first act for a point and click game. If you are a Homestuck fan like me, you're going to really enjoy playing this, looking into every detail and gasping at every reference or in-depth look at thing related to the webcomic.

Now, that doesn't mean that this game can't be enjoyed by people who doesn't know Homestuck, quite the opposite, indeed, the story is tailored in a way that no knowledge of the webcomic is needed to enjoy it. Sure, you'll miss part of the appeal of the game, but you won't have any "What? Am I supposed to know something?" moment while playing Hiveswap: Act 1.

Pros:

- A really nice and unique art style, with very fluid animations.
- A great soundtrack to enjoy every stage of the game.
- It's easy enough to assure you won't get frustrated by not knowing what to do to continue the story.
- The narration is very enjoyable, with humour everywhere, surely to make you feel like you are playing the likes of Monkey Island or Hollywood Monsters.

Cons:

- Maybe a little bit too easy, indeed. If you only enjoy point and clicks adventures that make you squeeze you brain out in order to solve an almost unsolvable puzzle, you're not going to enjoy this game, but hey! they point it out themselves, so...

- It is only the first act of a 4 acts series, so... Yeah, it really leaves you wanting more once you finish it, I'm not gonna lie. But well... It's only 8$, so it's a fair quantity of content for that price.

With all said, while I REALLY recommend this game to everyone who loves good humour and a great story, I must also say that, if you can, wait untill more acts are out, or have enough distractions at hand for when you finnish this one and find yourself craving for more Hiveswap.

34976600.review:
If you love P&C games with good art and a ton of dialogue, then Hiveswap is for you.

The generous pricing model, to me, recouped the game's negatives which were: Sometimes frusterating navigation, a couple visual bugs, and even a single game-breaking bug.

Wish it didn't have those, but I was too busy having legitimate laughs to get hung up on it.

Soundtrack is on point as well.

Overall, I don't know how to recommend this to non-Homestuck fans. Even though the game is presented in a way that completely works for newcomers, a lot of the enjoyment I had was from being an already existing fan. 

It's only $8 so, hey, it's worth a shot, right?

34976591.review:
Being a big fan of Homestuck, I naturally backed this way back when it was first announced and had no name. All the trouble aside with Hussie being scammed out of his money in the production of this game, I have to say I was a little disappointed with just under 3 hours of content from the first act.

However, I do have to say, those were probably the best 3 hours I've had in a while. The dialogue is on point, the music is great and all the subtle hints to the Homestuck universe are fantastic. Overall, this is definitely for fans of the series, however it would probably be fun for anyone new to it as well. This is only one act, though, and there's 3 more to come from what I know, so we'll have to see what that holds, but so far I can say I'm absolutely into it.

34976323.review:
Been waiting for this game for a very long time, not as much as some other people, but I've still been looking forward to this for a while.  The game is beautifully drawn and it has all the humor I expected and enjoy from something based off of Homestuck.

The cutscenes are well done and the final one in the first act gave me chills.  The characters are adorable and well written.  It also explains foreign concepts to non-homestuck readers in simple and concise ways.

You definitely don't need to have read homestuck in order to enjoy this game, but there are a lot of jokes and info that you will pick up on if you did end up reading the comic.  All in all, I recommend this to all those who read the comic, those who haven't but are willing to try it out, and those that just like point and click adventures.  

One thing I will say though is that the first act is rather short if you just go ahead and try to progress, but seeing as how almost every combination of item has its own unique response, you can enjoy yourself experimenting to see what does what.

34976298.review:
[h1]This game is good![/h1]

So yeah, I caved and bought [b]HIVESWAP. IT IS NOT HOMESTUCK THE GAME IT IS HIVESWAP. THE ONLY SIMILAR THING IS THE UNIVERSE IT TAKES PLACE IN, YOU COWARDS.[b]

Anyways, I bought HIVESWAP expecting an advnture game, and I got...well, I got an adventure game! A fairly short one, according to all of the reviews. But honestly, what were you expecting from a game that's supposed to be episode one in a four part series? 

First thing I noticed is a pretty glaring flaw, and that is [i]the cutscenes don't work on my computer[/i]. Now, I'm not gonna blame the game for this, seeing as I'm playing it on an older laptop, and I bet if I were playing it on a newer machine, this problem wouldn't be occuring. But I'm not a huge fan of the fact that none of the cutscenes for the entire story are gonna load for me. If anyone knows how to correct this problem (orwheretowatchthecutscenesinorder) that would be awesome. 

Other than that, the game is pretty great! I'm a HUGE fan of the art style here, I really think it does a great job of encapsulating the space. [u]The puzzles are hard, but not impossible.[/u] We're not knee-deep in moon logic here, but you gotta be ready to use your thinking cap on this one. It's no goat puzzle, essentially. 

[u]The soundtrack is solid, using both classic homestuck soundfonts and some stuff from Undertale.[/u] I would say Toby Fox did the music, but if you're a fan of his work (which you are if you're into homestuck, let's be real here) you could've told on your own. I guess this is payment for Andrew letting him make most of Undertale in his basement. 

[u]I'd reccomend this game to anyone, homestuck fan or not.[/u] If you're not into homestuck, you'll miss out on some minor references, but there's not really anything about homestuck you NEED to know to get this game. No major puzzles are based around your knowledge of homestuck lore. If you ARE into homestuck, you'll get some of the references and jokes they make [spoiler] (the my pet monster in the hallway for example) [/spoiler]  but you have no real upperhand. 

[b][u]However, this is definitely a pure adventure game and should not be partaken in if you dislike that style.[/b][/u] This is not my FIRST experience with the genre, but I know that it really takes some brains to get some of this stuff done, and it might not be appealing to you to walk around a dusty mansion looking for d-batteries [spoiler] (THEY WERE IN THE  RADIO I SEARCHED THE WHOLE FREAKING HOUSE JESUS FUCKING CHRIST ON A CRACKER) [/spoiler] but you certainly need to work for reward here. So if you're looking into a first look into the adventure game genre, I would definitely suggest either this game if you want to REALLY challange yourself, or maybe try out one of the humongous entertainment games, which I believe are available on steam. 

Final score: numbers are irrelevant to human emotion and numbers other than 10/10 or 0/10 are useless. Just write your review and be done.

It's pretty great if you're a fan of Homestuck and enjoy Andrew Hussie's writing, the main issue I have is that it's very short for something that started development in 2012, but I also understand that some of those years were eaten up by Hussie working on the actual webcomic, the original developers not taking the project seriously, having to set up What Pumpkin studios/get an LLC and everything else. Pros -
Fun writing
Great art
Great music
Nostalgia
Cheap
Everything you try to combine in your inventory has unique dialogue when you try it
Everything you try to use items on has unique dialogue for each interaction
Very well detailed and nice to look at environments

Cons -
Animations can be a little janky
It is very short, about three hours long
The puzzles are very easy
Not enough time spent with Xevros

All in all, whether or not you think three hours of game is worth your $8 is up to you. I think the art and writing along with the music and replayability to get the achievements makes it worth the price. If you can't bring yourself to justify that, I'd recommend holding out until more of the acts are out. 

Overall I give it a solid 8.5/10 It's not perfect but it isn't a bad time, I look forward to seeing the rest of the parts.

34975377.review:
A funny, engaging point-and-click adventure that tells a great tale of sci-fi/suburban fantasy, regardless of whether you've read Homestuck.

Pros:
+ Great writing. Comedy is to be found in basically every scene, environment, and item interaction. The dynamic between characters is also very genuine.
+ Beautiful art/animation, especially the environments
+ Great soundtrack

Cons:
- Definitely on the shorter side, with no known release date for the next episode. Definitely stop and smell the roses with objects in the environment and incorrect item combos to get the best experience, don't speed through.
- Some interactions/UI (especially in the mock "battle" segments) are a little unclear

If you're interested in a bouncy, character-centric point and click adventure, this is a good place to look.

34975260.review:
I'm a homestuck fan and was pretty hyped about this game. Not enough to contribute to the kickstarter campaign back in the days, but fairly excited.

So when it was put on steam greenlight, I supported it, and when it was released, I immediately bought it.
I started playing it - and then the first act was over. If I had to guess: probably after a bit over two hours.

That is an incredibly short amount of time. 

During these two hours I had to play with massive black bars on my screen (because of some screen resolution bug? - apparently they plan to fix that with the next update).

During my time playing I certainly was entertained. Every item in the game can be combined with probably 95% of the other items available and will give you an reaction to it, which makes up much of the humor in this game. The characters are definitely interesting and homestuck-esque, as is the rest of the writing.

The backgrounds are also beautifully drawn, and the callbacks to the homestuck series hidden everywhere are very satisfying to find (even though a bit forced at times).

As a homestuck fan, who probably would've bought the game even if the overall reactions had been horrendous, I had fun.

Yet, I cannot with good conscience give a recommendation to it.

The short playtime, the extremely easy puzzles (with sometimes absurd solutions), the currently still bugged presentation, the soundtrack (definitely not as good as recent homestuck fan-albums), everything is basically bundled into an episode of an, for the foreseeable future, incomplete game, which on its own merits just doesn't stand out enough to justify a purchase. 

In the end, I just don't know if you'll receive $8 worth of entertainment from this.
If I had paid 32$ for a hypothetical hiveswap season-pass (which, as far as I know, will be 4 acts in total, and if all acts cost the same: 4*8$ = 32$), and this was what I received for my money - I think I'd be pretty annoyed.

TL;DR: If you are a hardcore homestuck fan: buy it. If you think homestuck was pretty okay or you don't know anything about it: don't.

34974982.review:
Więc.
To był najdłuższy styczeń w moim życiu (na obecny moment). Ale do rzeczy.

Czym jest Hiveswap? Jeżeli szukasz odpowiedzi na to pytanie to zapraszam do góry, ale prawdopodobnie już przeczytałeś ten opis. Patrzysz też pewnie, czy warto go kupić. Powiem szczerze - przez rozgrywkę będzie ci się wydawać, że trochę nudnawo, ale w momencie, gdy ujrzysz napisy końcowe już będziesz czekał na więcej. I w tym właśnie momencie sprzedasz duszę Hussie'mu. Więc jeżeli nie chcesz jej stacić (albo jej części) to nie grasz. Hiveswap oraz Homestuck (od którego wszystko się zaczęło) są uzależniające.

Teraz trochę na serio. Hiveswap jest odświerzonym podejściem do gier typu point-and-click. Nie znajdziesz tu suchych tekstów typu "tego przedmiotu nie da się połączyć/użyć itp.", każda, ale to każda interakcja ma swój własny opis. 

Zagadki są łatwe, ale potrafią czasem dać w kość jeżeli nie jest się uważnym. Sam osobiście zaciąłem się dwa razy, ale nie wiem czy to ze zmęczenia (po całym dniu pracy udało mi się usiąść do gry), czy to z mojej głupoty albo z winy samej gry. Niemniej zawsze jest obecna satysfakcja, która tylko bardziej nas wciąga.

Historia jest... średnia. Przynajmniej na początku się taka wydaje. Z każdą minutą chłoniesz świat i jesteś nim coraz bardziej zainteresowany i w momencie zakończenia czekasz na więcej. To jest punkt, od którego nie masz odwrotu.
Dla mnie jako dla fana Homestucka (hipster ze mnie... chyba?) świat był o wiele bardziej wciągający, ale jeżeli nie czytałeś Homestucka to nawet nie próbuj - nie przerobisz go szybko, a wiele nie stracisz z odczuć gry.

Pomówmy o muzyce, chociaż wiele tutaj nie ma do gadania, bo jest po prostu wybitna. NAWET NIE PRÓBUJ DYSKUTOWAĆ (tak na prawdę to wszystko zależy od gustu, ale śmiało - OST jest dostępny do odsłuchu na YT, więc posłuchaj i decyduj).

Rozgrywka - co tu dużo mówić. Przygodówka point-and-click, z paroma dodatkowymi elementami pluz puzle (o których już wspomniałem). Nie jest ona główną atrakcją, ale jest na wysokim poziomie.

Błędy... Jako, że jestem osobą, która gra w tytuły od Bohemii Interactive to mi one za bardzo nie przeszkadzały (może dlatego, że trafiły mi się z 2 razy, choć na dzień dzisiejszy, czyli 15/09/2017 krążą po internecie różne doniesienia o błędach. Lecz nie są one rażące.

Reasumując: lubisz czekać na gry lub aktualizacje (jesteś fanem VALVe i ich gier oprócz Doty 2), zwracasz głównie uwagę na muzykę i historię, to Hiveswap jest grą dla ciebie. Jeżeli nie, to cóż. Na YT są już gameplaye, więc obejrzyj, a jak będziesz chciał więcej to kup drugi akt (i kolejne - będzie ich razem 4, choć nie zdziwiłbym się, gdyby nagle się okazało, że to nie byłby koniec).  Albo dorwij grę na wyprzedaży (trochę poczekasz, ale cóż poradzić).

34973056.review:
Hiveswap - это своеобразный приквел к комиксу Homestuck, который повествует о убийственной игре, где ты можешь даже стать "богом", в комической форме и с безумным автором, который обожал делать пробелы в полгода. Несмотря на то, что игру анонсировали на январь, январь всё же наступил в сентябре и игра вышла. Мой обзор совершенно никак не держит обиду на Эндрю и команду, потому что ожидание в много-много лет не прошли для меня даром. 
Несмотря на любовь к комиксу Homestuck, мне хотелось бы составить обзор чисто от лица игрока, без любви к предыдущим творениям Эндрю Хасси, в том числе и Сыщика, и тому подобное. 

Обзор чисто по первому акту.(!)

Плюсы:
- Смена графики с 3D на почти что полное 2D - чудесное решение. Игра смотрится красиво, как старые квест-игрушки, где всё вокруг было в 2D-шной графике. Модельки героев смотрятся иногда нелепо на фоне, но и не дешёво. Всё очень красиво прорисовано, катсцены вполне милые и играть в такую игру приятно. Нет резких и слепящих цветов. Пара хоррор-картинок спрятана для особо страждущих - оно и славно.
- Шутки остались, но тут же минус - мне кажется, что по сравнению с комиксом их довольно маловато, как и различных отсылок или гэгов. Игра кажется более серьёзной. 
- This gay shieet is nice.
- Расширение вселенной и возможность поиграть за троллей, о которых в комиксе было (ИМХО) не так много бытовой информации. 
- Приятные персонажи. Все разные и интересные.
- Механика игры. Атаки Джоуи в стиле чечетки или балетные па, чтобы уйти из режима страйфа - это круто. 
- Отсылки и ирония. К комиксу и не только. 
- Хороший сюжет. 
- Милые сцены и переписки. 
- Возможность потренировать английский на каверзных и сленговых выражениях. С другой стороны - слов там не так много, как в некоторых играх и в самом комиксе. Больше действий. Так что в принципе, игра подходит даже для тех, кто не про в английском. 
- Получить достижения не так просто и иногда нужно перепроходить многие моменты, если их пропустил или выбрал второй вариант. Советую читающим этот обзор - сохраняйтесь как можно чаще. 
- Фон главного меню меняется в зависимости от событий.
- Экшооон. 
- Креативный подход к битвам, оружию и миру. 

Минусы:
- Хасси, где обещанные "не будет как в других квестах невозможность скрафтить всё со всем".
- Функция подсказок не работает и не понятно зачем эта кнопка. Поржать? Nah. 
- Катсцены время от времени зависают. За наигранные часы в игру, у меня в трех из четырёх сохранений глючили катсцены и пришлось смотреть их на Youtube. При этом у меня компьютер довольно мощный, а не микроволновка. 
- Акт 1 показался очень коротким. Возможно я много играю во всякие инди-кликалки, но было бы классно, если в следующих актах было больше пасхалок на локации, больше кликабельных предметов, которые давали бы информацию. Не то чтобы минус, скорее nah. 


Те, кто поставят отрицательные отзывы за отсутствие русского языка - будут сожраны мобами Sburb'а. 

В общем и целом, пока что первый акт 10/10.

34971659.review:
HIVESWAP: Act 1 brings the distinct flavour of 90s nostalgia into the Homestuck universe, beautifully displayed in rich detail. Be warned, however, that a bug that I (and many others apparently) faced caused this beauty to be tarnished slightly. When opening the game, the aspect ratio is messed up. You can choose a new display ratio, and it *looks* like it might've fixed itself - but it hasn't. If you experience this issue, relaunch the game, or else the backgrounds are going to appear incorrectly at times.

Back to the review. Hiveswap is a short adventure game with minimal difficulty and no "dead ends" from what I could see. The battle system is a neat spin on the way STRIFE works in Homestuck, and from what I could see it has no failure state. Think of battles in this as a series of puzzles that you have time to fail and get right. The puzzles don't involve any real violence, the main charatcer speaks for herself on this: "I don't use guns."

What you get instead of anything above "I whack the critter" is a very funny and entertaining battle system, with the iconic bizarre one-liners of STRIFE combat acting as gags or hints. The puzzles in combat do suffer, however, from a lack of clarity. There are times in combat where you'd think an option would work... and it doesn't. However this is an issue that all adventure games suffer, the dreaded "macgyver" solutions. But to say that Hiveswap goes to extremes in the way traditional adventure games do would be a stretch - rather, you can have multiple items that seemingly serve the same purpose, but only one works.

The environment is littered with interactable objects, and as any astute player would be wont to do, you'll spend most of your time clicking through the background looking for items. If you're the kind of person who couldn't care less about the story, and just look for items to solve puzzles, you'll probably only spend 20-40 minutes on this game. I'm a big fan of Homestuck, and spent a lot of time reading item descriptions and looking around this new part of its universe eagerly. 

But that brings us to another point of contention for potential newcomers: the writing. I find the goofy and oftentimes slightly crude writing of Andrew Hussie to be amusing; it fits the theme of "a bunch of kids doing stuff" well, and can be very funny when it wants to be. However if you're the kind of person who's coming here looking for a tightly written and executed exploration of characters, then perhaps come into this game with an open mind. None of this is to say that Andrew's writing is bad, or lacklustre, or anything of the sort - heck, most adventure games also have corny writing. Rather I'd like to warn potential buyers that you're not walking into an oscar worthy piece of literary masterclass; rather, an emotional, epic, drama-abound script about kids being kids. It's great, but it's not for everyone.

Speaking of tone and atmosphere the music does the game much justice. I've seen comments about the music transitions being jarring but personally I never had issues with it. I did however spend a lot of time happily exploring with unobtrusive but pleasant melodies filling my ears. Homestuck has never been short of good music and Hiveswap is no exception. Don't let my description fool you however, when the game needs to get into full gear the soundtrack is happy to oblidge. 

The story of Hiveswap so far has been very engaging. As an avid fan of Homestuck I found myself drawn, yet again, to the exploration of themes such as society and class, as well as the intriguing inclusion of green and red spirals... As someone who has no experience with the Homestuck universe, however, the game still has much to offer. It isn't quick to throw you into themes unbeknownst to anybody but the "niche audience." The game offers a steady introduction to the themes of the universe, with only a few things sticking out to me as lacking explanation; namely the STRIFE system itself.

The only remaining topic worth touching on is the animation. The idle animations for characters are very expressive and speak to their personalities; but they feel lacking. Rather than being fluid and pleasing to look at, they are stilted, as if they were merely a few frames thrown together. This becomes less apparent over time but it was still distracting at first. The game features many cutscenes, some of which are mostly fully animated and beautiful (the opening and ending cutscenes come to mind, the latter being wonderfully animated) - while the rest are stills being played with sound effects and music. I wish we had seen more of the former, but I understand the team were on a budget, and respect that they used their money wisely.

Overall I would recommend this game to anybody with £5 to spare, an open mind looking for a goofy, funny, and rather dramatic story, and a love of puzzles. If you are none of these then it might still be worth a try, but the refund option may turn out to be your best friend. If I had to rate Hiveswap as how I enjoyed it as a fan: 10/10. If I had to rate it as a consumer: 7/10. Hiveswap is let down by its length and minor technical issues. Even while taking my time and reading everything I could, I finished the game in about two hours and forty minutes. I thoroughly enjoyed that entire time, with no dips in my enjoyment whatsoever - but it was still a rather short time.

I will be back when Act 2 releases to continue the story, and hopefully, continue to enjoy myself immensely.

34970944.review:
This is like the first game that I've been very hyped for and not been disappointed in afterwards in like... 5 years! 

It's a bit short if you dont have the attention span for reading stuff like i do, since a lot of the gametime comes from trying out different things with eachother and discovering all the fun text and achievements! Definitely has to be played a few times, if only to check out the different dialog options. 

The characters are interesting and likeable, and have very high potential for future development. I was slightly scared that the writing might not be able emulate that homestuck feel, but it's amazingly faithful. The game's rating is in no way holding back the plot, the jokes, the characters or their dialogs.

The music is amazing! Not much else to comment on that front. Just wow.

The puzzles have reasonable solutions (this is a point-and-click, youre [i]supposed[/i] to be clicking everything) and it [i]does[/i] give you hints for some of them (not too terribly visible ones, but you'll notice when you really start looking for the solution).

Accidental text skipping might happen occasionally, what with the slight delay in the textbox appearing after some cutscenes and although most things can be re-read, there are some one-time things you wont be able to read again unless you replay.

At moments there may be some weird and sometimes abrupt sound and/or cutscene transitions, and occasional graphical glitches may occur when playing(most of these are fixed by fiddling with the graphics options and restarting, like the black bars for example). 

I personally didnt have any crashes, only the black bars glitch, and the first strife had a VERY long loadtime which made the game unresponsive for a bit. It recovered.

I really, REALLY recommend you play HIVESWAP if you can! You dont need to have read Homestuck to enjoy it, and I'm very much looking forward to Act 2.

34970888.review:
What to say about Hiveswap? I absolutely love Hiveswap!
Sure it came out literal years after it was supposed to, and sure the game length is shorter than the time it took me to read Jailbreak. But you know what? Andrew Hussie has done it again.
Okay in all seriousness... for those of you who are a fan of Homestuck and possibly Undertale, this is RIGHT up your alley, with all the charm and unique humour you've come to expect from Homestuck and more.

34970628.review:
A fun point and click adventure game that'll appeal to both fans of the genre with no prior experience with Homestuck, and to die-hard Homestuck fans. The story follows new characters living over a decade before the start of the comic, so doesn't require any prior knowledge; all relevant concepts are explained as you go. If you are a fan, you'll quickly notice links between the new cast and some existing characters though. *WONK*

It keeps close to the tone of the original comic, though backs a little away from the aggressive tone and removes the swearing for a more accessible overall feel (I didn't think Homestuck with clean language would work, but it actually does hold up well, way better than Namco High did), and has an absolutely ridiculous amount of unique dialogue for attempts to combine unexpected items.

The visuals are charming and the musical score is a great mixture of bombastic and whimsical.

Overall, I'd recommend this for people who want a fun, lighthearted adventure that's not excessively taxing on the old thinkpan.

34969872.review:
The design gimmick is that there are an absolutely preposterous number of text reactions to putting different items together with each other and with the environment features. I've spent hours in the first room and haven't accomplished anything quest-related, just read what the game says when you click stuff together.

This verboseness has some small downsides... firstly, the music gets repetitive. Secondly, if you're offended by grammatical errors, watch out -- the text is absolutely LADEN with them. One in twenty text boxes has one, which is a lot when you're reading thousands of the things. Might be even one in ten. The game badly needs a few proof reading passes.

Humour is dark and relatively consistent.

Animation is kind of jittery and framey, but you're not really playing a 2D text adventure game for the animation, even if it is 2017.

I'm enjoying it so far.

34969534.review:
The game has amazing visuals, good music, and endearing writing that you'll feel right at home with if you're familiar with Andrew Hussie's other works. Because of all those reasons, I can look past the minor bugs, the horrendously limited video settings, or even the fact that it's supposedly only 3 hours long. But one fatal flaw that I cannot forgive is that it's the most poorly optimized game I've ever played, no joke. 
Seriously, as good as the visuals are, a game of this magnitude could have been pulled off in the early to mid 2000's and run butter smooth on low end machines of that era no problem. Instead, the game overheats my admittedly dated laptop in a matter of minutes, and chugs during cutscenes. By comparison, I can play both seasons of TellTale's The Walking dead for hours and only occasionally have to close it to let my laptop cool down. There's no excuse as to why I can run those games, but not this. 
I'm not forgetting that this is a freaking 2D point and click adventure. HD or not, what could possibly be eating up so many resources? The most taxing thing it would need to do is render a few layers of animated bitmaps. The other things like music, cutscenes, and UI are all things that have been around and haven't been innovated on since 2000. I suspect it's due to a combination of flimsy programming, and a bunch of junk tacked on by the Unity engine that the game doesn't even need. The game honestly would have been better off being built from the ground up.

You might not be able to empathize with me if you have even a decent computer by today's standards, but if you're like me and you're too broke to afford a new computer to replace your toaster that you've managed to keep running for half a decade, then I can't recommend this game. The minimum requirements page is misleading, and even then, it still shouldn't take that much processing power to run a 2D point & click adventure.

34969016.review:
[i]A reasonably priced short burst of well written point and click adventure fun, far from perfect but promising of a brighter future, maybe wait until Act 2 or 3 are out before picking this up if you are unsure. You do not need to be a Homestuck fan to enjoy this game.[/i]

It has been many years since I backed this game's kickstarter and almost a year since Homestuck itself has ended, it has been a long winding road. I cannot separate this review from the Homestuck fan that still resides inside of me, so this review is MOSTLY for other Homestuck fans, but also contains general critique.

HIVESWAP: Act 1 is the first part of the HIVESWAP series of point and click adventure games that follow a handful of rambunctious teens in an interplanetary adventure. The game is based on Homestuck the scarily popular and confusing (In a good way) webcomic which itself is styled on a partially text adventure partially point and click game that evolves into a lot more.

[h1]What it gets right:[/h1]
[list]
[*]HIVESWAP is no graphical masterpiece but its style is very charming and occasionally beautiful, the animations especially are a lot of fun, it's a joy whenever they are on screen.
[*]The writing for Act 1 is good, it clearly sets the humorous tone immediately and slowly eases you into the dialogues which Homestuck is known for. By the end of Act 1 you are having full blown conversations, much like in Homestuck, but in a much more digestible format as message by message is easier than a wall of text. It also starts simple on the typing quirks, which was the right choice. There are dialogue options and it adds a nice layer of interactivity throughout the conversations though they ultimately seem to have no real consequence in the story.
[*]The music is fantastic, it is hard to live up to the lightning in a bottle that is Homestuck's soundtrack, with a lot of fantastic early work by Tobyfox (Now of Undertale fame) and a plethora of other community artists, but Hiveswap does a damn good job of trying. James Roach and Toby Fox have made a refreshing and catchy soundtrack with just enough musical nods to leave any Homestuck fan happy.
[*]References are light and unobtrusive, this can be a real problem when popular things get spin-offs but I feel Hiveswap handles things correctly in this regard, it doesn't feel like I needed to read Homestuck to play this game and enjoy its style and humour.
[/list]

[h1]What it needs to improve:[/h1]
[list]
[*]As a basic point and click HIVESWAP: Act 1 comes across as a little flaccid. It isn't put across as a MYST style puzzle game so there isn't any expectations for hard puzzles to be crossed and it works hard to guide the player which overall makes you feel a little babied by the end of this first act. None of the solutions give you that feeling of overcoming something, I would hope that in later acts things get a little more challenging.
[*]There are a handful of jarring frame by frame scenes that would have done a lot better to be animated, the most glaring example being after doing some [spoiler]tap dancing in the basement.[/spoiler] I feel these scenes contrast harshly when the great animated scenes are still fresh in your mind, I hope the frame by frame is used sparingly in later Acts.
[*]The length of this game leaves a lot to be desired, I think price-wise even a penny higher would have been a risk. I think myself and a lot of other Homestuck fans will be looking for a lot more to chew on and the general public wont get as much mileage out of this like a Homestuck fan would. My first play through took 3 hours, I didn't rush, I looked at pretty much everything I could, I DIDN'T however use every item I have on everything I could look at, and the game does genuinely have a lot of unique text for this, which is great, I'll probably come back to this game and do that, but can I say everyone who will buy this game will do that? Probably not. 
I REALLY HOPE that this series is going to follow a Homestuck like formula in which the first act is the shortest and the later acts are longer in length. They have stated this series will be in 4 acts which would end up at 9 hours altogether if the first act is anything to go off of, which is nothing to sneeze at but I think closer to 12 - 14 would really benefit Hiveswap as a whole, especially if it decides to get anywhere near as complex as homestuck does.
[/list]

Overall I would say this game has a winning formula, its problem that it feels a little under-cooked in areas and that the portion size might not fill everyone's belly, as a starter it still leaves you wanting more, I'm excited for the next 3 courses and I wouldn't doubt that other Homestuck fans are too.

34969010.review:
It's a 3 hour game. While based on Homestuck it doesn't require Homestuck. Atleast in Act 1 it's just nods to the origins. 

It is also clearly set in the 1990s. It's not so much in your face about it, but 90s kids will just see little things here and there that are clearly 90s things.

If you are the kind of person who can handle episodic games, able to pick up the next chapter no problem. I can recommend this to get right now.

if you aren't, maybe wait till HIVESWAP has completed.

Homestuck isn't required reading for this game, which is good. Though if you've played this, and enjoyed it, I would recommend giving Homestuck a read. For three reasons.
1. To pass the time. Homestuck is so long, it may take you months, maybe even a year or so to read through it depending on your pace. 
2. To get background and little nods within the game. Some of the stuff mentioned in Act I will likely get explained, like Moirails.
3. Learning of the phenomenon that resulted in Newgrounds crashing. Cause yes, Homestuck caused that. Ironicly, it fit with the name and setting with the page/flash animation that caused it.. Cascade.

So yeah, that's basically what I have to say for it. Whether or not you're a Homestuck fan, there may be something here for you if you're a fan of point and click games.
Music's good too.

34968885.review:
Okay so I finally finished Act 1 and I believe it's about time I talk about it properly ; 
Hiveswap is a pretty good game. Sure, it's short. But, well, if you take some time to mess around with items and explore, you get some interesting developpement considering its only the first act ; some people announced only 2 hours of gameplay, I'm at 5 and i plan to replay again sometimes soon to explore some more, so it depends how invested you are I guess.

But when you rule this out, the game is really good imo. The characters are very likable and dynamic - even the ones who're not introduced properly yet, the artstyle of the game is really pleasant and reminds me of the comic without being too sketchy, the musics... are good, since james roach and toby fox did the job, and the writting is honestly well done even though Hussie wasn't the one in charge. 

If you're searching for a game including reflexion and deep puzzles, or action and reflexes, I can't recommand Hiveswap to you. Hiveswap is a game about exploring, going with the flow, experimenting with various items or simply following a story without worrying about how good you're doing. If you're the kind of person who'd attempt to spray spices on a pigeon, feed a poster or that kind of dumb shit, then yes, consider Hiveswap because the game expects you to test it. 
Also, I saw some non-homestuck persons wondering if the game was accessible for them : yes, it is! It happens 15 years before HS begins, so most of the characters weren't even born, and overall the game explains pretty much everything important. It just involves some references you won't catch, but nothing really problematic.
Anyway I'm hella hyped to see the rest. WP announced the other acts will take less time to come than this one, hopefully in 2018 we'll get something!

Totally worth the fiver for it, and the soundtrack is worth that bit more too. The writing and story are on point, and frequently had me genuinely laughing, not that amused snort that is often equated to "lol". Yeah, it's not the longest game ever, and there are a few finnicky niggles here and there (The resolution starts out at the minimum, and you need to restart the game for the resolution change to take effect, the cutscenes are a little glitchy), but its certainly worth all of five quid for 3 hours first playthrough and double that to mess around and hunt for things, when its just _that funny and engaging_. Maybe someone new to HS would be a little confused with the trolls but overall, I think they pulled off accessability well.

If you start playing expecting the whole story you'll be disappointed. This is Act 1 of 4 (supposedly), and there's talk of a counterpart game series telling the other side of the swap later called Hauntswitch. That said, it doesn't end on a massive cliffhanger, merely a open pause, and I doubt the next parts will take as long as Act 1 took to materialise (They've been working on them simultaneously, the engine is written, etc). Maybe you' also be disappointed too if you'd built up grand expectations in the meantime, but for what it is? I'd say it's a new classic of point-and-click.

Now if you'll excuse me, I'm gonna go grab some lunch and dive back in to go hunting for things.

34968033.review:
I've been a fan of Homestuck for a few years now. I got into it maybe two or three years before the comic ended and I followed it pretty religiously to the end. So naturally going in, I was expecting Hiveswap to have the requirement of understnading the comic and all its complexity.

I am happy to report that is not the case. While reading the comic will make you catch certain references and draw conclusions, Hussie is 100% correct when he says there is NO requirement to read the comic to understand this game. So if you've never read Homestuck or are thinking about reading it, this game is still really good.

The achievements are ridiculous and that is part of the charm. The writing is over the top and that's sort of Hussie's brand of humor. If you like quirky writing Hiveswap is the game for you, even if you're not a fan of Homestuck. That being said though if you're not a fan of quirky writing, you probably won't enjoy this game.

The soundtrack is excellent, there is nothing more to say about that. Get the soundtrack edition, you won't regret it.

The game also is very easy to pick up and play even if you've never played point-and-click adventure games before. It avoids the pitfalls of the genre such as accidentally putting the game in an unwinnable state (there's always a way to progress in Hiveswap).

I would highly recommend it and for $8 it'll be a great way to spend 2-4 hours. Will definitely play again.

34967999.review:
Homestuck has always had a place in my heart, and those who are fans of Homestuck know that it is known for going on hiatus. This game itself took 5 years to make. Did it take 5 years to make just Act 1, or do they have in store for us Acts 2, 3 ,4, etc. ready for us right off the bat? If it only took them 5 years to make one Act, we are going to have a problem.

Pros:
- Wonderful story, and fond throwback to the original Homestuck.
- Act 1 recaps the world of Homestuck for those who need a refresher, or are new to Homestuck and it does this quite nicely .
- The art style is wonderful, and it is nice to see a much beloved comic in this art style.
- The puzzels are wonderful, and help convey the story nicely.

Cons:
- I waited 5 years for a few hours of gameplay. There needs to be more to this, and if they cannot deliver fast enough, they will have some sad and angry people on their hands.
- Not all that bad, but the combats aren't really combats. I'll give the benefit of the doubt since it is a story game.

Overall, this game was wonderful to play and delved me deeper into the Homestuck world. The characters have a nice introduction and everything, and things are really just set up well for the first and upcoming acts. There just needs to be more meat to this all. . . There simply is just not enough content.

8.5/10

34967728.review:
I feel like the biggest decider for this game will be how they handle the sequential acts. This is the most important factor due to the very short length of the game. (Roughly 2 hours, or 4-5 hours if you interact every item with every other item to read their text boxes.)

Best case: It's free DLC. This is highly unlikely, but would be a welcome surprise.

Worst case: It's another $8 game. This is fairly likely, and I think this would cause a lot of non-die-hard fans to lose interest in continuing this series.

Middleground: It's a lesser-priced DLC, perhaps closer to $5. I feel like this is the most likely outcome, and will keep the majority of players purchasing the acts as they release. Maybe a "season pass" is released as well.

Other than that, there's not much I can say about the game itself that others haven't already. It's a point-and-click adventure game, so if you're not prepared to search the same 2 screens for an hour to find that 1 item you need to progress, maybe reconsider. You don't have to know anything about Homestuck to enjoy the game, but there are, of course, Homestuck references everywhere. Toby Fox did a fantastic job on the music, I always enjoy his work.

In my personal opinion, as a long-time Homestuck fan and point-and-click puzzle-solving extraordinaire, I would highly recommend this game, and all the upcoming acts.

34967462.review:
Hiveswap is a pretty decent game...I'd say an eight of of ten at most. 

Can I just say, I adored the dialouge between our two siblings and how quirky each character is in their own special way. Joey is once of the more likable characters I've seen in entertainment in recent years and I personally love how she knows what she wants to do and she's going to get it as soon as she can. As for the rest of the characters, I do hope to see more development on Jude, but hopefully in Hauntswitch, and Xefros was fun to read though he does need more development so we can really see the type of character he is.

I love the way you can tell how the characters lived and what they liked just by looking at your surroundings of where they lived, Joey's room and the kitchen expecially. The visuals were just outstanding, the backgrounds, even if initially concept art, and just so damn appealing to look and and they tell the viewer so much and I love that they get that point around and don't even need words for it but they go the extra mile by adding a shit ton of funny dialouge to each and every little thing in room. Cutscenes were smooth and crisp, I loved to watch them when my computer would actually properly load them, heh. 

Now the soundtrack....oh my god the soundtrack. IT'S JUST AMAZING. I love how the music in the game always is able to convey the atmosphere and feeling of the scene, whether it's goofy and laid back or to make you ready for action. It always gets it's point around and that's great for music. The motifs are lovely and I even bought the soundtrack included version of the game. Toby Fox's composition was incredible, but I think what made it really shine was James Roach's great instrument choices. (I personally really like SERPENT GENESIS)

As for controls, they were honestly a bit wonky, but not unbearably bad. Places in the manor were tedious to get around because of how inconviently the other room enterences were and how you would often accidentally click of them. But system wise it was fun and I love the charming puzzles, though a couple of them were really farfetched and I had to look up how to do them! 

I have to say, there's a lot of cons to this game, but most of them are so small that someone just enjoying it for the narrative wouldn't notice. I'd have to say the biggest things that bothered me in my first playthrough of this was the ocassional skip of dialouge (since any key goes to the next text bubble) and how, even on one of the lowest resolutions, the cutscenes were extremely slow and sometimes would make my game freeze. There were also times where I felt like the game wasn't complete just because of the sprite animations only having four to eight frames per second, which is honesly kind of sad to look at. There are also times where some of the dialouge, specifically between Joey and Xefros, where text feels unnessary or drawn out as if it's a filler episode in a comedy show. A very small conplaint is how there were just these moments of almost silence where I think they could have tried to work more on sound design of the monsters to help get the atmosphere of the scene across. 

A complaint that doesn't apply to most of the first buyers (like myself) but will probably impact a lot of people later on if this game gets really popular is that if felt like there was an extreme inbalance of the "Homestuck feel" that it was promising. At the start of the game Homestuck readers are refreshed with even just the text font but throughout the Half-Harley manor you see refrences scattered in almost every corner and I loved that...but when we got to Alternia it just felt well...devoid of anything Homestuck. Sure they have Alternia as a planet and the species and all that but the refernces were clearly toned down A LOT. I wasn't too personally effected by this but it just felt really off to me during my first play through. At the same time though, I feel like for someone who hasn't read Homestuck all these references are shoved down their throat and they're finally relieved of that once they get to the Alternian scenes. 

Another small gripe, though many people have talked about it, is the awkward switching between characters and how once you just get invested in Joey, she gets taken away from you and the bizzare Jude Harley is who you're playing as. It's just ackward and feels forced on you, and it was really sudden, I think it would have just been better to make the scenes with Jude in them cutscenes and keep the playable characters limited to Joey and Xefros. That is until Hauntswitch when Jude gets his own game, then it makes a lot more sense. 

Those were just my main gripes though, and the pros about this game definately overweigh the cons; plus, some of those cons won't even been noticed by people. I smiled a lot through playing Hiveswap and I think the dialouge and main visuals can make up for most of it's cons. It's just simply a fun game, though I think that after people experiance all of the combinations and get each achievement, it whill have a clear lack of replay value, that is until the next game comes out and we see what will become of Hiveswap.

34967320.review: Good game, but a lot of the cutscenes are broken and it doesn't support my native resolution. However, the great art and fantastic music by Toby Fox (creator of Undertale) make up for it, especially since they were cheated out of $788k by The Odd Gentlemen for King's Quest.

34967268.review:
Really powerful opener for a promising game series. Might occupy a place at the top of the adventure game heap. The puzzle solving, especially the 'battles', was fun and inventive, the settings were lush with things to explore and concepts to combine. The way the game would sometimes tease you for choosing ridiculous combinations and sometimes reward you with a surprisingly eloquent, deep and/or revealing quip makes taking your time and exploring your environment feel immensely rewarding. Some of the most poignant moments were revealed by something as simple as Joey trying out her heirloom on everything.
 
The art and animation are absolutely jaw-dropping, this is one of the most gorgeous games I've seen in a long time, the music is unique and perfectly attuned to the long-term looping that slow exploration and environment-testing lends itself to, and the story is captivating, with mostly lovable and always interesting characters, and with the themes explored in ultra-long-form in Homestuck honed to a keen edge of brevity. A lot of people I've talked to who have never read or didn't finish Homestuck seemed to appreciate this game quite a bit, so I feel like they are on the right track even if you remove the bias I possess of already liking Hussie's other work quite a bit.
 
I paid a decent chunk of change to help get this thing made, I waited patiently, and I can honestly say I'm happy with where the outcome is headed.

So as a pretty big homestuck fan i can say that this game is very refreshing to play. It takes the Universe of homestuck but only very briefly touches at the original story. This is a new story in a different time. The overall atmoshpere is a total nostalgia bomb what with it being set in the nineties. I can basically sum it up to this:
[list]If you enjoyed homestuck, buy this game.[/list][list]If you enjoy good writing, buy this game.[/list][list]If you like puzzles, buy this game.[/list]
Even if you're not a homestuck fan, it's still a solid point and click adventure game, and you don't even have to know anything about the universe to really play it. Anything important is taught to you in game.

tl;dr: You don't have to be a homestuck fan to enjoy this game. It's worth the money if you're into point and click games.

Holy shit it's been five years since the Kickstarter what am I doing with my life??? Still got the keychain though. 

In all seriousness, the worst part of this game is that it's too short. I got through the whole thing in about two or three hours of playtime, and that was me at my dumbest. I spent like five minutes on the milk puzzle alone. Presumably there will be more and we will be able to figure out what happened to Dammek etc., so not that big a drawback. I'm surprised I got so invested though. I actually wanna know what happens with these characters! 

The art is gorgeous, every background is teeming with details. There's a lot of eighties and nineties nostalgia, given the setting, and Joey's room in particular delighted me to no end. The music is fun and chirpy. There's a bit of lag at times, and some cutscenes won't play, but my laptop is a piece of shit so some of that might be on my end. The strife stuff is a bit weird, like there's not really any fighting so much as there is Joey tapdancing her way out of things. 

I'll definitely pick up the next act, if only to see Dammek and Jude interact on Earth and be conspiracy bros.

How to describe Act 1 of Hiveswap? Hmm.
Well for starters, as a long time fan of the Homestuck series I have to say it's very true to the universe it's set in, and every bit as much detailed. The same could be said for the character actions- it's very reminicent of its predesessor. The effort gone into the sylladex and the various combinations was enjoyable as were the little puzzles strewn about the game which were not too bad in terms of dicciculty.
 As for the downside to this game, the only real issue I had was with the cutscenes which were pretty common. The issue however did go away after so tinkering with the video settings, and even though thats not an ideal situation its understandable- having played it within hours of the release ... there's bound to be bugs somewhere. 
Overall I look forward to the next few acts in the making and of course Hauntswitch. I would really suggest this game (but i'd wait a few days until some bugs are fixed) for those looking for an interesting or detailed/easter-egg ridden setting those just looking for a new story or just to have fun!

I look forward to Act 2 and Hauntswitch!

34964832.review:
Absolutely loved it and can't wait for the next Act! Recommend to any fans of Homestuck!

That being said though, I'm not sure I can recommend this for someone who isn't a big fan. Pretty much all of the non-pop culture references will go right over your head, and there will be plenty of things you just straight up will not understand, such as what the hell Strife or a Sylladex is and why do these kids have such goofy or dangerous weapons, why do some of the characters talk in such a nonsensical way, who is their babysitter or father and why are they important. Many of these things are barely touched upon, if at all and will leave you with questions that won't get answered at least in this Act, but have already been long ago answered in the comic.

At the same time though, I have no way of experiencing this game with zero knowledge of Homestuck, so maybe not knowing these things is a lot better for you. And if you did get this game knowing nothing about Homestuck I HIGHLY recommend reading the comic assuming you enjoyed the game, because it's literally this game but focusing on different kids doing different things, is way longer, and you don't have direct control over where the character goes. Except on the few occasions you do have control over a character.

I'm not normally someone who likes Point and Click adventures, and I also despise episodic games, but to be completely honest I absolutely loved Hiveswap, and I don't really mind the episodic nature with Hiveswap specifically because it's like waiting for an update of the comic. I'm pretty sure God Emperor Hussie specifically told the devs to make it episodic so he could [strike]drag out our suffering[/strike] let us enjoy it longer. So I'll suffer through it, and if you've sold your soul to Hussie like I have, you know you will too, don't bother lying to yourself.

[spoiler]And if you haven't sold your soul yet run while you can, it's too late to save me, save yourself[/spoiler]

Hopefully acts 3-4 will be really long. The soundtrack is just amazing. Overall, this game is Great, and is probably short to keep the real meat of the story in the following acts. Highly recommended.

Again, the game is very short, especially having been worked on for 5 years. but overall, we can't yet determine if we are getting the bang for our buck.

>Cons

34964771.review:
I've been a dear dear fan of homestuck for many years. It's one of the many things that got me started online, and I wouldn't know the people I know today were it not for the comic. That being said, I would've loved Hiveswap in any form it came in, and would've bought it regardless. The thirst for new content is and has always been endless. However, I didn't expect Hiveswap to be as charming as it is! It is no way a faithful recreation of the comic itself, but instead a charming retake on all the specific parts of Andrew Hussie's writing style I loved!
By far though, I love the sprinkling of the 90's all through out the story. From Jude's treehouse, to the fact that Joey has to wait for her moden to boot up before she can log onto the internet. I've only played the first act, and I'm already in love with all of the characters!
I greatly await the next installment, and I am endlessly proud of what the dev team has been able to produce despite numerous setbacks over the years!

34964638.review:
Hiveswap is finally out!  And it's...  Good?   Yep!  Hiveswap is pretty much a love-letter to 90s, adventure games, and homestuck.  What's homestuck?  That's not important!  While Hiveswap is based off of homestuck, I was actually surprised to see that they kept their word about homestuck knowledge being unecessary.  There's a ton of references thrown in, but they shouldn't look too out of place if you haven't read any.

But what about the gameplay?  The puzzles are decently challenging, but usually after finding the solution I think "oh, that actually makes sense."  It's not the type of game where you'll have to try everything with everything to figure out some insane logic puzzle that makes no sense, and in fact the game usually hints pretty hard at what you need to do for most of the puzzles.   Speaking of trying everything with everything, you don't HAVE to, but you'll probably WANT to, since there's a unique line of dialogue for almost every single combination of items.  That being said, there are a few interactions that don't have any lines.  It didn't happen very often, but it would have been nice if there was a generic "that's not how that's used" just to fill in these gaps.

(edit: there's apparently been an update that's supposed to fix some interactions not having lines, so that's pretty cool.  Also I forgot to mention, there's a hint button in the game, but it was completely unhelpful.  Maybe future acts will feature harder puzzles that require hints, but for now you should be able to deduce most problems by just reading the hints the text provides.)

The soundtrack is... weird.  It wasn't bad, but the whole thing has a fairly unique sound to it that's kind of hard to describe.  It's not the type of soundtrack I would purchase, but there were definitely some songs I did enjoy.  Also, the battle music kind of cut in really suddenly and poorly.  The transition was pretty bad.  Other than that though I didn't notice any issues with transitions between songs. 

(Edit:  I've relistened to a few of the songs and they definitely grow on you.  I still don't think the album is really worth purchasing at full price, but you may consider getting the game + soundtrack bundle.)

I absolutely loved the art style.  It completely captured the feeling of homestuck and the 90s.  The houses are filled with all sorts of random trash and posters, and the majority of it is interactable.  The animation is also really good.  It's not super fluid at times, but even the lower quality cutscenes look very nice.

The writing is also surprisingly good.  They do a good job of introducing the alien concepts without just having a massive info dump, and the jokes were pretty on point as well.  There were a few grammar and spelling mistakes, but nothing too major.  I will say though the main character, Joey Claire, is a bit boring.  She does have a variety of interests, but other than that she acts pretty typically for a main character.  Luckily, the other characters have been a lot more interesting.  

The game, however, is pretty short.  It took me about 4 hours to get through it in one sitting.  How much time it takes the average person will probably vary a lot though, since you can waste a lot of time just interacting with random things.  Normally I would say hold off on purchasing a game this short, but for  8 dollars it really isn't too much of an investment.

Overal, I really enjoyed my time playing hiveswap.  If you're a fan of adventure games, you should check it out.  I definitely look forward to ACT 2, even if we will probably have to wait another 5 years for that to come out.

34963959.review:
Well. Its here. After 5 years of hype, HIVESWAP: Act 1 has finally been released. 

The gameplay resembles a classic point and click adventure style of game, with beautifully drawn backgrounds, HEAPS of dialogue and world building, and wonderful music. In addition, there is SO much lore for those who have read homestuck. I would say the game fills in many aspects of daily troll culture and life that we knew little to nothing about before the game. 

Its cute, funny, enjoyable, and I highly recommend to anyone who enjoys puzzle/point and click, even if they have not read through homestuck.

However. Was it worth the 5 years of hype, a long and drawn out release, and 8$ for one of four acts? No.

The movement is point and click, and while usually not too intrusive, can be extremely annoying for just getting your character out of the way of what you need to click on. Should have been a WASD movement system. Its a core mechanic that feels very unpolished relative to the rest of the game. In addition, upon startup there are a few EXTREMELY glaring bugs, the foremost of which is if you change your resolution and dont restart the game, it WILL make the UI look super weird and terrible. Which is how I played the entirety of the game. 

Which is not hard to do, as the game is not long. For something that had 5 years to be developed and raised over 2.1 MILLION dollars on kickstarter it is entirely underwhelming, especially with the 8 dollar price tag. Even though I took my time in exploring every interaction, I finished the game in exactly 2 hours. Not only that, but the game ends just when the story picks up, RIGHT as things get serious. Blueballs for sure. I mean, they didnt HAVE to leave it on a cliffhanger, and considering that this is act 1 of 4, seems like they could have condensed 2 acts into this one game and chosen a more resolved point in time. And what seems more ridiculous is that even though they left it on a cliffhanger, they couldnt bother to give us a date for the next installment. 

To conclude, I loved it, 5 hats out of 5, 8 out of 8, 10 decapitated Dirks out of 10.

Ps. F**K YOU Hussie where the hell is our epilogue you cant just END the comic when GAMZEE IS STILL IN THE FRIDGE I mean come ON.

If you have any love for homestuck you should dive back in and experience hiveswap. And hey, the soundtrack version is only $4 more and comes with 25 tracks from the game and 5 bonus tracks.

34963254.review:
Don't be fooled by my playtime-- this isn't a very long game. It takes maybe three hours to beat if you just sit down and get to it. But honestly, for the amount of enjoyment and the number of genuine laughs and moments of hype i got out of this game? Eight bucks it totally reasonable for three hours of playtime.

PROS
- Music is absolutely stunning. Toby Fox hit the nail on the goddamn head, but when hasn't he?
- Absolute truck loads of references, if you look for them and have the knowledge to recognize them. And if you don't have any prior Homestuck experience, the references aren't going to feel forced or in-your-face!
- No pixel hunting!!!! At all!!! Ever!!!!! Almost unheard of for a point-and-click adventure game!!
- The artwork is beautiful, lending to very immersive backgrounds that pull you in and make you want to click on just? everything?
- The cutscenes (what I could see of them, more below) were wonderfully rendered, and the animation in general is all around very very smooth and fluid. It's really gorgeous to watch in action, especially Joey's Tap-Dance Strife Specibus prototype.
- Did I mention no pixel hunting? Because that was a really big one for me.
- Movement speed in a point-and-click that's actually reasonable! No snail's pace from one end of the screen to the other! These are some kids who know how to make like a tree and abscond in a hurry.
- World-building is on point, and almost subtle in some places. It's got a fantastic build up, giving you new information just as you've finished processing the old. It does leave you guessing/wondering here and there, but in a very intentional "this will be built upon" way, not "we forgot to expand on this and hope you don't notice."
- The characters are fucking AMAZING. Joey and Xefros have some really fantastic interactions, especially with the cultural differences back-and-forths. And the radio talk between Joey and Jude is some of my favorite writing to come out of a point-and-click game-- as an older sister with a younger brother, it was dialogue that felt very, very familiar. Jude and Dammek get left in the dust a bit, but will presumably be explored in HAUNTSWITCH. That said, even Jude had a couple of shining moments whenever he popped up.

CONS
- It wasn't always very clear what actions would progress the story and which ones wouldn't. Not necessarily a fault of the game, I suppose, but it's always disheartening when you're trying to clear out a room and suddenly get transported away, or put in a scenario that railroads you somewhere else.
- Strifes were sometimes confusing? Strifing in general was VERY unclear in the first combat and just sort of tossed you into the deep end, and on one or two of the Strifes I had trouble figuring out what order the game wanted me to use abilities in. That very well might be user error however, so ymmv.
- The musical transitions are a bit glitchy, especially if you stay in one room for a prolonged period of time. Usually they fixed themselves if you changed rooms, but not always.
- Changing the screen resolution without restarting can Heck Things Up and icons will begin a gradual journey across the screen.
- This might be unique to my poor, overtaxed laptop-- but I couldn't see a single cutscene through to the end. After about 2-3 seconds, it would freeze and then skip to the next game play bit. I tried changing screen resolution, windowed vs. not, closing background programs, and restarting my computer, all to no avail. If your personal gaming box of choice is relatively current, you're probably fine. But if it's on the older side and lower end of the game specs like mine-- be warned. You're probably gonna miss a substantial amount of plot.
- It's so. SO. short. If you want a quick little world to sink your teeth into a blow a couple hours on, this might not be a bad thing. It sure wasn't for me! BUT. If you aren't necessarily a fan of the genre, want something a little more out of the game, or don't have a deep, multi-year emotionally investment in it, it's going to feel a little disappointing. Particularly since the end appears very abruptly.

My guys, I hecking love it. This game isn't going to be everyone's cup of tea, and after years of waiting and all the Drama TM surrounding its Kickstarter, it might feel like a let down. But if you just let the game Exist and go for the ride, it's a fucking good ride. The developers called it a love letter to 90's adventure games, and playing it feels like drinking a steaming hot cup of Nostalgia delicately cloaked in gross monsters, conspiracy theories, absentee fathers, and weird bug aliens. If it's your cup of tea, you're gonna hecking love it.

34963216.review:
Pros:
The game, as a whole, is extremely well written. It's witty, it's funny, it throws horrible puns at you that make you want to laugh out loud. I found myself laughing nearly all the way through. I would consider this the best part of the game.

The second best part would be the lovable, charming soundtrack. It's all very well made and always fun to listen too.

Finally, the characters are believable. This is a common theme in this and Homestuck, but the writers do such an amazing job at creating realistic, believable, fun characters that you just want to hug.

Cons:
The length. I understand this is a part 1, but the amount of time this game has been in development compared to what was recieved doesn't seem right.

The bugs. There was a few bugs I personally ecountered that stopped me from progressing for a while; An example was I had to open a larhe cabinent and grab the item inside, only to see that once it was open the game REFUSED to let me pick the item up, leaving me stranded until I saved and reset. Nothing big, but it was troublesome.

As a minor nitpick, I had a bit of trouble at times navigating, but it was only a minor annoyance. 

Overall:
It's funny, it's great, you'll love it, even if you haven't read Homestuck. However, you're going to be left wanting more, and feel as though there wasn't enough.

34963146.review:
Raymond Albert Romano (born December 21, 1957) is an American stand-up comedian, actor and screenwriter. He is best known for his role on the sitcom Everybody Loves Raymond, for which he received an Emmy Award, and as the voice of Manny in the Ice Age film series. He created and starred in the TNT comedy-drama Men of a Certain Age (2009–11). From 2012 to 2015, Romano had a recurring role as Hank Rizzoli, a love interest of Sarah Braverman in Parenthood.

Personal life and family
Romano was born in Queens, New York, the son of Lucie (Fortini), a piano teacher, and Albert Romano (November 7, 1925 – March 11, 2010), a real estate agent and engineer.[2][3] He is of seven-eighths Italian, and one-eighth French descent, and grew up in the Forest Hills neighborhood of Queens.[4] He has an older brother, Richard (born in 1956), a sergeant with the NYPD, and a younger brother, Robert, a second grade teacher in New York City.[5] Romano married his wife, Anna Scarpulla, in 1987. They met while working at a bank together.[6] They have four children.

Romano's character's daughter on Everybody Loves Raymond was named after his real-life daughter. Also, in the series pilot, Ray and Debra's twin boys were named Gregory and Matthew, after Romano's real-life twin sons, but Romano felt it was inconvenient to have all his TV children have the same names as his real children, and changed the twins' names to Geoffrey and Michael on screen. He also said his brother was not pleased with Ray Barone's TV brother.[7]

Romano's family has made various appearances in the show. Romano's real-life daughter Alexandra "Ally" Romano made several appearances on Everybody Loves Raymond as Molly, the best friend of his on-screen daughter, Ally, and the daughter of Ray Barone's nemesis, Peggy the Cookie Lady. Romano's father, Albert Romano, has made various appearances as Albert, one of Frank Barone's lodge buddies in various episodes such as "Debra at the Lodge", and "Boys' Therapy". Romano's brother, Richard Romano, appeared in the episodes "Golf For It", "Just a Formality" and "The Toaster". Romano's wife Anna appeared as one of the moms in the background at Geoffrey and Michael's school in season 6's episode titled "The Angry Family."

In February 2012, Romano revealed that his wife Anna had successfully battled stage one breast cancer in 2010. Romano told People magazine that "the reason we're going public is to share our experience, yeah, but to have an effect. Our goal is to help people."[8]

Career
Romano attended elementary and middle school at Our Lady Queen of Martyrs in Forest Hills. After transferring from Archbishop Molloy High School, Romano graduated from Hillcrest High School in 1975.[9] He was in the same high school class as Fran Drescher. Before getting into show business, Romano briefly attended Queens College, in Flushing, New York, where he studied accounting.[6]

His early comedy career started when he competed in the Johnnie Walker Comedy Search in 1989 directed by Saturday Night Live short film producer Neal Marshad and appeared on The Comedy Channel. His career included many outlets, such as Comedy Central, where he had been a recurring guest voice on the show Dr. Katz, Professional Therapist. He also was a contestant on Star Search in the stand-up comedy category. He originally was cast to play Joe (originally named Rick) on the American television sitcom NewsRadio, but was fired and replaced by Joe Rogan. He then appeared on Late Show with David Letterman doing his stand up routine which formed his ties with CBS. Shortly thereafter, he became the star of his own show, Everybody Loves Raymond on CBS, that featured a cast and format more suitable to Romano's brand of humor. His work on the series earned him six Emmy nominations, winning in 2002, as well as five Screen Actors Guild Award nominations and two Golden Globe Award nominations.

Romano and his comedian best friend Kevin James starred in the salesman comedy Grilled as two Average Joes of the same profession who are both desperate to land a big sale.

Romano was featured on a 2000 episode of Who Wants to Be a Millionaire, on which he won US$125,000 for the NYPD's D.A.R.E. Unit.

In 2001, Romano was named one of E!'s top twenty entertainers of the year. That same year he was featured with his brother (a teacher at a school in Long Island) on a New York Police Department recruiting poster.

In 2004, he became the highest-paid television actor in history for his role of Raymond on CBS's Everybody Loves Raymond. It was later revealed on E! that he had broken another record by his show having the highest revenue at US$3.9 billion.

On December 13, 2003, Romano was featured as a special guest star, sending a birthday card to Bob Barker in his eightieth-birthday bash on the twenty-seventh "Million Dollar Spectacular" special of the long-running daytime CBS series The Price Is Right.

Romano was the subject of the documentary film 95 Miles to Go. The film documents Romano's road-trip for a series of rides across the south of the United States. The film was released in theaters on April 7, 2010, by ThinkFilm.[10] In August 2006 Romano was interviewed in front of a live audience at UCLA by fellow stand-up veteran David Steinberg, for an episode of Sit Down Comedy with David Steinberg. The program first aired on the TV Land network in March 2007.

Romano returned to television with a new dramedy for TNT in 2008, Men of a Certain Age, which he co-created with former Everybody Loves Raymond writer, Mike Royce. It co-starred Scott Bakula and Andre Braugher.

Romano made an appearance in the seventh season of NBC show The Office as Merv Bronte, a nervous job applicant interviewing for the job left vacant by Michael Scott.

Romano made an appearance in the third-season premiere of ABC sitcom The Middle as Nicky, a friend of Mike, who ruined his and Frankie's honeymoon. Romano was the second actor from Everybody Loves Raymond to be reunited with Patricia Heaton on The Middle. Doris Roberts guest-starred in three episodes.

He joined the cast of Parenthood beginning September 11, 2012.[11][12] He became a semi-regular, playing photographer Hank Rizzoli, who hired and later had a romantic relationship with Sarah Braverman and developed a friendship with her nephew who has Asperger syndrome. The role was specifically created for him after he expressed his love for the show and met with creator Jason Katims on the set of Friday Night Lights.[13]

In 2002, Romano voiced the wooly mammoth Manfred (Manny) in the film Ice Age, followed by Ice Age: The Meltdown in 2006, Ice Age: Dawn of the Dinosaurs in 2009, Ice Age: Continental Drift in 2012, and Ice Age: Collision Course in 2016.

Competitions

Romano at the 2010 World Series of Poker main event
Romano competed in the World Series of Poker in 2007, 2008, 2009, 2010, 2011, 2013 and 2015.

In early 2010, Romano starred in the second season of The Golf Channel's original series The Haney Project in which Tiger Woods' former coach Hank Haney attempts to improve the golf games of different celebrities and athletes. Romano's goal was to finish the show being able to break 80.[14] Romano took time off from the show to be with his father, Albert Romano, who died in March 2010. Romano is also a regular competitor in the AT&T Pebble Beach National Pro-Am, where he finished fifth in 2012 with his partner, Australian professional Steven Bowditch. It was the first time Romano had qualified for the final round after failing to do so on 11 successive occasions. He also competes annually in the American Century Championship, a celebrity golf tournament owned by NBC and held at Lake Tahoe[15][16] each July.
