34962944.review:
Let's get straight into it, the first thing I noticed about this game is that it was windowboxed with a giant black border, and none of the resolution settings seemed to fix it. If you entertain even a vague notion of this game functioning at all, you must start the game, then go into the settings and fix the resolution, and then *quit out of it entirely and restart it*. Otherwise you risk getting a white screen at the first Strife and having to restart the game from the very beginning.

I'm seeing other reviews suggesting the difficulty should be harder. Look, I *loved* Loom, but we really should never, *ever* go back to the LucasArts adventure game days. The world has changed, and while the art in Loom was *Art*, the gameplay was crazy-making, and we've come to expect a higher standard of gameplay now. Besides, if you were to only read the game's description, you'd see that the game is "adventure-lite" in the same way that "rogue-lite" is less punishing than your typical roguelike. So please, go into this knowing that it's casual gaming, and that's a Good Thing.

So, with that out of the way...

Pros:
[list]
  [*] Feels like one big interactive page ripped from SBURB. Were you, like me, hoping for that? Well that's exactly what this is. Spend some time to appreciate the posters, the pogo ball, the absurd fetishism of Betty Crocker. It's all here.
  [*] Lite difficulty makes this kind of like an adventure-game-themed kinetic novel
  [*] On-point humor befitting the SBURB lineage.
  [*] Every thing can be tried on every other thing. Every error message is unique.
  [*] Many of the chat interactions have scroll bars so you can actually go back and read something you've missed by mashing continue too many times.
[/list]

Cons:
[list]
  [*] The aforementioned resolution problem. Game stability generally feels bad because of it.
  [*] In spite of claiming no alien-logic puzzles, some of the solutions are rather strange, such as having to use an item on a door when the result doesn't ever involve either of these things touching.
  [*] The amount of content is very, extremely, surprisingly small. My playthrough was casual, and involved a total restart from the beginning because of the resolution bug, and yet my playtime is 2.5 hours. There are no choices I could go back and play through differently. I'm never opening this game again. That's all the entertainment it holds for me.
[/list]

This game puts me in a tough spot. I don't want to return it. I experienced - and enjoyed - as much as this game has to offer. But overall, if I were to compare this to another good "experience" game like The Stanley Parable or The Turing Test, the value proposition for this is much lower. If you see all four chapters of this come out in a bundle for $15, buy it. Each one individually for $8? I reccommend passing for now.

34962278.review:
Pros:

VERY good.

Cons:

VERY short.

The Homestuck feel is spot-on, the aesthetics are great (oh how I wish that time and money hadn't been wasted on the inital attempts at polygonal 3D, since I highhhhhly doubt the final game's level of background detail would've ever been possible following that route), the characters were endearing [spoiler]though I fear for Hauntswitch, given how big a jerk Dammek seems to be, and given that his paranoia is closely parallel to Jude's conspiracy theorizing[/spoiler], the adventure game design is good (if pretty darn easy), the hidden little interaction jokes are grand... I'd be giving this a perfect review if it weren't for its length. I polished Act One off in 3.6 hours of relentlessly poking almost everything.

Now, I'll grant that with Life is Strange, my only other experience with episodic gaming, I didn't play it until all the episodes were out, and so that contributed to my not feeling that it was a short game. Hopefully by the end of Hiveswap, it'll feel weighty enough for me to unreservedly recommend it, because there's so much here that's [i]right[/i]. But right now, at this juncture, it feels like it ends so abruptly, with so much left to be done, which is not a great feeling to have given this game's... protracted development cycle.

Please give me more, What Pumpkin, and please don't leave us hanging another three years.

34962110.review:
Hiveswap is an absolute must for Homestuck fans just like myself. But even if you're not a fan, it's still a pretty good adventure game. The only major thing hampering it, at least on release, is the amount of bugs. Most of them are visual bugs with the environments and UI. It can break the immersion just a bit. They will most likely get fixed. It happens, usually, when you first switch to fullscreen and to a higher resolution. It goes away upon restarting the game.

Nothing else seems to be wrong, technically speaking. Vertical Sync is available with good Resolution Options, Volume Levels, and Windowed Mode. When loading, the game suffers some framerate issues, but that literally means nothing since there isn't a thing on screen during this process. Moving around does feel clunky, especially on stairs in cramped spaces.

Other than that, there's very little wrong with this game. It's almost "perfect", despite it having this sort of "cheap" feel to it... but it's so minor, that it barely affects the game at all.

This game is a crap load of fun, with plenty of laughs to be had. The 90s pop culture references are off the charts, and the nostalgic feel is wonderful to the point of being palpable. Sadly, this wonder only lasts about 5 hours. It ends too quickly. The price justifies the length at least. There's some replayability, especially since you're practically encouraged to try every item and weapon with everything. I actually didn't think of trying every item with everything. I was just using the weapons with everything, and even then I eventually stopped doing that. So there's probablly quite a few things I'm missing, which is evident by me having 57% of the achievements after beating the game.

What makes this game so great is the text, which is amazingly written and hilarious, and the sheer amount of things in each environment that make them feel "real". Trying out stuff on everything will give you this text, making each action you do rewarding just for the downright fun writing to read. Don't even get me started on the story, it's very good and keeps you playing all throughout. Andrew Hussie has crafted yet another fantastic story of youth and the celebration of the people, hobbies, dreams, or things we care about. If you haven't read Homestuck, go and do it right away, it will take you weeks! Even after hours of binging per day!

Hiveswap is worth so much more, I would've paid $15.00 for it at most just for the fun it gave me. I can't wait for more. As a Homestuck fan, it was more than I hoped for!

34961910.review:
Alright, jeeze, been waiting on this a while. Technically got the game for free, but I gifted that copy and got the soundtrack edition because #bettervalue.
Anyway, ok where to start? I'm not much of an adventure game kinda guy, so I don't know how this stacks up against the rest of the genre, but as a fan of Homestuck I'm glad to see some expansion on less clear aspects of that universe. There were a couple implications which I believe were new, but i never looked close enough at the source material to tell.
The game itself is enjoyable. I found myself getting bored of clicking on literally everything, but I imagine that's just my impatience with the format.
There were a few typos that seemed to have made it into the final dialogue, only one managed to confuse me a little bit because I guess an entire word got cut and it was kind of key in that context. Otherwise just a couple letters off, but I got the point.
I only got stuck at one point, and that's probably just because I assumed a couple objects were connected but they had different dialogues associated with them. From my perspective, it was overall an enjoyable experience. It does look like this is going to be episodic, like a Telltale game. I finished Act 1 and I assume I have to wait for Act 2 to come out.
Followed homestuck for its last few years, so that's nothing new.
I can't say for sure how this would appeal to newcomers who never checked out any MSPA comics. Hard to know, but I think it would hold up for the uninitiated.
So, yeah, Fun game so far. Pretty basic stuff, and a good preview for what's to come. Also showcases that classic Homestuck humor very well, with a few good references aside from the obvious.

But I guess this is first and formost a point and click game, not an Undertale style action adventure, so combat is not the games main focus.

The writing is good and the dialog is funny. They managed to give the kids their own personalities, rarther than being Jade and John 2.0. There were enough Homestuck refrences to keep fans happy but they shouldn't distract too much for people who haven't read the comic.

So yeah, a nice 3-4 hour campaign with probably another 2-3 hours of exploring of you want to unlock all the things. All of them. Some people might say that's not worth the asking price, but if you also pick up the soundtrack (which you should, it's amazing) I think it's a fairly good bargin. Looking fowrard to when act 2 drops in 2029!

4/5 hats

34961696.review:
TL;DR Good game, good story, but not worth for those who waited 5 years. Maybe when the story comes to completion?

So anyways, I've been waiting for this for around a year myself and I can say that its definitely worth my personal wait. For those of you who have been hyping over this as Homestuck fans, its finally here! The story just rings with Hussie's writing, comedy, and none of his seriousness that turns out to be actual sincerity. I laughed, I teared up a bit over the poor troll boy's life, and I got interested and involved to the point for where I'm itching for Act 2. 

If you're one of the many who have been waiting for this game for a long while:
Each action and inspection you make adds just a bit more story and personality to the characters and their lives. The game has beautiful art and music, just as I would expect from some of the names I saw in the credits. If you've read Homestuck, you'd be familiar with quite a few of the callbacks and references involved in the game. Although I'm a little disappointed in the fact that what we've been waiting for doesn't involve our kids from Homestuck, the kids here in Hiveswap have their own story and voice to be told and heard, and I've already fallen in love with what we're seeing.

If you're just now hearing about all this Hiveswap and Homestuck stuff:
Welcome to the product of 5 years of hype and strife!

Hiveswap: Act 1 has given a very strong foundation with its small amount of content (took me nearly 3 hours to complete, and I went about checking everything I could) for the rest of the franchise soon to come, and I'm hopeful for its future. 
+ The Artstyle fits perfectly with what we know in the traditional Homestuck world
+ The Music fits scenes very well, giving character's their own themes.
+ The Story was easy to get into, and enjoyable the entire while. I never felt like I was reading on some unimportant piece of lore.

- There were quite a few grammar mistakes in the dialogues. I don't mean like sentence structure, I mean there were parts where instead of "it's" it said " 's." Not too much of a problem, but should be noted.
- If you're one of the ones who have been waiting for as many years as most of us have, 3 hours doesn't exactly fulfill much on that. Hopefully the rest of the series will help on that need?

34961571.review:
I love point-and-click adventures, and this one is particularly -- no other word for it -- charming.   I've read all of Homestuck, but it seems to me that this can be played without Homestuck knowledge; the only Homestuck characters appear in portraits on a wall.   The art is often breathtaking, the music is pleasant and cheerful, and the animation is delightful.   The principal character, Joey, is funny and angry and has a great interior voice; I rushed through the last part of the game because I wanted to get her to safety.

Every single object in the game has a pre-written relationship with every other; if you use any A on any B you will always get a response, most of which are funny.  You'll never get "I see no [item] here" or "You cannot use [item] on [item]."

A lot of people are having problems with glitchy cutscenes.  I'm on a Mac running OS Sierra and haven't had any problems.  If you are on a different platform, you may want to save frequently in case of a crash.   I was playing this at the same time as a Discord friend, and that friend had to stop, save, and restart fairly frequently because the correct solutions to puzzles didn't work for him.  (He knew they were correct because he was asking me for hints.)

If you don't already have a code, I would recommend waiting until the first patch, and then playing.  It's a sweet and funny and slightly melancholy game.

34961085.review:
Oh man you guys, I've waited five years for this game and lemme tell you - ACT 1 was so worth it. This ACT was mostly set-up for people who haven't played the game, or a refresher for those who haven't read Homestuck in a while, so it may feel a little slow at first, but the ending? We're gonna be in for a ride when ACT 2 is released. 
It was a sweet trip down memory lane to revisit this world, it's a great introduction to Hussie's universe for those who are unfamiliar, the game runs beautifully, the controls weren't confusing at all, the art is stunning, and the characters are adorable! You can really tell how much work What Pumpkin put into making this for us. And it's only $8! Seriously guys, buy this game; it's worth every penny.
I'd also like to note that you don't have to have read Homestuck to enjoy this game. The story is set in 1994, which is long before the events of Homestuck take place. I do totally recommend checking out Homestuck for more of this universe if you enjoy the game though! It's free to read online at mspaintadventures.com if you're interested in doing that!

This game is a prequel to the webcomic "Homestuck". While one does not have to have read it to play this game, all of it is pretty much referencing the Homestuck storyline to come. 

The writing style, music, animation, and mechanics are reminiscent of and consistent with the pseudo-"prompt style game" the comic is presented in, adapted to a point and click puzzle solver. Act 1 is short (a few hours), but with the smoothness and quality of animation, along with the sheer volume of mechanics (you can combine anything and everything and recieve a special prompt for it), there's lots to explore beyond the main storyline. With the quality this game presents, I'd pay for this game even if I didn't already pay for it during the kickstarter.

I encountered barely any bugs, and it's pretty much a solid game from the start! A refreshingly polished game compared to most fresh game releases I've encountered! Excellent job overall

34960913.review:
I just finished up the first Act of Hiveswap, and while I've never been one to write out reviews, I felt compelled to for this adventure.

This game has an amazing team of artists behind it, and all the art is incredibly lush and detailed. The animation is fun and bouncy, the environments are amazing and have a lot of depth, even the UI and the title screen are incredible.  The music is very memorable, my favorite track being ‘Rustblood’. The writing is comedic and echoes MSPA’s style perfectly, and managed to get me giggling like a lunatic a good few times. All around, it’s easy to tell this is a labor of passion.
The gameplay is simple and entertaining, with nigh endless dialogue for all the sorts of combinations you can do with the items and environment. The battles are fun littles puzzles themselves, and all the puzzles in the game or logical and flow well with the pace. The only times I was confused were because the cursor could use a directional indicator to be clear on where the player is clicking to move in the environment.

The only complaints I have are the length, because it was easily finished in 3 hours and could possibly have a long wait for the next acts (which is just speculation on my part for now). It’s also worth noting that the devs, at this time, are patching a few graphical glitches, however I encountered very few problems with this and it was solved by playing in windowed mode. 

However long that wait for the next part is, I think this game is well worth your time and money. It’s a delight, and if you have any interest in the quirky humor of the MSPAdevntures, you’ll love this one.

34960557.review:
Hiveswap Act 1 is definitely worth a play if you're a fan of Homestuck. The art and soundtrack are fantastic, and I found the scattered bits of lore interesting and worthwhile. The writing and dialogue were inoffensive and generally pleasant. There were, however, several issues I took with the game and think are important for the potential consumer to be aware of:

1) Volume inconsistency—the second track on the soundtrack is nearly twice as loud as the first, and this isn't an isolated example. Some sound effects were terribly quiet, while others made me temporarily mute my computer volume.
2) Length—the game is wayyyyy too short; while I understand that this is only the first episode, it felt more like a demo than an actual game. It took me about as much time to play through as it took me to play the Undertale demo when it came out, and here I was trying nearly every combination of items and interactables I thought to try.
3) Combat—the strife system was poorly paced and made no sense. I found myself really struggling to understand what I was supposed to do half the time. I think the game would have been better had the strife not been included at all.
4) Puzzles—The puzzles had quite a bit of handholding, and the next objective was often spelled out very explicitly. Where this wasn't the case, there wasn't any satisfaction in figuring out what to do next because the solution was a little bit contrived, and not in a clever way. If you're looking for good puzzles, maybe give this title a pass.

ALRIGHT let's begin this review, it's a lovely JANUARY evening and I gotta say.

I REALLY RECOMMEND THIS.. IF you are a fan of Homestuck, obviously. While I do think it's a great point and click game, you won't get much out of it right now unless you're already a fan of homestuck, WELL... If you like Point and Clicks then youll like this. Sorta.

34960186.review:
A short, but fun tribute to classic point-and-click games. A bit glitchy, but not game-breakingly so, and should be fixed in the next few weeks. Absolutely hilarious at points ([spoiler]RIP Pigeon 1[/spoiler]), and the fact that there are so many different combinations of items adds to the replay value, if only slightly. The promise of 3 more acts, as well as a sidequel, means most likely there will eventually be over 24 hours of content, which for a point-and-click is massive. Overall, a good game for a newcomer, and an amazing nostalgia-filled experience for a Homestuck fan, at a surprisingly fair price.

8/10, 9/10 if you're a fan of Homestuck.

PS [spoiler]If you haven't already, try to put the pigeon in the alien microwave. You will not regret it.[/spoiler]

34960170.review:
[h1]Thoughts on the game[/h1]

It's ok. It feels like it lacks some polish, but it worked and I didn't run into any issues which is more than you can say for many games these days. The resolution felt a bit weird. I'm not sure why they made the screen so wide or fixed the aspect ratio but whatever, that's nitpicking.

The way the game starts throws you directly into the action, which is nice, but the way they presented it is a bit jarring. Apart from that, it's nice. The puzzles are neat, although I wish they'd made some things a bit more obvious, like explaining properly what your weapons do when you get them. I had to figure it out for myself and it was a bit frustrating. When I got the hang of the system, though, it was pretty cool.

I'm not a big fan of the battles. They're not much more than puzzles, and the way you go about solving them just doesn't seem to fit the idea of "I'm locked in combat with a deadly monster". There weren't too many of them though, so while they felt kind of weird to play I didn't get hung up on it for too long.

Generally, the story was good. I could immerse myself into what's going on. My only complaint is Jude's dialogue. As a character, he's annoyingly obtuse about telling you what to do and they made the choice of putting it in all-caps too. Not the biggest fan. The later conversations between Xefros and Joey are much easier to read and more pleasant in general. Another thing to note is that so far things seem increbibly linear. The game isn't choice-based.

This episode was short. I think a little too short. That said, the story did cut off at a good point; it didn't feel like it ended abruptly. Would I say it's worth it for the price? Honestly, not really. $7.99 is a bit steep for something that only took 2-3 hours to play through. But we'll see whether future acts deliver on being more worthwhile.


[h1]Conclusion[/h1]

If you're a homestuck fan, it's nice. If you think you can happily enjoy 2-3 hours of homestuck stuff as an actual game, rather than a webcomic about a game, for the price it's being sold at, go ahead and buy it. It's not bad, and I certainly don't regret getting the game. Just keep in mind its strengths and flaws.

If you're not a homestuck fan, I'm not sure it's worth getting, especially at the current price. It has in-jokes and familiar terminology and mechanics that would be lost on anyone not at least slightly familiar with the homestuck universe. It's clearly geared to those already familiar with the source material. If you're interested anyway, try reading Homestuck first. It'll help you understand what's going on.

I feel as though it would be confusing for someone who hasn't read Homestuck to play this game, but hey, it has plenty of positive qualities on its own!! It DID have problems running on my computer, such as glitching animations and freezing, but nothing that ruined the experience, and nothing I can't watch footage of on Youtube anyway! Summary: Loved it, and looking forward to more!!

34960073.review:
I DID MY WAITING

FIVE YEARS OF IT

Seriously, this game was in development for FIVE YEARS, for a variety of reasons that can basically be summed up in THEFT and LEGAL DRAMAS. 

IT. WAS. WORTH. THE. WAIT.

When you keep in mind that Andrew Hussie, creator of infamous webcominc HOMESTUCK, basically created his own goddamn game development studio in order to deliver this to us, the five years makes a lot more sense. I mean, watch the end credits for gods sake, this beautiful piece was made by a relaively small handful of people, who have obviously worked very very hard to get it to this high level of quality. 

The art is amazing. Honeslty, the colours are beautiful and rich, and the styles are both clean and nostalgic. The music is wonderful and enchanting, and serve as a cheeky throwback for those of us raised on the music of Homestuck. The writing and dialogue is everything I was hoping it would be. Absolutely fantastic.

The puzzles are straightforward for the most part, but still satisfying and challenging. The mechanics are smooth and everything worked perfectly for me. 

Guys, seriously, Im so pumped for Act 2. Act 1 has set the scene so beautifully, I can tell we are going to be in for a wild ride in the coming Acts.

a pefect score from me. 

Thank you WhatPumpkin Games. Thank you Andrew Hussie. This is G L O R I O U S.

34959978.review:
When I started this game, I was afraid it wasn't going to be as good as I had hoped. The resolution seemed wonky, there was a big pause between the very first transiton into the next side of the room, and the sky in the background seemed to have not loaded properly. After so long, I was very much worried there were still going to be a lot of bugs and I wasn't going to enjoy the game as much.

Then I reinstalled the game. The resolution was a misshap of the download it seems because it got fixed immediately. That one loading time still seemed wonky, but the Skybox was back in its rightful place- As long as you didn't check it IMMEDIATELY after switching rooms. Outside of that room however? When I got out of the very first room, things transitioned smoothly. The animation is gorgeous, the references are lovely, the additions to the lore are deeply intriguing. Every piece of dialog has been interesting so far, either in its quirkiness, how it adds onto the lore (Which so far has even been a tad depressing), or how it gives clues to how to proceed. The puzzles aren't too obscure either, and the Combat Sequences are more akin to timed puzzles than actual battles, which are a nice break from the slower paced rest of the game.

I've only just begun this adventure, but I am already enthralled, and the very, very few bugs I found didn't come back once I went out of the very first room.

This is the Game I've been waiting for 5 years.

The wait has been incredibly worth it.

Thank you. <3

34959862.review:
Well, that was a trip down memory lane.  I backed this game on Kickstarter five years ago, back in the height of the Homestuck craze.  So much has happened since then, both in the webcomic and with my life, but playing Hiveswap reminded me of the magic of that time, sitting on my new college friend's dormroom floor at 3AM devouring surprise updates.  If you're like me, an old Homestuck fan, I think you'd be pretty safe in picking this up and enjoying it.

The overall writing quality is fantastic. Though Hussie did not write this himself, his trademark slightly dry, tongue-in-cheek narrative voice is wonderfully prominent in the object descriptions and interactions.  There also is unique text for many, many, many strange combinations of objects, as you would hope in a point and click adventure. However, I feel that the character dialogue was a little different stylistically than I was expecting.  It wasn't bad per se, just not quite as "Homestuck" as the rest of the writing. This is especially noticable in the later parts of the game, where two characters are interacting much more frequently.

Though it was quite short, I believe that Hiveswap stayed for about as long as it needed to for this Act. I finished it in my 2.5 hours of playtime and I did quite a lot of random clicking and combining, though I do read much faster than the average person.  What Pumpkin kept the zones pretty small, which kept the time spent getting stuck to a relative minimum.  I am admittedly a point-and-click philistine, but this more confined space allowed me to finish without feeling frustrated, or looking up a solution, which has happened other times I've tried to play games in this genre.

Other users have reported some debilitating bugs and graphical glitches.  In my playtime, I had no crashes or game breaking bugs, though there were a few minor UI blips.  Hopefully these issues get patched soon, but it isn't 100% broken.

If you're a Homestuck fan, I don't really see any reason not to pick this up.  If you're not a Homestuck fan, it's still a solidly written, beautifully drawn short adventure.  As long as you're not expecting some gigantic Joycean epic, it'll definitely be an enjoyable afternoon of attempting to tapdance at every clickable object in vicinity.

34959854.review: Really awesome, well worth the money! I had a bit of a problem finding the batteries, and there were a few graphical glitches, but otherwise it was really fun. I enjoyed clicking on and combining everything for the flavour text, and enjoyed the cutscenes, and I had fun with all the little references to various things! I'm just worried the next act will take forever to be finished, but I know making video games takes time, and I'm certain it will be well worth the wait!

NEGATIVES:
There were a handful of bugs, black bars, one or two cases of glitchy UI, and the text was worded a bit too oddly (not by Homestuck typing quirk standards, but was just phrased weirdly). The mini games were fun (like the serpents) however the implementation felt clunky. A couple of the puzzles were unintersting (about three I can think of, rest were pretty solid)

POSITIVES:
Interesting narrative, as always. Interacting everything with anything was really fun, especially to see funny jokes. The references to past homestuck/hiveswap jokes were great and it felt good to think "yeah, I remember that!". You didn't actually follow Homestuck/Hiveswap before playing it? That's fine! Even if you have no prior experience it's accessible! Strifing was a lotta fun too, with the mini puzzles put into those.

ALL IN ALL:
This game is primarily good for narrative. If you like rading, finding little secrets, this is something you'll really enjoy. Or if you're just interested in Homestuck! This, however, is not a game for people who want serious hard puzzles, given most are fairly simple.

34959439.review:
As one of the original backers for this game wayyyyyyy back in the heyday of Homestuck, it's certainly been a wild ride waiting for Hiveswap. And after 5 years of delays, hiatuses, and a mess of a fandom constantly reeling at the idea of a video game being *somewhere*, I can honestly say that not only was this worth the wait, but I'm already excited for Act 2.

A word of caution that's been thrown around for quite a while about this game: If you haven't read Homestuck, it's *very* recommended that you do so beforehand. It's not necessarily required, but it definitely will help you quite a bit in terms of understanding the backstory to this game. Plus, it shines a lot of light onto the universe you're diving into here.

In terms of gameplay, this is certainly a 90's-style point-and-click in every sense of the term. There are the occasional puzzles here and there, but you're not going to be constanly fretting over them like say, Myst or Secrets of Monkey Island. They're quite simple, and don't take too much thought. Your inventory will have at most 10 items, and only 5 or 6 things can be combined to solve the puzzles. Still, that doesn't discount the game in my eyes.

If you're playing this, you're doing it for the experience. The game itself looks stunning, with the beautiful background sets, incredible sound work by James Roach and Toby Fox (Yeah, *that* Toby Fox), and the occasional interlude of animation, very much styled in the form of Homestuck's flash panels.

If you're taking your time and reading all the flavortext, checking out everything in your environment and taking the experience in, this game will last you around 3-4 hours per playthrough, and on my first playthrough I only got about half the achievements, so there's room for replayability.

It's hard to say if I'd recommend this for someone who hasn't read Homestuck, just because you'll be diving into an integral part of the story's universe in this game, but if the game does interest you, I'd say the source material is worth the read. It'll take you a little while, but the art and music that spawned from the webcomic should definitely get you excited to delve into this adventure.

At this point, all I can do is wait excitedly for the next entry, which hopefully comes sooner than later.

Beyond pure gameplay, though, Hiveswap has much to offer in the form of visual art, sound design and music. Gorgeous paintings, piles of random objects and blue lamps modeled after scanitly-clad women added to a unique aesthetic that I haven't yet found the words to describe. 
There were a few bugs, as is to be expected from the first day of release, but far fewer than I expected.
Over all, playing this game was a truly enjoyable experience.

Okay, I sat in front of my computer and refreshed the Steam page for at least an hour (oh, what happy memories). I got the game, downloaded it and played through it in about 3.6hrs. And I have to say... it was worth the wait.

The Homestuck fandom has been waiting for this game for years now, and the people at What Pumpkin have delivered an amazing game riddled with references to Homestuck in practically every panel. Believe me, I looked!

The art style is simple and very reminscent of the art styles depicted in Homestuck itself. The STRIFE sequences in particular reminded me of John's confrontation with his Dad in Act 1.

And with more stunning music from Toby Fox, I had to get the Soundtrack Edition. Again, every little thing the people at What Pumpkin have poured into this game over the years really makes it feel like Homestuck.

34959129.review:
In it's current form this game is pretty hard to recommend to anyone except people who readily consider themselves fans of Homestuck. 

At 3 hours (Having pretty much clicked at everything possible) this is one of the worst "value" purchases I have ever done in Steam. Sure Since I only got bit over half of the achievements it is safe to say the alternative choice routes will give the game re-playability of maybe round, or two. However, considering the content is only point and click it seems rather.. lackluster. I wouldn't consider this worth the money unless it was IP I was already invested in. (Which sadly I think the devs are counting on, too) 
On top of this the game is still very buggy. Sometimes the cursor is very buggy with recognizing things, the screen keeps oddly shifting and gets visual glitches (Such as slivers of last scene showing on the border etc), screenshots come out awfully cropped in windowed mode, there isn't a borderless window mode, there are save corrupting crashes.. 

If we assume the episode length to be constant, the sequel to be same legth as this and the price to stay constant..
Then they plan to milk us for 32$/12h twice.. at 64$ for 24 hours of gameplay it sounds like AWFUL proposition. Sure lets hope the episodes get longer but... don't hold your breath. 

I'm sad because the art of the game is gorgeous. The writing is fantastic. But the game play, the game engineering are mediocre at best. The value proposition is awful. I wish all the best to What Pumpkin but as this game stands (and the future prospects it holds) it is hard sell to anyone who wasn't already planning to buy it regardless of the price and delays anyhow.

Alright, I just have finished Act 1 and now....let me tell you about Hiveswap. ;)

It doesn't really matter if you have read Homestuck or not..or you just never finished it.
Everything gets explained!

In this game, or more in this part of the game you'll find wonderful art and animations, awesome music, good humor and of course a lot of Homestuck references. [spoiler]ZOOSMELL POOPLORD![/spoiler]
But there are plenty other references as well. Just look at the beautiful drawn backgrounds where you can spot many stuff from your own childhood.
It kinda made me feel old but also nostalgic.

The puzzles aren't very hard but enjoyable.
The story is dragging you in and you just have to love the characters.
[spoiler]Okay, maybe not Dammek. He seems to be a d*uche. XD[/spoiler]

Since it's Whatpumpkins first game, there are some small bugs and errors in the game.
I saw some grammar mistakes and in the epilouge some of the text wasn't in the picture.
Also it's really short if you don't go and look for every detail in the game.

BUT

It's totally worth it's price.
Heck, we Homestucks even have paid a much higher price; Time!
Lot's of it. Waiting.
And I may just speak for myself, but the wait was worth it. I never expected it to be 'perfect'. It's the first part of their first game after all!
Even with a lot of trouble, Hussie managed to create a wonderful game with fans, for fans and for not-yet-fans.

Can't wait for Act 2!

34958835.review:
Hello homestuckers and non-homestuckers!

I must really say that act 1 really is a great game, and you have to get it!

[CONS]

Since it comes out in acts and this is only act 1 you can't get much playtime out of it, which is the only sad thing about it. This will however be fixed when the other acts come out.

The other thing I have to mention is minor bugs and glitches, these will of course soon be fixed and didn't affect my gameplay. As long as you change to the right resolution for your screen you should be fine

[PROS]

I think you should buy this game, as a homestucker the game is LOADED with homestuck references, everything from a Signless plushie to "PLAY HAUNTING MELODY" two character from homestuck actually (somewhat) being in the game. You can easily miss or not understand the references but they had me smiling throught the entire game (now my cheeks are tired Dx)

As a non-homestucker this game is a beautiful cartoony puzzle-game with unique characters, abilities, quirks and beautiful cut-scenes. The game is a prefect game for someone who wants to get motivated to start getting into the homestuck fandom, but also for the indie/puzzle/casual gamer, as the game is set BEFORE (most) of Homestuck. The game has nostalgia for the 90-s kids with old-school games and whims that makes your nostalgia-senses tingle. 

Hiveswap can be played in 2 different ways, the fast way, you don't click or look at most of the things currently in the game OR you can spend up to 4 hours clicking and interacting wth every single item you can find. When I get more time I WILL for sure go back and make sure I have looked at everything (even though I think I almost got it all)

The game is beautiful and really cool especially since it was made by only a few developers, writers and artists! I will for sure keep my eyes glued to when the next act comes out, and I hope you do too.The game has weird and hidden achievements, lots of humor and hidden interactions that you can play around with.

As I said before the game is not very long and is kind of cheap, so I you want to search through a gold-mine of fun for a few hours and play around with it I certainly won't stop you. As for the later acts you will probably have to wait for a while to get the chance to play them, but as far as I know Hussie will probably have something up his sleeve to keep us entertained in the meanwhile!

If you have 2-3 hours and a little money in your steam wallet I think this game is a must have.
*finger-guns' away into the abyss but trips over a log and get's run over by a steamroller*

34958711.review:
QUICK SPOILER FREE REVIEW: 

UPSIDES: It was a fun journey, and the world was alive. Every tiny thing was filled with details and Hussie's signature humor style. The music is fantastic and the characters are really well made. You can tell how they feel about things by their words and surrounding. The story has a lot of potential and I can't wait to see more. The puzzles are fun. And for 8$, it’s a fantastic game.

DOWNSIDES: With a 4 hour game time if you just do the essentials, it may leave you unsatisfied. You really have to take your time and not rush the story. Enjoy the small things. If you breeze through, you’re not going to have a lot of fun.

CONCLUSION: All and all, a great game, really delivered with the content it had, which wasn't much unfortunately. I'd recommend waiting until all the games are out, then buy and play through them all to get the most out of it. If you don’t want to wait, be sure to take your time and enjoy the world.

Great job Hussie, can't wait for more!

~Eric Witney

34958588.review:
Alright, I've been waiting for this game for a LONG and arduous time, so you know it's gotta be good for me to recommend it. 

[h1]Pros:[/h1]
- Really good humor and writing(I would say it's as good as Homestuck's Andrew Hussie's, if not as eclectic).
- Excellent soundtrack.
- Amazing art, tons of unique animations and cutscenes for even tiny stuff. 
- Attention to detail, both in gameplay and text. However, I feel like this might have harmed the game's length, check below for what I mean.
- Vast breadth and depth of references that are subtle enough to not be cringey (and in fact would go over most players' heads, there were even humanimals references), but recognizable enough to still make you smirk.
- Good worldbuilding and setup, I can see future acts having a really good plot.
- Very, very good characters. I wish Jude could have been fleshed out more, but I guess that's for Hauntswitch so I can't complain!

[h1]Cons:[/h1]
- Music transitions are buggy, especially around strifes. Volume is also extremely inconsistent across rooms, even compared to sound effects. Seems more of a programming issue than anything related to sound design, however.
- Weird "hitboxes" for items, and a few "conflicts" between movement and interaction. Particularly, having to use an item on a door was unexpected, considering the icon didn't change from the regular movement icon when you hovered over it with the item, and the fact using items on transitions was unprecedented.
- ANY button skips stuff, even the screenshot button. A nitpick, but an annoying one.
- Relatively short, took me three hours while taking my time. I would have vastly preferred a bigger amount of interactions between the characters over item combination/interaction text, which I enjoyed, but wouldn't deliberately seek out. That said, this is no big deal: I have to remember it's only Act 1.
- It's just too easy. I got stuck one time, and that was with the door incident I mentioned above. I definitely don't want an obscurely frustrating experience like with some old adventure games, but I feel like the only times the game made you use your head were ruined by the fact you got unasked hints for them right afterwards. Maybe make the hints optional in future acts?


Conclusion: [b]8.5/10[/b]. A very fun adventure game, and a great Homestuck experience (if you're into that), but a bit too easy and too short to be perfect. I hope future acts make you think a bit more often. 
I can recommend it to everyone who enjoys adventure games, and it's definitely a must-play for Homestuck fans.

34958587.review:
[b]YOU DON'T NEED TO KNOW ANYTHING ABOUT HOMESTUCK TO ENJOY THE GAME![/b]...aham...just to be clear.
[code][h1]HIVESWAP[/h1][/code]
Opening case: Hiveswap always got me intrigued, as the game's development was turbulent and the fact that I love Hussie's work, I've been heart broken once by Mighty N.9 and didn't want to go through the pain again, either way I spent all day on my computer refreshing the page so I could help people on the same page as I was.
[code][h1]ACT 1: Presentation to new audience[/h1][/code]
The First act released a few hours ago and I'm pretty happy with it, every room is packed to the brim with objects to interact and different ways to do so, point-and-clicks are alredy hard to come across, ones with different dialog on each object depending on how you interact with it is really something to praise, I spent 3 hours on the first act and half of that was only interacting with the background to read the neatly written dialog.
Music is fine, didn't have time to become repetitive, it's nothing to buy the soundtrack for yet, if they continue making songs for the next episodes I can see why one would buy the soundtrack edition, I didn't tough.
No puzzle was really hard to figure out but I don't think they are suposed to for now as the first act seems like a tutorial, that said they are really well integrated to the plot, there is also a minigame and I hope more are added, it's a nice contrast to the gameplay.
This first episode was a little slow but I think it was needed to present the world to players, I'm overall happy with it, it ended on a high note and I'm with good expectations for the next episode!


I'll be reviewing the next acts as they come out, as of this review I came across two bugs, one which crashed my game and made me waste around 10 minutes, it's far from a mess but they are there, save often!

I might've expected too much out of it, but so much more could've been done, considering what the source material has to offer, regarding puzzles for example. I just want to say, I've retyped this a million times and I'm just not sure how to really feel about this game. 
I had very high expectations for it due to being a 2.5 million kickstart and being from Andrew Hussie, but this was just disapointing.. 

First off the backgrounds and everything artwise is amazing but the cut sences are choppy. Everything is 30 fps, which makes anything moving look as if they're constantly lagging. Also, moving around with only the mouse is fine, but going up and down stairs is a hassle without keyboard function. 
The game has a slow begining which it didn't start to really pick up till [spoiler] you are transported onto Alternia [/spoiler] but after that the game ends within 30 minuets of actual game. Which this honestly really pisses me off, because I spent 8 dollars expecting at the very least 4-5 hours of game play, but most of the actual game play was an hour at most... The entire game is mostly filler dialogue while clicking things.
I personally spent about an hour searching for the attic key because I was impaintent and couldn't figure out what I needed to do. But it was mostly because I skimmed the dialogue I needed to actually pay attention to. Which makes this even worse time wise because this was basically a 2 hour game for myself if I don't include the hour of pure anger searching. 

A lot of issues with achievements as well, after giving up on finding the key I saved and quit and upon playing the game, any achievements I was suppose to earn I didn't recieve. I finished this act completly with only the begining 4 achievements. I looked up the list of them, it appears I should have earned up to 5 more just by progression..  Which mostly what gave this away was when [spoiler] you change to jude and I didn't get the achievement for just being him [/spoiler]

I will most likely add more to this review, I  have high hopes for this game and since there are 3 more acts I will hope that Andrew will listen and try fixing a few issues... I mostly would like to see the graphics changed. 

But honestly, I was really hoping to play this longer than it lasted.. There is nothing more I can really do with it now, Hiveswap Act 1 will just sit in my library because I have gotten all the game play available out of it, and I just find that very disapointing.

34957792.review:
It's finally here!

So, I've just completed it and couldn't recommend it more! The art and music is incredible and really carries on the feeling of Homestuck, the web comic that this extends from. You certainly do not need to know anything about Homestuck to enjoy this, but there's a ton of stuff packed in for fans to appreciate and lore to speculate about.

The game itself had no issues, although the screen does have black bars around the top and bottom occasionally, or some clickable parts of the screen half-cut off. This is most likely related to me playing the game in fullscreen in 4k resolution, but I figured I'd mention it anyway. That's about the most I've noticed here and there, but it doesn't stop you from experiencing all the game offers.

It's basically an old-school point-and-click puzzle solver and there's tons to explore. You can interact with just about everything you can see in the environment and use items together or on the surroundings and it almost always gives you a unique message about it - there has to be literally thousands of all unique lines. The highlight of the game is probably that - the cute and quirky dialogue, with an obvious huge amount of thought put into it.

This is, as to my knowledge, act 1 of 4. After that, a separate game will be released which tells the events from the opposite perspective. The first act was pretty short, but with about half the steam achievements unlocked from one playthrough, it's pretty guaranteed that there's way more I missed, even though I was pretty careful about exploring. I'd say you'll get about two or so hours out of this, which is pretty good because there's replay value in my opinion, especially for fans of Homestuck. The pricetag at $8 USD is an amazing value, and the soundtrack is so dense and great, I'd say get it if you have the money to spare.

Congrats to Andrew Hussie and the developers at What Pumpkin! They smashed it out of the park.

Ok so, I've just finished this chapter (or at least, I presume I have? I'll touch upon that in a moment,) and following an initial restart due to some graphical glitches (sky dissapearing in one section, main world screen minimised and jumping about as I moved) I found myself having a very enjoyable experiance with the game. The small references are great but not enough to alienate any new comers to the homestuck series, as well as leaving you ready for more. The story itself is great and the characters are interesting and lovable! (or at least the ones you're meant to love.)

My first run through of the chapter took me about 2.4 hours, and what interests me is I'm still missing around 20 achievements. I don't know if this means theres more to the game than I've done, but the only none-secret achievement talks about 'picking up where you left off.' I don't know if this means there's more to this first chapter that I'm missing, but  if I'm not then I have mixed feelings about this time spent. On one hand, I enjoyed every moment of it and would happily play it all again, but on the other hand it feels fairly short considering the time spent putting it together. I'm aware it's episodic and I now hope that following chapters come rather swiftly? But if we wind up waiting a year+ for roughly 2.5 hours every time, then I can't help but feel a little cheated. 

As a whole, however, the game itself is fun and interesting! I certainly recommend giving it a go, but if you're worried about play time then I recommend waiting until more is out.

34957643.review:
Lushly rendered backgrounds, expressive animation, and imaginative environments pepper a classic point-and-click adventure the likes of which you may remember from decades past. This is chiefly a story game, and thankfully the writing is snappy, clever, and genuinely funny. Had me giggling stupidly from bootup. As with the webcomic which inspired it, Hiveswap's cast of characters are well-realized and quick to grow on you, their eclectic interests and personality quirks mixing well with the game's frequently referential, frequently metafictional, and constantly wry sense of humor. 

And speaking of humor, it is -everywhere-. Every one of the numerous environments are packed with clickables with amusing bits of dialogue, and nearly every obtainable item can be used with any other item, or any background object, to produce a unique dialogue or interaction. The amount of (optional) text in this game is absolutely boggling. 

As of writing, the game suffers some occasional graphic bugs, depending on your resolution, including improperly aligned cameras. It is not immediately clear what background elements can and cannot be interacted with from a glance, which interrupted gameplay, though this happened rarely, and was a minor issue. The graphical issues are annoying, but hardly deal-breaking. 

Those gripes aside, the game is bursting with personality, promising a weird and hilarious adventure through a mysterious and enthralling world. Short, but cheap at the price - and with the promise of more to come, Hiveswap lays a very strong foundation.

My imperessions:

 - Yeah, every single object combination has a unique description.

 - The writing feels very similar to Homestuck's writing. So if you liked Homestuck, you'll like this game.

Some people have reported graphical glitches, but my playthrough was spotless. Take the concerns with a grain of salt.

34957351.review:
For such a long development cycle, the game is atrociously short, only clocking to about two hours playtime for the average player. I understand that the game is being released in acts, but until the other three are released, or at least have /some kind/ of release date, I'd strongly reccomend against purchasing it. 

As it stands now, Hiveswap plays more like a demo for the full game, instead of a full game. I don't feel like I was burned on the price, being so low, but I was really hoping for more. 

If you watch the trailers, you've basically seen the whole game. The entire plot is spelled out there. Know this before going in.


That aside, there are small bugs within the game, including a really, really bad issue with the camera panning over to other rooms while still staying on the room you're in. On top of this, there is no "losing" hivewap, it is esentially a visual novel, and less of a game. These are minor issues overall, and didn't impact my playthrough all to much, but they are worth noting.

On the upside, the art is fantastic, and the animated cutscenes have some charm to them. The writing did give me a chuckle, and was very evocative of Homestuck, if that's the kind of thing you care about. The soundtrack was limited, and became really repedative, but was very enjoyable for a while. 

Overall, Hiveswap is a silghly more involved visual novel, with pretty pictures and nice animation, but doesn't actually feature very much outside of the content shown off in it's trailers. Fans who were expecting more will be dissapointed, and I can't reccomend this to any adventure game fans who are looking for something new. Hard pass, at least until the story itself is completed.

The story is great! I'm only 'halfway' or maybe even one fourth of the way through the game (considering I dont really know where it ends yet), but it's gripping. The music fits and gives you the lighthearted feel of a teenager exploring and doing all she can, even while monsters ruin her house and endanger her she's just doing her objectives as told and asked by her younger brother. 

Theres so much information and lighthearted plots that help break the tension while also building, the hints through text dialouge and even during strifing really helped provide hints, while the hint button was literally a joke.

34954953.review:
Oh my god the references! There's so much nostalgia here for me. I grew up in the period this game is set, so there's so many toys and other junk that I recognize. That aside, this game is, SO FAR, fantastic. If it keeps this level of quality that I've had in the first hour, then it's going to be one of my all-time favourite point/click adventure games.

The music, the visuals, the humor! And the hidden achievements! I just got an achievement for trying to feed the Bubsy poster a pet treat. The result was hilarious.


EDIT: I've just finished ACT 1, which is currently all that's available. Here's my thoughts on my experience:

I'm sure if you only spent your time solving puzzles, you could beat it in about 20 minutes. But that's not what I did. I spent as much time as possible using every object and action on everything else even to the point where I got an achievement for trying to use a pigeon on 30 different objects.

3 hours later, I was very satisfied with the experience, and I will probably play through it again tomorrow to try different object interactions. I hope ACT 2 doesn't take too long to release.

If you're looking for reviews of specific things or whatever, then here you go.

Visuals: Very familiar to Homestuck fans. Some camera errors that don't impede gameplay that I'm sure will be fixed soon.

Audio: The soundtrack is stuck in my head.

UI: The top bar can get in the way of some puzzles, so if you're stuck, maybe try minimizing it while you look around. On the subject, there is no highlight on the interactable objects (aside from your cursor changing when hovering over), which I feel was actually a good choice. When you discover some funny writing by doing something like, as a previous example, feeding a pet treat to a Bubsy poster, it feels all the more special by the knowledge that the game didn't explicitly try to tell you there was stuff you could do with it at all.

Stability: Well, in all the time I played it, it didn't crash. That's something.

Story/Writing: Top quality writing. The story definitely seems to be accessible to people who have never read Homestuck. In fact, I think it will make those people go and start reading it.

If you've got any specific questions, leave a comment on this review. I don't write reviews often so maybe I've missed something you want to know.

39506604.review:
[h1]More of this, please. [/h1]
I'm going to be honest: I really don't like point-n-click games (with the exception of the Ace Attorney series) and this game presents my problems with them: Gameplay-wise, they're boring. A lot of meaningless text, with no voice acting. Most of the time you find yourself relying on a guide because you easily get lost on what you have to do to progress the story because solving the puzzles aren't clear enough. (◔_◔)

However, despite that P&C games aren't what I would usually play, this game just kept me smiling the entire way no matter what. It just has this adorable charm to it that makes it impossible to hate it.

[b][u]THIS GAME SO FREAKING CUTE![/u][/b]
It doesn't matter if I'm a bit bias for games that have hand drawn art styles, I am in love with this game's art! (≧◡≦) ♡ It's just so adorably cute and it fits amusing story and characters so perfectly. Just take a look at the screenshots of the game and tell me how it doesn't make you want to play the game to completion. There is just this immense child-like innocence you feel while playing HIVESWAP. The animations are so charming that I can feel it touching my inner child. While the soundtrack wasn't legendary by any means, it definitely did get my attention. It's a perfect rhythm for the theme of the game. 

[b][u]Gameplay[/u][/b]
I've already said what I don't like about P&C games and that this game has pretty much all of my issues of why I don't play them. It was kinda annoying to have to rely on a guide to beat the game, and while I accept that it's not my style of play, I believe better hints can be placed for those who aren't too familiar with P&C games. 
There was some interesting RPG-like battle segements in the game that I have mixed feelings about. The battles are like a hybrid of Point & Click and RPG, there's no damage stats and all that jazz. It's more of a puzzle than anything. And while I do think it works with the game just fine, I still wish it had a traditional RPG experience with it that balances with the game's P&C game style.

[b][u]The Story[/u][/b]
I love the characters and the writing is amusing. The best thing about the games loveable characters is that the art style suits just how cute and loveable they are. I really did enjoy playing as Joey all the way and I'm really interested in where this is all going. I'm not one for episodic games (especially when you have to wait until each chapter is released), but HIVESWAP: Act 1 really delivers on what an Episode 1 of a game should do: [i]Make you excited for the adventure that awaits, while keeping the beginning a fun experience[/i]. You obviously won't get mind-blowing plot twists here, however I'll say it's a really good start for an adorable and fun story. Without trying to spoil anything, I would say the strongest point of Act 1 is really when it concludes. It's so cute and concludes nicely without feeling like an annoying cliffhanger.

[b]Do I recommend HIVESWAP: Act 1?[/b]
ABSOLUTELY. Even if you despise Point & Click games, if you find the game interesting enough to play, I highly doubt you will feel disappointed as long as you know what you're getting into.

39481014.review:
https://youtu.be/4uuaNZxAWc8

Monsters are everywhere! In this amazing hand-drawn point & Click Adventure game called Hiveswap.

First thing I noticed in Hiveswap we're the great cartoonish graphics. I love the artful indie games with hand-drawn elements. I later on learned this game is based on the Homestuck web comics. So I probably missed some of the inside jokes, it was still a lot of fun to play even as a non Homestuck fan. Hiveswap has very charming graphics and a witty written storyline. It's a classic point & click game with a lot of text, at some points the game felt more like a Graphic novel story, however the game does have fun puzzle elements. The game has unique Combat scenes, sometimes you will encounter monsters and you will have to tap dance, ballet dance and use other tricks to get past them. This game has a lot of attention to detail, you can click on just about anything. If you love story rich Point & click games I definitely recommend it!

The Good:
+ Great artwork and graphics
+ Fun witty humor
+ Good music
+ Lovable characters

The Bad:
- Wished it was longer
- Puzzles are sometimes simple

It can be completed in about 2-4 hours, depending on your pace.

40948593.review:
I'm conflicted about Hiveswap: Act 1. As a Homestuck fan who kickstarted the project, I'm pretty disappointed. But as a fan of point-and-click adventures and obscure references, I totally dig it. I was actually super hype to play this game on release day, but within 20 minutes of playing, I encountered a bug and ragequit for a few months until I could get the sour taste out of my mouth. I really wanted to properly enjoy this game, and it's a shame I couldn't, because it's actually quite nice, even with the sometimes awkward controls.

The music is catchy, the writing is fun, and the artwork is eye-candy at the best of times, but the overall content is lacking. Even though I understand all of the drama surrounding this game's production (really, I've been nothing but supportive and patient over the years), I'm left feeling just... bitter that Hiveswap's first installment feels more like some kind of demo/teaser. Most of my hours put into this game were after my initial playthrough when I decided to achievement hunt. I got distracted a lot and just tabbed out, letting the music play in the background. At most, you're probably only going to get a couple hours out of this game's first act, and that's only if you're hellbent on testing out every item interaction.

Right now I only tentatively recommend Hiveswap. It does a lot of things right, but, ultimately, I'm frustrated with the lack of actual story I was able to play after 5+ years of waiting. Here's hoping Act 2 and beyond adds a considerable amount of content to overwrite my current Kickstarter backer bias.

You know? Many have tried to make a title in a series something that people who don't know about the series could enjoy, some even trying to appeal to both old fans and newcomers alike. Many have failed, but NOT THIS TIME! For the fans of Homestuck, it's a visit to the world they grew attached to and wanted to know more about, while for newcomers, it's a (less foul-mouthed and less bloddy) gateway to Homestuck.



The story is interesting, expanding on what Homestuck has built. But because of what the events cover and the nature of Homestuck, even though it's obiously a prequel, it's impossible to tell what will happen.


Long story short, if you're a fan of Homestuck, this is a game made for you. And if you don't know Homestuck, then this game will introduce you to it.


Though this is only the first Act, so there's still a lot more to come. But the future looks bright.


So I will give this game all of the recommendations, ALL OF THEM!

40692689.review:
This game *so far* has most certainly been worth the wait. I'm quite the Homestuck fan so this game has immediately gotten me in love with the Homestuck universe again.

From this game though, it's quite balancing for people who are new to Homestuck, and those who aren't.
For people who are new, I believe it gives you a great introduction to the characters in the story. It doesn't just toss you into it expecting you to know something, which in other cases is rather poor design in my opinion in gaming, unless it's just a series continued after the first one, which is of course always recommended to start the first part of the series. 
If you haven't read Homestuck though, and are completely new to the Homestuck universe, I really do highly suggest you read it. Homestuck is a wonderful web comic that everyone says is terrible, but it's really not.

Then of course for the people that actually know about Homestuck and have been through the hell of reading all of Homestuck, you can be like "Hey there's <insert name here>!", which in my opinion is a treat for those that have read all of Homestuck.

Anyways, general gameplay talk though.
The whole point-and-click thing, I'm totally in love with it. I think it's done well, just like many other point-and-click games out there. Nothing too extreme or simple, which in this case is good for this type of game. I feel it's more story based than actual game mechanic based. Or I could be wrong, I don't entirely know, just going by what I experienced. 

Then there's the story progression. The story progression I feel is just the right amount of pace. It could be because of how much time I spent on the puzzles, I don't know hard they actually are in general but it felt like the right type of pace for me.

Then there's the music. The music is outstanding, I'd get the music but oh well, money. The music fits with the scene just right, feels like I could actually think about the scenes just listening to the music by itself.

Last but not least, my most favorite part of the game, the artwork. The artwork is SO well done. I don't know why but the artwork just allures me so much. It's for sure taken them time to actually implement the artwork, unless they're extreme professionals and did most of it in just hours, which is still even impressive. It's for sure a step up from the actual Homestuck comic, which don't get me wrong I love Homestuck's style of art, it actually inspires me. This type of art is quite detailed though, and for sure a bump up of what Homestuck was. So the people who made the artwork, bless your soul.

40468481.review:
Disclaimer: I ended up receiving this game for free, after attempting to purchase it on sale on chrono.gg. There was an issue with the payment not going through so they sent me a Steam code this morning for the trouble.

I became aware of this game quite a while ago. As a long time reader of MS Paint Adventures, and a fan of Homestuck, it was hard to NOT know about this game and the controversy surrounding its development and its delays. All that aside, I did not expect much from this, as games stuck in that kind of limbo generally either never come out, or just don't do well when they finally are released. I ended up being pleasantly surprised.

Although short (around 2 hours), I ended up running through Act 1 in one sitting. I'm pretty excited for Act 2 now. The writing is done very well, and is very reminiscent of the Homestuck comic. I also enjoyed the animation, although it was a little blocky at times. The decision to go with 2D after the original 3D plan was a good one, but you can tell that so many design changes had an effect on quality of the product.

The last thing I want to comment on is the music. Homestuck ended up with a nice little trove of aspiring composers, and I know some of them also worked on this game, although I'm not sure which ones. Toby Fox of Undertale acclaim was involved in the music here, and I can definitely hear some of his tones coming through.

Overall, I would recommend this if you are a fan of Homestuck - some of the references thrown in are a nice little touch. You may not enjoy this as much if you are not already a fan of Andrew Hussie, but I say give it a try anyway.

This game in one word? "Wow".
It's an adventure gem. Not only it has gorgeous artwork, hilarious dialogue, likable and well developed main characters, toby fox's music and intriguing mystery... but you can combine *every* *single* *item* with *everything*. And each combination will give you unique, well-written and extremely humorous lines! I can't imagine an amount of work and creativity that this took.
And frankly... isn't this just what the best adventure games are about? Combining everything together for no reason, just laughing your ass off? I just spent literally three hours in the first location just using everything on everything... and had an absolute blast doing it.
My only small concern is no option to highlight useful items, and just a bit of pixel hunting involved because of it, which, however, just makes finding insane combinations even more rewarding.

40245353.review:
[h1]Let me tell you about Hiveswap[/h1]

I started reading the Homestuck webcomic back in about 2015 when some of my friends showed an interest in it, and though I have since learned that the community [u]can be[/u] completely toxic and obnoxious, I do hold the webcomic dear to my heart, as i've made many friends from it. I feel like I have to preface this by saying: [u]No, I have not completely read through Homestuck in its entirety.[/u]

[i]i know, i know, i plan on it, though i love homestuck, ive just never had the time to read anything past act 5, i'll get to it though, i swear![/i]

Now, with that out of the way, let's actually get the the part where I tell you what Hiveswap actually is, if you dont already know. [i]Hiveswap is a point and click adventure game based in the universe of the wildly popular webcomic "Homestuck" by Andrew Hussie[/i]. Hiveswap features an entirely new story with entirely new characters not featured in the webcomic itself [i]which means[/i] that you can actually play this game without any knowledge of Homestuck, other than that it exists, and is what the game is based off of, [i]have i mentioned that this is a homestuck game?[/i]

[h1]PROS[/h1]
[list]
[*] Well made story with fun characters that are hard to dislike.
[*] Great music with much of it by Toby Fox (Creator of Undertale).
[*] Only the first part in a series, meaning more to come.
[*] [strike]It's Homestuck[/strike]
[/list]

[h1]CONS[/h1]
...
wait...
. . .

I can't think of anything?

This is a first.. no seriously.. I cannot think of anything bad about this game, and i'm not just saying that because "OMG IT'S HOMESTUCK IT'S PERFECT!!" I legitimately cannot think of anything. It kind of irks me to be honest. What is a review if it doesn't have its pros and cons?

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]

All I can say is that if you like Homestuck, you won't be disappointed, and if you think the game looks sweet, you'll probably like it. I'ts hard for me to say that the game is a 10/10 just because there are no cons, so i'll give it a rating based on my enjoyment.

[h1]That score is: 9.6/10[/h1]

Go buy the game, and if you haven't already, try out Homestuck, don't be turned off by Homestuck just because its fanbase. The rules of fanbases don't just apply to Homestuck, there are many fanbases that totally misrepresent content, and it's only because, when you have a ton of people liking something, you are bound to have some socially awkward weirdos in there too. 

Good Luck!

40162498.review:
Hiveswap is a simple point-and-click game that takes place in the Homestuck universe. A girl named Joey Claire and her brother Jude come into contact with alien creatures that are surrounding the house. It is revealed later on that this may have some ties to a mysterious draped-over object in the house's attic. The game progresses through the Harley manor until Joey is sent to Alternia, the homeworld of the trolls.

I thoroughly enjoyed the game. Hiveswap opened me up to a lot of things I wasn't aware about before within the Homestuck fandom and got me interested in the fandom itself. The visuals and music are exceptionally well-done, although I'm not exactly sure why the characters' idle animations run at 10 frames a second. For fans of Homestuck, the game is also peppered with references to the previous webcomic series, from subtle objects in the background to the implementation of a Sylladex-esque inventory system. Overall, Hiveswap was very fun to play and I'm eagerly awaiting Act II to release.

[h1]I rate this game a 9/10.[/h1]
Definitely one to pick up, especially for Homestuck fans.

40146710.review:
Mechanically clumsy and simplistic, HIVESWAP is still worth experiencing for the charming dialogue and detailed environments. This is essentially a high quality "young adult" story in video game form, featuring a narrative tone that avoids both condescension and preachiness. Ruminations on the meaning of friendship and family are woven into the beginning of a sci-fi adventure that seems span galaxies and dimensions.

I say beginning because this "ACT 1" is short and incomplete. I finished the game in two hours, with another couple hours of idle time when I left the app running and went to dinner. At $8.00 or so per act (on sale for six at the moment), I'm not sure what the value proposition will eventually be. Are three acts planned? Five? If there's a complete edition, what will that cost? I think the story and world here are worth experiencing, but I'm not sure if five acts of this would be recommended over $40 of other adventure games on Steam.

I never read a single bit of the homestuck comic this is inspired by, clearly fans of the original source material would have a lot more fun playing this game but this will be a completely blind opinion on the game. and to be honest im pretty excited to see where the story goes, but i am also feeling like its a bit too underwhelming for what it could have been.

the artwork is fantastic, well animated, has a great style, and has a lot of charm to what you see. the story seemed fairly interesting, though i wish we were able to see both sides of the story instead of having to wait for another game to see the aliens side of the story. and the puzzles certainly fun and never felt annoying, some critics might say the game is too easy and i can see where they are coming from, but its clear this game is a lot more casual in its adventuring so i can accept that.

what i dont accept is the missed potential, the game has a mechanic of being able to switch between multiple characters, but the story never really made you switch between them, compared to a game like broken age where you really could play either story whenever you want and switch between them, you only switch between the characters when the story makes you have to, its incredibly linear in that regard and feels like a dissapointment.

and the game is definitely too short, the story only lasted me 2 hours, which is fine for the most part, seeing as i accept companies like telltale and dontnod for giving short episodic stories, but they always give you a small gap of time between them, maybe about 2 months of so at most, but seeing as fans have had to wait almost 6 months for the 2nd half of this game, it feels frustrating as the story was just getting good and we are stuck on a cliffhanger with the ending barely in sight. i will still reccomend the game, but i feel you definitely should wait until act 2 comes out around spring or so before buying. and i am hoping that you dont have to pay extra for act 2 similar to how you will probably have to pay for the alient half (hauntswitch) when that comes out

39899257.review:
The great part about this game is that it is a standalone piece from the webcomic that its storyline originates from. As much as I love Homestuck, and all its ironically/ maybe not ironic glory, gentlepersonly showmanship, and actiony whimsical jokery, it's a good thing that you don't HAVE to have read the webcomic in it's entirety, or possibly at all to get what's going on in the game. Will you see some easter eggs if you have? OFC! But, you don't have to come from it to learn something and have a great time. Whether you're fresh off the Homestuck express, or green as a scallion in the ground, you're sure to have a good time here, and that's what's up.

The characters are well thought out, as usual, and they have their own unique personalities that follows in the same vein as we've all come to love. Or at least, I do. It's super interesting to see what different hobbies and differences each character embodies over time and how they grow from those beginnings to the individuals they end up as in the end. It's an evolving spectrum of character development and the friendliness and care shown between the characters about what is and isn't a good relationship between two people is really enlightening for the player as well as the characters themselves. It's a ride in itself. Like in Battleblock Theatre, we're taking a journey on the great ship, Friendship, who knows where we'll end up next.

The artwork is classic Homestuck style, which was comforting to me, and led me to something familiar where I could venture from Nostalgia into a vast beyond of a new world unfamiliar to me as of yet. It gave a little better of a view of the characters as they were when they were younger, and other tidbits we might not have known before, which was kind of cool in itself. The cutscenes were great, and helped to draw the storyline and plot together. The dialogue was fun, and in general, I'm ready to play Act 2. So ready.

It is short though (it's only episode 1 of 4 (or 8, as it might turn out)), completed it in ~3 hours, but can be padded out if you like to explore and interact with everything (which rewards you with fun writing and dialogue) or go looking for secret achievements.
